1-6-3-11: Imposition Of Penalties
1-6-3-12: Powers And Duties
1-6-4: Ordinances
1-6-4-1: Style Of Ordinances; Publication
1-6-4-2: Passage And Approval
1-6-4-3: Technical Codes
1-6-4-4: One Subject; Expressed In Title
1-6-4-5: Effective Date
1-6-1: ELECTION; TERMS OF OFFICE:
On the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November in odd numbered years,
a town election shall be held, at which the qualified electors of the town
shall elect the officers of the town whose terms of office will expire.
Members of the town council shall be elected for four (4) year, overlapping
terms of office. The elections for town council and mayor shall be conducted on
a nonpartisan basis. Council members shall be elected at large. Two (2) council
members shall be elected at large every two (2) years. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
1-6-2: MAYOR:
The mayor shall be the chief executive and chief administrative officer of the
town. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
1-6-2-1: QUALIFICATIONS:
No person shall be eligible for the office of mayor unless he shall be at least
twenty one (21) years old, a resident of the state for at least three (3)
years, a resident of the town or an area which has been annexed by the town for
two (2) years next preceding his election to said office and a qualified
elector pursuant to article IV, section 2 of the Montana constitution. The
mayor shall reside in the municipality during his term of office.
The mayor shall be elected for a four (4) year term of office. The election
shall be at large on a nonpartisan basis. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
1-6-2-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The mayor is the chief executive officer of the town and has power to:
   A.   Appoint Nonelective Officers: Nominate and, with the consent of the
council, appoint all nonelective officers of the town provided for by the
council, except as provided in title 7 of Montana Code Annotated.
   B.   Suspend Or Remove Nonelective Officers: Suspend and, with the consent
of the council, remove any nonelective officer, stating in the suspension or
removal the cause thereof.
   C.   Execute Ordinances; Supervise Subordinate Officers: Cause the
ordinances of the town to be executed, and supervise the discharge of official
duties by all subordinate officers.
   D.   Statement Of Affairs: Communicate to the council, at the beginning of
every session, and more often if deemed necessary, a statement of the affairs
of the town, with such recommendations as he may deem proper.
   E.   Recommendations: Recommend to the council such measures connected with
the public health, cleanliness and ornament of the town, and the improvement of
the government and finances as he deems expedient.
   F.   Ordinances And Resolutions:
      1.   Approval; Veto: Approve all ordinances and resolutions of the
council adopted by it and in case the same do not meet his approbation, to
return the same to the next regular meeting of the council, with his objections
in writing. No ordinance or resolution so vetoed by the mayor shall go into
effect unless the same be afterwards passed by two-thirds (2/3) vote of the
whole number of members of the council.
      2.   Failure To Return: Veto any objectionable part of a resolution or
ordinance, and approve the other parts. If the mayor fails to return any
resolution or ordinance as aforesaid, the same takes effect without further
action.
   G.   Call Special Meetings: Call special meetings of the council, and when
so called, he must state by message the object of the meeting, and the business
of the meeting must be restricted to the object stated.
   H.   Statement Of Financial Condition: Cause to be presented, once in three
(3) months, a full and complete statement of the financial condition of the
town.
   I.   Bid At Tax Or Judicial Sales: Bid on for the town any property sold at
a tax or judicial sale, where the town is a party or interested.
   J.   Oaths: Take and administer oaths.
   K.   Request Militia: Request that the governor call out the militia to aid
the mayor in suppressing riots or other disorderly conduct, preventing and
extinguishing fires, securing the peace and safety of the town, or carrying
into effect any law or ordinance; and any person who does not obey such call
forfeits to the town a fine not exceeding twenty five dollars ($25.00).
   L.   Require Exhibit Of Books: Require of any of the town officers an
exhibit of his books and papers.
   M.   Pardons: Grant pardons and remit fines and forfeitures for offenses
against town ordinances, when in his judgment public justice would be thereby
subserved; but he must report all pardons granted, with the reasons therefor,
to the next council.
   N.   Other Duties: Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by law or
by resolution or ordinance of the council.
   O.   Jurisdiction Of Power: The mayor has such power as may be vested in him
by ordinance of the town, in and over all places within five (5) miles of the
boundaries of the town, for the purpose of enforcing the health and quarantine
ordinances and regulations thereof. (1977 Code § 2.08.020; amd. 2000 Code)
   P.   Enforce Laws: Enforce laws, the town charter, ordinances and
resolutions.
   Q.   Administer Affairs Of Government: Administer the affairs of the town
government.
   R.   Carry Out Policies: Carry out policies established by the council.
   S.   Execute Bond, Notes, Contracts, Etc.: Execute bonds, notes, contracts,
and written obligations of the council, subject to the approval of the council.
   T.   Prepare Council Agenda; Preside At Council Meetings: Prepare the
council agenda, preside at council meetings and may take part in council
discussions.
   U.   Administrative Duties: The mayor may:
      1.   Appoint one or more administrative assistants to assist in the
supervision and operation of the town government, and such administrative
assistants shall be answerable to the mayor and the town council;
      2.   Appoint, with the consent of a majority of the council, all
department heads including either a clerk, treasurer or clerk/treasurer; remove
department heads; and appoint and remove all other employees;
      3.   Prepare the budget in consultation with the council and department
heads;
      4.   Exercise control and supervision of all departments and boards.
(Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
1-6-2-3: PRESIDING OFFICER OF COUNCIL:
The mayor is the presiding officer of the council, must sign the journals
thereof and all warrants on the town treasury, and decide by his vote all ties,
and has no other vote. (1977 Code § 2.08.030)
1-6-2-4: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The mayor may be removed from office by a finding, adopted by the affirmative
vote of three (3) council members, that the office has become vacant as
prescribed by law or by recall of the mayor by the electors of the town of
Manhattan as prescribed by law. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
1-6-3: COUNCIL:
1-6-3-1: QUALIFICATIONS OF COUNCIL MEMBERS; COUNCIL CHAIR:
   A.   Qualifications: Anyone who is eighteen (18) years of age or older, a
citizen of Montana, a resident of the town of Manhattan for a period of at
least one year immediately preceding his/her election to office and is a
qualified elector pursuant to article IV, section 2 of the Montana constitution
is eligible to hold the office of council member.
   B.   Chair Of Council: The council shall have a chair who shall be elected
by the members of the council from among their own number. The chair of the
council shall preside at council meetings when the mayor is absent, and shall
vote as other members of the council. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
1-6-3-2: REGULAR AND SPECIAL MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meeting: The town council shall hold a regular meeting for the
transactions of town business on the second Thursday of each month, and such
other meetings to which the council, by order, may adjourn, or which may be
called. The council shall establish its rules of procedures and time and place
of meetings by resolution. (Ord. 10-003, 9-14-2010)
   B.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called by the mayor, or at
the request of three (3) members of the council. When special meetings are
called, the clerk/treasurer shall give reasonable notice thereof, in writing,
to the mayor and all members of the council present in the town. (1977 Code §
2.12.020)
1-6-3-3: QUORUM:
A majority of the members of the council constitutes a quorum for the
transaction of business, but a lesser number may meet and adjourn to any time
stated, and may compel the attendance of absent members under such rules and
penalties as the council may prescribe. Unless otherwise required by law, this
chapter, or the town's charter, the affirmative vote of a majority of the
council members present at a lawful meeting of the council shall be required
for all official actions of the council. A minimum of three (3) council members
must be present to convene a lawful meeting of the council. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-
2008)
1-6-3-4: RULES:
The council may determine the rules of its proceedings, punish its members for
improper conduct, and expel any member for the same by a two-thirds (2/3) vote
of the members elected, and must cause to be kept a journal of the proceedings,
which must be open to inspection. (1977 Code § 2.12.040)
1-6-3-5: VOTING:
The ayes and noes must be called and recorded on the final passage of an
ordinance, bylaw, or resolution, or making any contract; the voting on the
election or appointment of any officer must be viva voce; and a majority of the
whole number of the members elected is requisite to appoint or elect an
officer, and such vote must be recorded. (1977 Code § 2.12.050)
1-6-3-6: GENERAL POWERS:
The town council has power to make and pass all bylaws, ordinances, orders, and
resolutions not repugnant to the constitution of the United States or of the
state, or of the provisions of state law, necessary for the government or
management of the affairs of the town, for the execution of the powers vested
in the body corporate, and for carrying into effect the provisions of title 7
of Montana Code Annotated. (1977 Code § 2.12.060; amd. 2000 Code)
1-6-3-7: PRESCRIBING DUTIES AND COMPENSATION:
The town council has power to fix compensation, and to prescribe the duties of
all officers and other employees of the town, subject to the limitations
mentioned in Montana Code Annotated. (1977 Code § 2.12.070; amd. 2000 Code)
1-6-3-8: OBTAINING REPORTS:
The town council has power to require from an officer at any time a report in
detail of the transactions in his office or any matter connected therewith.
(1977 Code § 2.12.080)
1-6-3-9: CONTRACTS:
The town council has power to make any and all contracts necessary to carry
into effect the powers granted by state law, and to provide for the manner of
executing the same. (1977 Code § 2.12.090)
1-6-3-10: ARRESTS:
The town council has power to make regulations authorizing the police of the
town to make arrests of persons charged with crimes, within the limits of the
town, within five (5) miles thereof, and along the line of water supply of the
town. (1977 Code § 2.12.100)
1-6-3-11: IMPOSITION OF PENALTIES:
The town council has power to impose fines and penalties for the violation of
any town ordinance as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this title. (1977 Code § 2.12.110; amd. 2000 Code)
1-6-3-12: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The town council shall be the legislative and policy determining body
of the town. All powers of the town shall be vested in the town council except
as otherwise provided by law or the town charter and the council shall provide
for the exercise thereof and for the performance of all duties and obligations
imposed by law, this chapter, or the town's charter.
   B.   The council may override the mayor's veto by the affirmative vote of
three (3) members of the council. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
1-6-4: ORDINANCES:
1-6-4-1: STYLE OF ORDINANCES; PUBLICATION:
The style of ordinances shall be as follows: "Be it ordained by the Council of
the Town of Manhattan". All ordinances may be published or posted, as
prescribed by the council. (1977 Code § 1.12.010)
1-6-4-2: PASSAGE AND APPROVAL:
All ordinances, bylaws and resolutions must be passed by the council and
approved by the mayor, or the person acting in his stead, and must be recorded
in a book kept by the clerk/treasurer called "The Ordinance Book", and numbered
in decimal system. (1977 Code § 1.12.020)
1-6-4-3: TECHNICAL CODES:
   A.   Power To Adopt: The town council may adopt technical building, zoning,
health, electrical, fire, and plumbing codes in whole or in part by reference.
   B.   Publication Of Notice; Copy On File: At least fifteen (15) days prior
to final action by the council, notice of intent to adopt a technical code in
whole or in part by reference shall be published in a newspaper of general
circulation in the town and one copy of the code, or part to be adopted, shall
be filed with the town clerk/treasurer for inspection by the public.
   C.   Adoption By Reference: If a technical code, or part of a code, is
adopted by reference, a record in the ordinance book may be made by recording
the ordinance without setting forth the provisions of the code, or part of the
code, adopted. (1977 Code § 1.12.030; amd. 2000 Code)
1-6-4-4: ONE SUBJECT; EXPRESSED IN TITLE:
Ordinances take effect from and after their passage, except as otherwise
ordered, and no ordinance shall be passed containing more than one subject,
which shall be clearly expressed in its title, except ordinances for the
codification and revision of ordinances. (1977 Code § 1.12.040)
1-6-4-5: EFFECTIVE DATE:
   A.   General Measures: No ordinance passed by the town council shall become
effective until thirty (30) days after its passage, except general
appropriation ordinances providing for the ordinary and current expenses of the
town and, excepting also emergency measures. All resolutions shall be
immediately effective unless a delayed effective date is specified. (Ord. 06-
009, 9-12-2006)
   B.   Emergency Measures: In the case of emergency measures, the emergency
must be expressed in the preamble or in the body of the measure, and the
measure must receive a two-thirds (2/3) vote of all the members elected. In
emergency ordinances, the resolutions shall include only such measures as are
immediately necessary for the preservation of peace, health, and safety, and
shall not include a franchise or license to a corporation or individual; any
provisions for the sale of real estate; any lease or letting of any property
for a period exceeding one year; or the purchase or sale of personal property
exceeding five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in value. (1977 Code § 1.12.050)
CHAPTER 7
TOWN OFFICERS
SECTION:
1-7-1: Principal Officers
1-7-2: Elective And Appointive Officers
1-7-3: Eligibility
1-7-4: Commencement Of Term
1-7-5: Vacancy
1-7-6: Removal
1-7-7: Council May Abolish Office
1-7-8: Consolidation Of Appointive Offices
1-7-9: Salaries
1-7-10: Oath; Bond
1-7-1: PRINCIPAL OFFICERS:
   A.   Executive: The executive officers of the town are the mayor, chief of
police, and such officers for the assessment, collection, auditing,
safekeeping, and disbursing of the revenue, and keeping of the records and
journals of the town, as the council may provide.
   B.   Legislative: The legislative officers are the council members.
   C.   Judicial: There may be a judicial officer termed a city judge, or a
justice of the peace may fill the office of city judge. (1977 Code § 2.04.010;
amd. 2000 Code)
1-7-2: ELECTIVE AND APPOINTIVE OFFICERS:
   A.   Elective: The officers of the town consist of one mayor and a total of
four (4) council members who must be elected by the qualified electors of the
town as provided in chapter 8 of this title. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
   B.   Appointive: There may be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and
consent of the council, one clerk, who may be ex officio assessor and a member
of the council, and one treasurer, who may be ex officio tax collector, and one
police chief, who may be ex officio street commissioner, one city judge, and
any other officers necessary to carry out the provisions of the town ordinances
and state law. (1977 Code § 2.04.020; amd. 2000 Code)
1-7-3: ELIGIBILITY 1 :
No person is eligible to any town office, elective or appointive, who is not a
citizen of the United States, and who has not resided in the town or an area
which has been annexed thereto for at least two (2) years immediately preceding
his election or appointment, and who is not a qualified elector thereof. (1977
Code § 2.04.030)
 
Notes
1 1. See constitution article IX, sections 7, 10, 11 for qualifications to hold
  office.
1-7-4: COMMENCEMENT OF TERM:
The terms of all officers elected at a town election are to commence on the
first Monday in January after such election. Appointive officers shall commence
their employment within ten (10) days after receiving notice of their
appointment. (1977 Code § 2.04.040; amd. 2000 Code)
1-7-5: VACANCY:
   A.   Vacancy Of Office: An office becomes vacant on the happening of any of
the following events before the expiration of the term of the incumbent:
      1.   The death of the incumbent.
      2.   A determination pursuant to Montana Code Annotated title 53, chapter
21, part 1, that the incumbent is mentally ill.
      3.   The incumbent's resignation.
      4.   The incumbent's removal from office.
      5.   The incumbent's absence from the town continuously for ten (10) days
without the consent of the council.
      6.   The incumbent's open neglect or refusal to discharge duties. (1977
Code § 2.04.050; amd. 2000 Code)
      7.   The incumbent's ceasing to be a resident of the town causes a
vacancy of his/her office. This subsection does not apply to an appointed town
officer who resides outside the town limits with the approval of the town
council and within a distance of the town approved by the town council. (Ord.
08-003, 4-8-2008)
      8.   The incumbent's ceasing to discharge the duty of office for a period
of three (3) consecutive months, except when prevented by illness or when
absent from the town by permission of the town council.
      9.   The incumbent's conviction of a felony or of any offense involving
moral turpitude or a violation of official duties.
      10.   The incumbent's refusal or neglect to file an official bond within
the time prescribed.
      11.   The decision of a competent tribunal declaring void the incumbent's
election or appointment. (1977 Code § 2.04.050; amd. 2000 Code)
   B.   Filling Vacancies:
      1.   When a vacancy occurs in the office of a council member, the
position shall be considered open and subject to nomination and election at the
next general municipal election, except the term of office shall be limited to
the unexpired term of the person who originally created the vacancy. Pending
such election and qualification the council shall appoint, by the affirmative
vote of the majority of the remaining council members, a person possessing the
qualifications for office required by law and this chapter, within thirty (30)
days of the vacancy to hold the office until the successor is elected and
qualified.
      2.   If there are fewer than three (3) council members serving in office
at the time of an appointment to fill council vacancies is required, the mayor
shall appoint, with the written consent of each of the incumbent council
members, a person possessing the qualifications for office required by law and
this chapter within thirty (30) days of the vacancy to hold the office until
the successor is elected and qualified.
      3.   When a vacancy occurs in the office of mayor, the position shall be
considered open and subject to nomination and election at the next general
municipal election, except the term of office shall be limited to the unexpired
term of the person originally creating the vacancy. Pending such election and
qualification the council shall appoint, by the affirmative vote of three (3)
council members, a person possessing the qualifications for the office required
by law and this chapter within thirty (30) days of the vacancy to hold the
office until the successor is elected and qualified. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
1-7-6: REMOVAL:
A council member may be removed from office by a finding, adopted by the
affirmative vote of three (3) council members, that the office has become
vacant as prescribed by law or by recall of a council member by the electors of
Manhattan, as prescribed by law. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
1-7-7: COUNCIL MAY ABOLISH OFFICE:
The town council may abolish, by majority vote of the council, any office,
except that of city judge, the appointment to which is made by the mayor with
the advice and consent of the council and may discharge any officer so
appointed. (1977 Code § 2.04.080; amd. 2000 Code)
1-7-8: CONSOLIDATION OF APPOINTIVE OFFICES:
The town council may, by ordinance, consolidate any of the offices, except that
of city judge, the appointment to which is made by the mayor with the advice
and consent of the council, and may require any of the elected officers to
perform any of the duties of an appointed officer whose office has been
abolished. (1977 Code § 2.04.090; amd. 2000 Code)
1-7-9: SALARIES:
The council shall annually, by ordinance or resolution, fix the salaries and
compensation of elected and appointed town officers and all town employees.
(1977 Code § 2.04.100; amd. 2000 Code)
1-7-10: OATH; BOND:
   A.   Oath: Each officer of the town must take the oath of office.
   B.   Bond:
      1.   Filing Of Bond Required: Any officer that is required to give bond
shall file the same, duly approved, within ten (10) days after receiving notice
of his election or appointment; or, if no notice be received, then on or before
the date fixed for the assumption by him of the duties of the office to which
he may have been elected or appointed. (1977 Code § 2.04.110)
      2.   Town Officers And Employees: Elected or appointed town officers and
employees shall be bonded in such sums as ordinance may require. The amount for
which a town officer or employee shall be bonded shall be based on the amount
of money or property handled and the opportunity for defalcation. The town
council shall actively solicit offers on a competitive basis from available
qualified insurance or surety companies before purchasing bonds. (1977 Code §
2.04.120)
      3.   Purchase Of Bonds: The council shall purchase all surety bonds for
town officers and employees. A bond may cover an individual officer or employee
or a blanket bond may cover all officers and employees, or any group or
combination of officers and employees. (1977 Code § 2.04.130)
      4.   Bond Conditions:
         a.   Faithful Performance: The condition of every official bond must
be that the principal shall well, truly and faithfully perform all official
duties then required of him by law, and also such additional duties as may be
imposed on him by any law of the state or the town subsequently enacted, and
that he will account for and pay over and deliver to the person or officer,
entitled to receive the same, all monies or other property that may come into
his hands as such officer. The principal and sureties upon any official bond
are also in all cases liable for the neglect, default, or misconduct in office
of any deputy, clerk, or employee, appointed or employed by such principal.
         b.   Execution: All official bonds must be signed and executed by the
principal and two (2) or more sureties, or by the principal and one or more
surety companies organized as such under the laws of this state, or licensed to
do business herein. (1977 Code § 2.04.140)
ARTICLE A. TOWN CLERK/TREASURER
SECTION:
1-7A-1: Office Created
1-7A-2: Supervision
1-7A-3: Qualifications
1-7A-4: Duties And Responsibilities
1-7A-5: Terms Of Employment
1-7A-6: Selection Guidelines
1-7A-1: OFFICE CREATED:
   A.   Offices Combined: There is hereby created the office of town clerk/
treasurer. The office of town clerk is hereby abolished and combined into the
position of town clerk/treasurer. (1977 Code §§ 2.06.010, 2.06.020; amd. 2000
Code)
   B.   General Purpose: To provide a variety of general administrative,
clerical, accounting, data processing, and technical work in maintaining
records and systems of the town government. (2000 Code)
1-7A-2: SUPERVISION:
   A.   Received: Works under the general supervision of the mayor.
   B.   Exercised: Exercises supervision over office personnel and other staff,
as assigned. (2000 Code)
1-7A-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Desired Minimum Qualifications:
      1.   Education And Experience:
         a.   A bachelor's degree in public or business administration,
political science, accounting or a related field, and
         b.   Two (2) years of progressively responsible experience in fiscal
management of a town or business management, or a related field required.
         c.   Six (6) years of experience may be substituted for a bachelor's
degree.
   B.   Necessary Knowledge, Skills And Abilities:
      1.   Working knowledge of the principles and practices of modern public
administration; extensive knowledge of office practices and procedures;
thorough knowledge of modern records management techniques, including legal
requirements for recording, retention and disclosure;
      2.   Skill in operation of listed tools and equipment; ability to
accurately record and maintain records; ability to establish and maintain
effective working relationships with employees, other departments, officials
and the public; ability to communicate effectively verbally and in writing;
ability to plan, organize and supervise clerical workers and assigned staff.
(2000 Code)
1-7A-4: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
   A.   Essential:
      1.   Manages and supervises assigned operations to achieve goals within
available resources; plans and organizes workloads and staff assignments;
trains, motivates and evaluates assigned staff; reviews progress and directs
changes as needed.
      2.   Provides direction and assists in the development of short- and
long-range plans; gathers, interprets, and prepares data for studies, reports
and recommendations; coordinates department activities with other boards,
departments and agencies as needed.
      3.   Communicates official plans, policies and procedures to staff and
the general public.
      4.   Assures that assigned areas of responsibility are performed within
budget; performs cost control activities; monitors revenues and expenditures to
assure sound fiscal control; prepares annual budget requests; assures effective
and efficient use of budgeted funds, personnel, materials, facilities, and
time.
      5.   Issues written and oral instructions; assigns duties and examines
work for exactness, neatness, and conformance to policies and procedures.
      6.   Assists subordinates in performing duties; adjusts errors and
complaints.
      7.   Serves as custodian of official town records and public documents;
performs certification and recording for the town as required on legal
documents and other records requiring such certification; seals and attests by
signature to ordinances, resolutions, and contracts, easements, deeds, bonds or
other documents requiring town certification; catalogs and files all town
records.
      8.   Attends regular and special town council meetings and records
accurate action of the proceedings.
      9.   Provides and assembles background material and related information
for decision-making purposes (i.e., agendas, reports); conducts research,
analysis, and prepares recommendations regarding proposal for programs, grants,
services, budget, surveys, equipment, etc., and distributes as requested.
      10.   Files ordinances and resolutions of the council and oversees the
codification of ordinances into this code.
      11.   Prepares and advertises bids and legal notices of public hearings
and special meetings.
      12.   Administers the issuance of municipal licenses, i.e., business and
dog, in accordance with applicable town ordinances and other regulations.
      13.   Provides public records and information to citizens, civic groups,
the media and other agencies as requested.
      14.   Attends seminars and workshops related to town clerk/treasurer's
duties and responsibilities.
      15.   Types council members' and mayor's correspondence.
      16.   Assists in the preparation of ordinances and resolutions as
directed.
      17.   Composes, types, and edits a variety of correspondence, reports,
memoranda, and other material requiring judgment as to content, accuracy, and
completeness.
      18.   Assists in the development of notices, flyers, and brochures,
newsletters, and other informational materials about programs and services.
      19.   Accepts claims for damages and other legal papers served on the
town.
      20.   Responds to inquiries from employees, customers and the general
public and refers, when necessary, to appropriate persons.
      21.   Reviews billings for correctness and accuracy and refigures bills
which have been issued to customers improperly.
      22.   Pursues collection of delinquent utility accounts, including
preparation and mailing of final notices, shut-off and turn-on orders,
establishing and monitoring payment schedules.
      23.   Processes work orders for utility disconnections, reconnections,
new orders, and other public works service requests.
      24.   Prepares and mails utility bills; maintains current customer
account files; reconciles utility billing activity with the general ledger.
      25.   Processes claims and vouchers for payment, and verification of
account codes.
      26.   Maintains a cash balance and balances cash on hand against
receipts; prepares and balances deposits.
      27.   Manages investment of the town funds in accordance with investment
policies and goals, and local, state and federal regulations. Maintains
required investment records and preparing related reports as required.
      28.   Establishes and maintains records needed for bond payments, fiscal
agent, and related redemption ledgers.
      29.   Serves as cashier including receipting of utility payments and
various other payments.
      30.   Communicates official plans, policies and procedures to staff and
the general public.
      31.   Makes records available to the general public and assists in their
understanding of the documents.
      32.   Adheres to standards of confidentiality.
   B.   Special Requirements:
      1.   Must be bondable;
      2.   Have a valid state driver's license, or ability to obtain one. (2000
Code)
1-7A-5: TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT:
   A.   Tools And Equipment Used: Typewriter; personal computer, including word
processing, spreadsheet and data base software; ten (10) key calculator; phone;
copy machine; fax machine.
   B.   Physical Demands: The physical demands described here are
representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform
the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to
enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
While performing the duties of this job, the employee is frequently required to
sit and talk or hear, use hands to finger, handle, feel or operate objects,
tools, or controls and reach with hands and arms. The employee is occasionally
required to walk.
The employee must occasionally lift and/or move up to twenty five (25) pounds.
Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision and the
ability to adjust focus.
   C.   Work Environment: The work environment characteristics described here
are representative of those an employee encounters while performing the
essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to
enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
The noise level in the work environment is usually quiet. (2000 Code)
1-7A-6: SELECTION GUIDELINES:
Formal application, rating of education and experience; oral interview and
reference check; job related tests may be required.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific statements of duties
does not exclude them from the position if the work is similar, related or a
logical assignment to the position.
The job description does not constitute an employment agreement between the
employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as the needs of
the employer and requirements of the job change. (2000 Code)
ARTICLE B. TOWN SUPERINTENDENT
SECTION:
1-7B-1: Creation Of Office
1-7B-2: Supervision
1-7B-3: Qualifications
1-7B-4: Duties And Responsibilities
1-7B-5: Terms Of Employment
1-7B-6: Selection Guidelines
1-7B-1: CREATION OF OFFICE:
   A.   Created: There is hereby created the position of town superintendent.
(1977 Code § 2.14.010; amd. 2000 Code)
   B.   General Purpose: Performs a variety of supervisory, administrative
skilled, technical, and maintenance work in the planning construction,
operation, repair, maintenance, and replacement of the town water, wastewater,
street and park facilities and systems. (2000 Code)
1-7B-2: SUPERVISION:
   A.   Received: Works under the general supervision of the mayor.
   B.   Exercised: Exercises close supervision over assigned maintenance
workers and equipment operators. (2000 Code)
1-7B-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Desired Minimum Qualifications:
      1.   Education And Experience: The above knowledge, skills, and abilities
are typically acquired through a combination of education and experience
equivalent to:
         a.   High school diploma or GED.
         b.   Three (3) or more years' experience in operating heavy equipment.
         c.   Experience with heavy manual labor preferred.
         d.   Two (2) or more years in a supervisory position or any equivalent
combination of education and experience.
   B.   Necessary Knowledge, Skills And Abilities:
      1.   Considerable knowledge of equipment, facilities, materials, method
and procedures used in public works.
      2.   Skill in operation of the listed tools and equipment.
      3.   Ability to interpret specific chemical and biological analyses,
ability to guide, direct and motivate employees, ability to organize and
supervise the activities of various crews performing construction and
maintenance work; ability to communicate effectively, verbally and in writing;
ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with
employees, other departments and the public. (2000 Code)
1-7B-4: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
   A.   Essential:
      1.   Plans, schedules, supervises and implements construction,
maintenance, and construction activities designed to provide quality water,
sewer, street, and park service for the town. Oversees construction and
maintenance work to determine acceptability and conformance to standards.
      2.   Trains and supervises employees performing the duties of
maintenance, construction, and repair of water, sewer, street and park
facilities.
      3.   Supervises the control and use of, and assumes responsibility for,
all materials, supplies, and equipment used in the maintenance of public works
and parks to ensure that all equipment is in proper working order.
      4.   Inspects and supervises the repair of chlorine machine, booster
pumping stations, and other water system components at frequent intervals, to
ensure that all aspects of the systems are functioning properly.
      5.   Oversees the analyses of the water treatment, state testing
requirements and reporting for the safety of town water customers.
      6.   Oversees the analyses of wastewater, sludge, and effluent samples to
provide data for the efficient operation of the wastewater treatment plant.
      7.   Supervises, instructs and assists assigned crews in installation of
new infrastructure, and in repairs and replacement of present infrastructure.
      8.   Requisitions needed supplies for the departments and maintains
relating records.
      9.   Advises mayor, attorney, engineer, and other town officials in
matters relating to department activities. Provides information to the public
and individuals regarding facility problems and services.
      10.   Responds to complaints and service requests regarding public works
and parks; evaluates the situation, determines the problem and explains the
findings to the appropriate person and makes the repair if required by town
policy.
      11.   Contacts residents and business owners in the area where service
will be discontinued and of the duration of the outage.
      12.   Oversees the safety of assigned workers by instructing individuals
in proper safety procedures and monitoring work in progress.
      13.   Recommends work projects, estimates time schedules and manpower as
well as material requirements.
      14.   Determines the locations of gas, telephone, power, television,
water, and sewer lines from the appropriate sources prior to excavation.
      15.   Supervises the review of private project development plan for
compliance with codes, regulations, and standards, adequacy of application for
permits and compliance with approved plans.
      16.   Maintains regular contact with consulting engineers, construction
project engineers, town, county, state and federal agencies, professional and
technical groups and the general public.
      17.   Responds to public or other inquiries relative to department
policies and procedures. Evaluates issues and options regarding municipal
public works and parks and makes decisions.
      18.   Analyzes annual operating costs and makes recommendation for
department budgets.
      19.   Participates in short- and long-term planning of capital
improvement projects.
      20.   Adheres to standards of confidentially.
   B.   Special Requirements:
      1.   Must possess or acquire within a reasonable time a valid Montana
state driver's license with appropriate commercial driver's license
endorsement.
      2.   Must possess or acquire within a reasonable time water and
wastewater operator certificates from the state of Montana. (2000 Code)
1-7B-5: TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT:
   A.   Tools And Equipment Used: Knowledge of operation and use of motorized
vehicles and equipment, including dump truck, pickup truck, utility truck,
sewer jet, backhoe, tamper, compactors, saws, pumps, compressors, sanders,
generators, and common hand and power tools. Skill in use of detection devices.
   B.   Physical Demands: The physical demands described here are
representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform
the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to
enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
While performing the duties of this job, the employee is regularly required to
use hands to finger, handle, feel or operate objects, tools, or controls and
reach with hands and arms. The employee frequently is required to stand and
talk or hear. The employee is occasionally required to walk, sit, climb, or
balance, stoop, kneel, crouch or crawl, and smell.
   C.   Work Environment: While performing the duties of this job, the employee
works in outside weather conditions, near moving mechanical parts, exposed to
wet and/or humid conditions and vibration. The employee occasionally works in
high, precarious places exposed to fumes or airborne particles, toxic or
caustic chemicals, and with energized electrical equipment.
The noise level in the work environment can be loud in field settings and
moderately quiet in office settings. (2000 Code)
1-7B-6: SELECTION GUIDELINES:
Formal application, rating of education and experience; oral interview and
reference check; job related tests may be required.
The duties listed above are intended only as illustrations of the various types
of work that may be performed. The omission of specific statements of duties
does not exclude them from the position if the work is similar, related or a
logical assignment to the position.
The job description does not constitute an employment agreement between the
employer and employee and is subject to change by the employer as the needs of
the employer and requirements of the job change. (2000 Code)
ARTICLE C. TOWN CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER
SECTION:
1-7C-1: Office Created
1-7C-2: Supervision
1-7C-3: Qualifications
1-7C-1: OFFICE CREATED:
   A.   There is hereby created the position of town code enforcement officer
(code officer). The code officer shall perform a variety of routine law
enforcement and public contact work in enforcing codes and ordinances
governing:
      1.   Parking and assisting the public by providing information about
parking locations and regulations;
      2.   Animal control, licensing, animals at large, kennel license,
nuisance complaints, vicious dogs;
      3.   Garbage and refuse violations;
      4.   Zoning issues, street obstructions and encroachments, signs, weeds,
zoning permits; and
      5.   Other duties as from time to time delegated by the chief of police
and/or the town council.
   B.   The code officer shall not inspect buildings or enforce title 12 of
this code unless specifically trained and authorized to do so. (Ord. 07-005, 7-
10-2007)
1-7C-2: SUPERVISION:
The code officer works under the general supervision of the mayor and under the
close supervision of the chief of police. (Ord. 07-005, 7-10-2007)
1-7C-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   Minimum Qualifications:
      1.   Requirements: The knowledge and skills necessary are typically
acquired through a combination of education and experience equivalent. The code
officer must be eighteen (18) years or older at the time of employment; must
possess, or be able to obtain by time of hire, a valid state driver's license
without record of suspension or revocation in any state; no felony convictions
or disqualifying criminal histories within the past seven (7) years and must be
able to read and write the English language.
      2.   Education And Experience:
         a.   High school diploma or GED equivalent, and
         b.   One year of general office, communications, or public contact
work; or
         c.   An equivalent combination of education and experience.
      3.   Necessary Knowledge, Skills And Abilities:
         a.   Some knowledge of modern parking enforcement principles, animal
control procedures and civil law enforcement procedures, techniques, and
equipment.
         b.   Some skill in the operation of most of the tools and equipment
listed below.
         c.   Ability to learn the applicable laws, ordinances, and department
rules and regulations; ability to analyze situations accurately and adopt an
effective course of action; ability to interpret, apply and explain codes,
rules, regulations, policies and procedures using tact, patience and courtesy;
ability to maintain accurate records; ability to communicate effectively;
ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with peers,
supervisors and the public; ability to follow verbal and written instructions;
ability to learn the town's geography.
         d.   Knowledge and skill in operation of computer data entry and word
processing and ability to write reports of activities and observations.
         e.   Ability to communicate in a firm confident manner without being
abrasive towards the suspected violator. (Ord. 07-005, 7-10-2007)
CHAPTER 8
ELECTIONS
SECTION:
1-8-1: Wards
1-8-2: Compliance With This Title And Town Charter
1-8-1: WARDS:
The territory embraced within the corporate limits of the town shall be, and
the same is hereby divided into two (2) wards as follows: All that portion of
the town lying north and east of the right of way of the Northern Pacific
Railroad, as the same is now located, shall comprise the first ward and all
that portion of the town lying south and west of the said right of way shall
constitute the second ward. (1977 Code § 1.08.040)
1-8-2: COMPLIANCE WITH THIS TITLE AND TOWN CHARTER:
The election for officers of the town, including council members and mayor,
shall be at large and in accordance with the town charter, effective January 1,
2006, and with this title. (Ord. 08-003, 4-8-2008)
CHAPTER 9
TOWN FINANCES
SECTION:
1-9-1: Fiscal Year
1-9-2: Borrowing Money
1-9-3: Yearly Financial Statement
1-9-4: Inactive Accounts
1-9-5: Transfer Of Funds
1-9-6: Capital Improvement Program Fund
1-9-7: Contracts
1-9-7-1: Awarding Certain Contracts; Vote By Electors
1-9-7-2: Advertisements
1-9-7-3: Emergencies
1-9-7-4: Bids
1-9-7-5: Preparation Of Contract
1-9-7-6: Public Works Contractor's Bond
1-9-1: FISCAL YEAR:
The fiscal year of the Town commences on July 1 of each year and ends on June
30 of the following year. (1977 Code § 3.04.010; amd. 2000 Code)
1-9-2: BORROWING MONEY:
The Town Council has power to contract an indebtedness on behalf of the Town,
upon the credit thereof, by borrowing money or issuing bonds for the purposes
and to the extent specified by the constitution and laws of the State 1 . (1977
Code § 3.04.020)
 
Notes
1 1. For limitations on borrowing by municipality, see constitution, article
  13, §6.
1-9-3: YEARLY FINANCIAL STATEMENT:
   A.   Contents: Within six (6) months after the close of each fiscal year,
the Town Clerk/Treasurer must make out, in duplicate, a full and complete
statement of the financial condition of the Town for such fiscal year, showing:
      1.   Indebtedness: The indebtedness of the Town, funded and floating; the
amount of each class of indebtedness; and the amount of money in the Treasury
subject to the payment of each class of indebtedness.
      2.   Taxes: The amount of money received from taxes upon real and
personal property.
      3.   Fines, Penalties And Forfeitures: The amount of money received from
fines, penalties and forfeitures.
      4.   Licenses: The amount of money received from licenses.
      5.   All Other Sources: The amount of money received from all other
sources, each source and the amount received therefrom being shown separately.
      6.   Funds: For each fund the amount of money, if any, on hand at the
beginning of such fiscal year, the amount received by and the amount paid out
during such fiscal year. The total amount of money paid out must be deducted
from the sum of money on hand at the beginning of the fiscal year and money
received during such year by the Town Clerk/Treasurer, and a balance must be
struck for each fund.
      7.   Property: A concise description of all property owned by the Town
with an approximate estimate of the value thereof.
      8.   Rates Of Taxation: The rates of taxation and purposes for which
levied during such fiscal year.
      9.   Other Information: Such other information as may be, from time to
time, required by the Department of Commerce.
   B.   Form Of Statement: The forms on which such statement shall be made
shall be prescribed by the Department of Commerce.
   C.   Transmittal To Department of Commerce: The Town Clerk/Treasurer must,
not later than six (6) months following the close of each fiscal year, transmit
one copy of such statement to the Department of Commerce, and must present the
other copy thereof to the Town Council at the first regular meeting thereof in
the month of September.
   D.   Failure To Make And File Statement: If the Clerk/Treasurer shall fail
to make and file a copy of such statement with the Department of Commerce
within the time above specified, it shall be the duty of the Department of
Commerce, without delay, to examine the books, records and accounts of the Town
and to make therefrom such statement of the financial condition of the Town for
the immediately preceding fiscal year in the same manner and form as the same
should have been made by the Clerk/Treasurer. (1977 Code § 3.04.030; amd. 2000
Code)
1-9-4: INACTIVE ACCOUNTS:
Whenever the Town Council shall deem it necessary to remove inactive accounts
from its records where said accounts shall not have any further purpose, it
shall be lawful for the Council to direct the proper Town officials to file
claims against the respective inactive funds in favor of the General Fund of
the Town, after which the Council shall allow the same and cause the inactive
funds to be closed and not continued in the record of active funds. (1977 Code
§ 3.04.080)
1-9-5: TRANSFER OF FUNDS:
Money may not be transferred from one fund to another except by resolution of
the Town Council unless previously authorized by budget resolution or as
prescribed by Montana Code Annotated section 7-6-4124. (1977 Code § 3.04.050;
amd. 2000 Code)
1-9-6: CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM FUND:
An amount not to exceed ten percent (10%) of the money received from an all-
purpose levy provided for in Montana Code Annotated section 7-6-4452, may be
placed in a separate fund, known as the Capital Improvement Program Fund, to be
earmarked for the replacement, improvement, and acquisition of property,
facilities, or equipment; provided, that a capital improvement program has been
formally adopted by resolution of the Town Council. (1977 Code § 3.04.060; amd.
2000 Code)
1-9-7: CONTRACTS 1 :
 
Notes
1 1. Power of Town to make any and all contracts necessary to carry into effect
  the powers granted by the legislature, see MCA § 7-5-4301.
1-9-7-1: AWARDING CERTAIN CONTRACTS; VOTE BY ELECTORS:
   A.   Awarding Certain Contracts: All contracts of the Town for the purchase
of any automobile, truck, or other vehicle or road machinery, or for any other
machinery, apparatus, appliances, or equipment, or for any materials or
supplies of any kind in excess of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), or for
construction, repair, or maintenance in excess of twenty five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) must be let to the lowest responsible bidder after advertisement
for bids.
   B.   Certain Contracts Submitted To Voters: The Council shall not let any
contract let pursuant to subsection A of this Section extending over a period
of five (5) years or more, except contracts for solid waste management systems
as defined in Montana Code Annotated section 75-10-103, which may not exceed
ten (10) years, without first submitting the question to a vote of the
taxpaying electors of the Town. (1977 Code § 3.08.010; amd. 2000 Code)
1-9-7-2: ADVERTISEMENTS:
Advertisements required by subsection 1-9-7-1A of this Chapter shall be made in
the official newspaper of the Town, if there be such official newspaper and, if
not, it shall be made in a daily newspaper of general circulation published in
the Town, if there be such, otherwise by posting in three (3) of the most
public places in the Town. Such advertisement, if by publication in a
newspaper, shall be made once each week for two (2) consecutive weeks and the
second publication shall be made not less than five (5) days nor more than
twelve (12) days before the consideration of bids. If such advertisement is
made by posting, fifteen (15) days must elapse, including the day of posting,
between the time of the posting of such advertisement and the day set for
considering bids. (1977 Code § 3.08.020)
1-9-7-3: EMERGENCIES:
The provisions of Section
1-9-7-2 of this Chapter as to advertisement for bids shall not apply upon the
happening of any emergency caused by fire, flood, explosion, storm, earthquake,
riot or insurrection, or any other similar emergency, but, in such case, the
Council may proceed in any manner which, in the judgment of three-fourths (3/4)
of the members of the Council present at the meeting, duly recorded in the
minutes of the proceedings of the Council by aye and nay vote, will best meet
the emergency and serve the public interest. Such emergency shall be declared
and recorded at length in the minutes of the proceedings of the Council at the
time the vote thereon is taken and recorded. (1977 Code § 3.08.030)
1-9-7-4: BIDS:
   A.   Opening Of Bids: The bids shall be opened by the Clerk/Treasurer in the
presence of the Council while the Council is in actual session at a regular,
adjourned, or special meeting. After the bids shall have been opened, the
contract shall be let or awarded by the Council. The award shall be made to the
lowest responsible bidder.
   B.   Council Action: The Council may postpone action as to any such contract
until the next regular meeting after bids are received, or may reject any and
all bids and as. (1977 Code § 3.08.040)
1-9-7-5: PREPARATION OF CONTRACT:
Upon receiving the statement of the awarding of a contract, it shall be the
duty of the Town Attorney to prepare a contract and bond in accordance with the
statement. All contracts shall be executed on the part of the Town by the Mayor
and attested by the Clerk/Treasurer, and together with the bond therefor shall
be filed with the Town Clerk/Treasurer. (1977 Code § 3.08.050)
1-9-7-6: PUBLIC WORKS CONTRACTOR'S BOND:
Whenever the Council shall contract with any person to do any work for the
Town, the Council shall require the person with whom such contract is made, to
make, execute and deliver to the Council, a good and sufficient bond with two
(2) or more sureties, or with a surety company as surety, conditioned that such
person shall faithfully perform all of the provisions of such contract, and pay
all laborers, mechanics, subcontractors and materialmen, and all persons who
shall supply such person or subcontractors with provisions, material, or
supplies for the carrying on of such work. A copy of such bond shall be filed
with the Town Clerk/Treasurer. (1977 Code § 3.08.060)
CHAPTER 10
CITY COURT
SECTION:
1-10-1: Established
1-10-2: Concurrent Jurisdiction
1-10-3: Exclusive Jurisdiction
1-10-4: Preliminary Examinations
1-10-5: Criminal Actions
1-10-6: Civil Actions
1-10-7: City Judge
1-10-8: Substitute Judge Called In
1-10-9: Collection Of Fines
1-10-1: ESTABLISHED:
A City Court is established in each Town. A City Judge shall establish regular
sessions of the Court. On judicial days, the court must be open for all
business, civil and criminal. On nonjudicial days, as defined in Montana Code
Statutes section 3-1-302, the Court may transact criminal business only. (1977
Code § 2.16.010; amd. 2000 Code)
1-10-2: CONCURRENT JURISDICTION:
The City Court has concurrent jurisdiction with the justice's court of all
misdemeanors and proceedings. (2000 Code)
1-10-3: EXCLUSIVE JURISDICTION:
The City Court has exclusive jurisdiction:
   A.   Of all proceedings for the violation of any ordinance of the Town, both
civil and criminal, which must be prosecuted in the name of the Town;
   B.   Of any action for the collection of taxes and assessments levied for
Municipal purposes; or for the erection or improvement of public buildings; for
the laying out, or opening, or improving any public street or sidewalk, alley,
or bridge; or for the purpose of or the improvement of any public grounds; or
for any and all public improvements made or ordered by the Town within its
limits, when the amount of the tax or assessments sought to be collected
against the person assessed does not exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00);
but no lien upon the property taxed or assessed for the nonpayment of the taxes
or assessment can be foreclosed in any such action;
   C.   Of an action for the collection of money due to the Town or from the
Town to any person, when the amount sought to be collected, exclusive of
interest and costs, does not exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00);
   D.   For the breach of any official bond given by any Town officer, and for
the breach of any contract, and any action for damages in which the Town is a
party, or is in any way interested; and all forfeited recognizances given to or
for the benefit or in behalf of the Town; and upon all bonds given upon any
appeal taken from the judgment of the Court in any action above-named, where
the amount claimed, exclusive of costs, does not exceed five thousand dollars
($5,000.00);
   E.   For the recovery of personal property belonging to the Town, when the
value of the property (exclusive of the damages for the taking or detention)
does not exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00); and
   F.   Of an action for the collection of any license required by any
ordinance of the Town. (1977 Code § 2.16.030; amd. 2000 Code)
1-10-4: PRELIMINARY EXAMINATIONS:
Proceedings in preliminary examinations in criminal actions in the City Court
must be had in conformity with the provisions of Montana Code Annotated section
46-10-105 and section 46-10-202. (1977 Code § 2.16.040; amd. 2000 Code)
1-10-5: CRIMINAL ACTIONS:
Proceedings in City Courts in criminal actions triable in such courts are
regulated by Montana Code Annotated title 46. (1977 Code § 2.16.050; amd. 2000
Code)
1-10-6: CIVIL ACTIONS:
The proceedings of the City Court in civil actions are regulated by Montana
Code Annotated title 25. (1977 Code § 2.16.060; amd. 2000 Code)
1-10-7: CITY JUDGE:
The presiding officer of the City Court shall be the City Judge. If none is
elected or appointed by the Town, the justice of the peace of the township in
which the Town is situated shall be the City Judge. (1977 Code § 2.16.070)
1-10-8: SUBSTITUTE JUDGE CALLED IN:
   A.   In all cases in which the Judge is a party, or in which he is
interested, or when he is related to either party by consanguinity or affinity
within the sixth degree, and in case of his sickness, absence, or inability to
act, the City Judge or Mayor may call in a justice of the peace residing in the
Town to act in his place and stead. (1977 Code § 2.16.080)
   B.   The City Judge may call in a city judge, justice of the peace, or some
qualified person to act in his stead when a disqualifying affidavit is filed
against him pursuant to the Supreme Court's rules on disqualification and
substitution of judges.
   C.   A city judge of any city or a justice of the peace of any county may
sit as city judge at the City Judge's request. (2000 Code)
1-10-9: COLLECTION OF FINES:
The City Judge shall collect all fines, costs and forfeitures that accrue to
the Town from cases tried or disposed of in the City Court. He shall give a
receipt therefor to the person paying the same, and pay the collected monies to
the Town Clerk/Treasurer. (1977 Code § 2.16.090)
CHAPTER 11
ANNEXATION
SECTION:
1-11-1: Hemlock Addition

1-11-3: School District No. Three

1-11-16: Eagle Point Estates
1-11-1: HEMLOCK ADDITION:
   A.   Description Of Property: The following described tract of land
adjoining the limits of the town, all of which land is located in the county of
Gallatin, state of Montana, is hereby added to, taken into and made a part of
the town of Manhattan:
The following described tract of land situated within the city limits of
Manhattan, lying in the Northwest one-quarter (NW 1/4) of Section Eleven (11),
Township One (1) North, Range Three (3) East, Montana Principal Meridian,
Gallatin County, Montana, and being more particularly described by the
following metes and bounds, to wit:
Beginning at the West one-quarter (W1/4) corner of said Section Eleven (11),
Township One (1) North, Range Three (3) East, thence North 00 degrees 23'25"
East along the West line of said Section, a distance of 1166.08 feet, to the
true point of beginning of the herein described tract.
Thence North 00 degrees 23'25" East, along the West line of said Section Eleven
(11), a distance of 278.95 feet to the Southerly line of Seventh Street.
Thence North 37 degrees 49'02" East along the Southerly line of Seventh Street,
a distance of 95.57 feet to the South line of Washington Avenue.
Thence South 88 degrees 05'00" East, along the South line of Washington Avenue,
a distance of 126.70 feet, to the centerline of Hemlock Street.
Thence South 00 degrees 23'25" West, along the centerline of Hemlock Street, a
distance of 356.40 feet.
Thence North 88 degrees 05'00" West, a distance of 184.80 feet to the true
point of beginning. Said tract contains 1.46 acres, along with and subject to
any and all existing easements. The above- described tract is known and
designated as "Hemlock Addition" to the Town of Manhattan. The West One-half of
Hemlock Street is to be granted, donated and dedicated to the use of the public
forever.
      (1977 Code § 2.34.010)
   B.   Name: Said lands shall hereafter be known as Hemlock Addition to the
town of Manhattan, Montana. (1977 Code § 2.34.020)
   C.   Extending Of Boundaries: Upon the taking effect of this section, the
corporate limits and boundary lines of the town shall be expanded to include
the above described real property, in addition to the previously recorded
corporate limits on file and of record in the office of the clerk and recorder
of Gallatin County, Montana. (1977 Code § 2.34.030)

a distance of 22.91 feet to the north sixteenth corner of the Northwest Quarter

feet to a point on the southerly right-of-way of said Madison Avenue; Thence

Avenue, a distance of 1097.12 feet; Thence along the curve to the left, having
a central angle of 26 degrees 22'20" and a radius of 417.52 feet, an arc
distance of 192.17 feet; Thence North 25 degrees 25'31" West, a distance of

09'09" East, along the North- South section line, a distance of 108.94 feet to
true point of beginning, and containing 3.038 acres.
   (1977 Code § 2.34.040)
   B.   Purpose And Date Of Annexation: It is hereby declared that the
annexation describe in subsection A of this Section was performed for the best
interests of the Town and its inhabitants. Said annexation occurred after a
public hearing held on August 6, 1985 at 7:00 p.m. in the Town Council Chambers
and after all due publication and notice requirements were completed. (1977
Code § 2.34.050)
