7-1-3-4: PROHIBITED; REMOVAL:
   A.   Prohibited: No person shall maintain any building, fence, porch, steps,
gallery, or other structure upon any street or alley within the town and no
person shall encumber or obstruct or cause to be encumbered or obstructed, any
street, alley or other public place in the town by placing therein or thereon
any building materials, trash, vehicles, machinery, earth, garbage, rubbish,
debris, or accumulated snow and ice removed from an adjoining private premises.
No person shall place or maintain any shafts of wood, iron or other material,
inventory, furniture, fixtures, equipment, billboards, signs, fences, poles,
rods, cables, or wire in any of the streets, public places or alleys of the
town. (Ord. 07-012, 7-10-2007)
   B.   Permit To Allow For Limited Time: (Rep. by Ord. 07-012, 7-10-2007)
   C.   Order To Remove:
      1.   Removal: Any building, fence, porch, steps, gallery, or other
structural obstruction now upon or hereafter placed or erected upon any street
or alley within the town, or which may be upon any new street or alley which
may hereafter be opened or created within the town, shall be removed therefrom
within a reasonable time, not exceeding thirty (30) days and not less than
three (3) days after an order to remove, in writing, has been given to the
owner or person responsible for such obstruction. (1977 Code § 12.12.050)
      2.   Unable To Find Owner Or Person Responsible: If the owner or person
responsible for such obstruction cannot be readily found for the purpose of
such notice, it shall be the duty of the town superintendent or chief of police
to cause the obstruction to be removed, in his discretion. The expense of such
removal shall be recoverable from the owner or person responsible for the
obstruction. (1977 Code § 12.12.050; amd. Ord. 07-012, 7-10-2007)
      3.   Interference: Any person who interferes with, resists or obstructs
by acts or threats, the removal of any such obstruction shall be deemed guilty
of a violation of this section. (1977 Code § 12.12.050)
   D.   Notice To Remove Obstructions: Notice to remove obstructions described
in this chapter and subsection C of this section, specifying same, and the
place and extent of same, shall be given to the occupant or owner of the land
involved, or to the person owning or causing such obstruction. Notice shall be
given by leaving it at the place of residence of the person to be served, if he
resides in the town, or by posting it on the obstruction, if such person does
not reside in the town. (1977 Code § 12.12.060)
   E.   Action To Remove Obstruction: If the obstruction required to be removed
by the notice of subsection D of this section is denied, and the owner,
occupant, or person controlling the matter or thing charged with being an
obstruction, refuses either to remove or permit the removal thereof, the town
shall commence in the proper court an action to abate the same as a nuisance;
and if the town recovers judgment, it may, in addition to having the same
abated, recover five hundred dollars ($500.00) for every day such nuisance
remained after such notice, and also costs in said action. (1977 Code §
12.12.070; amd. 2000 Code)
   F.   Removal Without Action: The town council may, at any time, order the
town superintendent to forthwith remove any such obstruction without commencing
an action. (1977 Code § 12.12.070; amd. 2000 Code; Ord. 07-012, 7-10-2007)
7-1-3-5: PUTTING GLASS, OTHER MATERIALS ON STREET PROHIBITED:
   A.   Prohibited: No person shall throw or deposit upon any street, any glass
bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans, or any other substance likely to
injure any person, animal, or vehicle upon such street.
   B.   Removal Required: Any person who drops, or permits to be dropped or
thrown, upon any street, any destructive or injurious material shall
immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed.
   C.   Wrecked Or Damaged Vehicle, Removal Of Glass: Any person removing a
wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street shall remove any glass or other
injurious substance dropped upon the street from such vehicle. (1977 Code §
12.12.080)
7-1-3-6: EXCEPTIONS:
The placing or maintaining of encroachments by the permission of the council,
for which an encroachment tax is paid, or the erecting or maintaining of poles
by telephone, telegraph or electric light companies for which permits have been
granted by the town are excepted from the provisions of this section
7-1-3. There is also excepted from the provisions of this section
7-1-3 the maintenance of light poles and bus benches placed by the authority of
the town. (1977 Code § 12.12.090)
7-1-3-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating a provision of this section
7-1-3 shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 07-002, 2-13-2007)
7-1-4: SNOW AND ICE, REMOVAL FROM SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Duty Of Property Owner Or Occupant: It shall be the duty of every
person owning or occupying any business or commercial property in the town, to
keep said sidewalk in front of his or their property free and clear from snow
and ice. (Ord. 07-012, 7-10-2007)
   B.   Removal Before And During Business Hours: Whenever there shall have
been a fall of snow during the ordinary business hours of the day, from eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. until five o'clock (5:00) P.M. of any day, such owner or
occupant of any property, shall at once and without unreasonable delay remove
said snow from said sidewalk along the entire frontage of the said property
owned or occupied by him. Whenever there shall have been a fall of snow during
the night, or at any time between the hours of five o'clock (5:00) P.M. and
seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. of any day, it shall be the duty of such owner or
occupant of any of the property to remove said snow from said sidewalk along
the entire frontage of the property owned or occupied by him, not later than
the hour of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. of said day. (1977 Code § 12.14.020; amd.
Ord. 07-012, 7-10-2007)
   C.   Penalty: Any person violating this section shall, upon conviction
thereof, be punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 07-002, 2-13-2007)
7-1-5: PROTECTION OF STREET AND TRAFFIC DURING CONSTRUCTION:
7-1-5-1: BARRICADES AND WARNING LIGHTS:
   A.   Required: Whenever excavation work in any street in the town is in
progress, efficient barricades shall be erected by the contractor, or other
person in control, around all trenches or embankments made by him within the
limits of any street or sidewalk.
   B.   Failure To Protect: Failure or omission to protect against accident, in
the manner required by this section, shall cause a forfeiture of any permit
which may have been granted with reference thereto. (1977 Code § 12.16.010;
amd. 2000 Code)
   C.   Traveling Upon Streets With Barricades: No person shall walk upon or
drive upon a street, alley or sidewalk barricaded as stated in this section.
(1977 Code § 12.16.020)
   D.   Removal Prohibited: Whenever any barricade or other warning device
shall have been placed upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the town by any
official or employee of the town in the course of his duty, or by any
contractor working on any street, alley or sidewalk, no person shall move or
remove such barricade or other warning device. (1977 Code § 12.16.030; amd.
2000 Code)
   E.   Removal After Completion: Following completion of the construction work
and restoration of the street or sidewalk to a safe and passable condition, the
contractor or person in charge of the work shall promptly remove all
barricades, warning lights and other safety devices from the street or
sidewalk. (1977 Code § 12.16.010)
7-1-5-2: MARKING WET CONCRETE:
Where lights, signs, barricades or obstructions have been placed and maintained
to protect concrete, no person shall walk, run, drive, ride or step upon the
newly laid concrete, so as to mark, mar, or in any way, injure the same. (1977
Code § 12.16.040)
7-1-5-3: CHIPPING CONCRETE:
No person other than the town superintendent, a member of his force or a
concrete inspector, shall intentionally or wilfully chip, break, cut, or in any
manner, deface or injure any concrete in any sidewalk, curb, gutter or
pavement. (1977 Code § 12.16.050; amd. 2000 Code)
7-1-5-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating a provision of this section
7-1-5 shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 07-002, 2-13-2007)
CHAPTER 2
EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
7-2-1: Definitions
7-2-2: Permit Required
7-2-3: Bond
7-2-4: Minimum Travel Interference
7-2-5: Time Limitations For Open Excavation
7-2-6: Backfilling
7-2-7: Revocation Of Permit
7-2-8: Penalty
7-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
EXCAVATION: Any ditch, trench, cut, hole or change of grade.
STREET: The entire width of a highway between the boundary lines of other
public or private properties on the sides. (1977 Code § 12.04.010)
7-2-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall open up, dig into, excavate or tunnel in any of the
streets, avenues, public places or alleys of the town, whether to connect with
any of the mains or pipes, to connect with any sewer, or for any other purpose,
without having first:
      1.   Obtained a permit from the town council;
      2.   Made a cash payment with the town clerk/treasurer; and
      3.   Filed with the clerk/treasurer a good and sufficient surety bond.
   B.   The council shall make rules and regulations as to the amount and
conditions under which such payment shall be made. The council may, in its
discretion, waive the filing of bond. (1977 Code § 12.04.020)
7-2-3: BOND:
The bond required by section
7-2-2 of this chapter shall be in the sum of twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00) and shall be executed by a surety company authorized to do
business in the state, conditioned to save the town harmless from any damage or
injury whatsoever to any person or property of any description, however owned,
by reason of leaving open any excavation or tunnel or by reason of failure to
properly guard any such excavation or tunnel or failure to place red lights at
such excavation or tunnel at night. Any person may furnish a yearly bond
conditioned as hereinabove set forth. (1977 Code § 12.04.030)
7-2-4: MINIMUM TRAVEL INTERFERENCE:
Excavations in streets and alleys shall be made in such manner as to impede
travel as little as possible. At no time during the progress of the work shall
sidewalks be unnecessarily blocked to travel. (1977 Code § 12.04.040)
7-2-5: TIME LIMITATIONS FOR OPEN EXCAVATION:
The time that any street or alley excavation is open may be limited by the town
superintendent or another responsible official of the town. (1977 Code §
12.04.050; amd. 2000 Code)
7-2-6: BACKFILLING:
   A.   Required: After the completion of the laying of any pipe, line or
conduit, or the installation or repair of any facility for which the excavation
was undertaken, the excavator shall cause the work to be backfilled in such a
manner as to make the street in as good a condition as before the excavation.
   B.   Maintenance Of Excavation: Any person making any excavation in any
street or alley, as set forth in this chapter, shall be fully responsible for
the maintenance of the excavation for a period of six (6) months after the
backfill thereof. If any settlement occurs in the area that was formerly
excavated, the excavator or person causing the excavation shall immediately,
upon notice, fill in the settling and put the street, alley, or avenue, in as
good condition as possible for use by the public. (1977 Code § 12.04.060)
7-2-7: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
   A.   Power To Revoke: Any permit issued under authority of this chapter may
be revoked for failure of the permittee to perform the work in accordance with
the specifications, methods or time limits required or approved by the town.
   B.   Request For Hearing: Any permittee whose permit is revoked may, upon
request, receive a hearing before the town council or person designated by the
council. The council, after such hearing, may reinstate the permit or take any
other action it deems proper. (1977 Code § 12.04.070)
7-2-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating a provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 07-002, 2-13-2007)
CHAPTER 3
DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION
SECTION:
7-3-1: Permit Required
7-3-2: Application
7-3-3: Construction Standards
7-3-4: Revocation Of Permit
7-3-5: Penalty
7-3-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   No person shall break any curb or make any opening or excavation for
the purpose of constructing a driveway on any of the paved areas of any of the
streets, avenues or alleys of the town without first making application, filing
suitable bond, and obtaining a permit from the town council therefor.
   B.   The council shall make rules and regulations as to the amount and
conditions under which such payment shall be made. The council may, in its
discretion, waive the filing of bond. (1977 Code § 12.08.010)
7-3-2: APPLICATION:
All applications for permits for driveways must give a description of the
property to be served and such other information as may be required by the town
clerk/treasurer, and must be signed by the owner or his authorized agent. (1977
Code § 12.08.020)
7-3-3: CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS:
   A.   Standards And Specifications: Standards and required specifications for
the construction of driveways shall be declared by the town council, and a copy
of same shall be on file in the office of the town clerk/treasurer.
   B.   Plan: Plans for the proposed driveway shall be submitted by the
applicant to the town clerk/treasurer, or other responsible town official
designated by the council for that purpose. No permit for the construction of a
driveway shall be denied where it is shown by the applicant that the proposed
work conforms to the standards and specifications prescribed by the town.
   C.   Variance From Standards And Specifications: Whenever a proposed
driveway construction plan varies from the town standards and specifications,
the council may grant a permit to the applicant where, in its opinion, the
variance will not cause damage to the surrounding street and sidewalk area.
(1977 Code § 12.08.030)
7-3-4: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
   A.   Power To Revoke: Any permit issued under authority of this chapter may
be revoked for failure of the permittee to perform the work in accordance with
the specifications, methods, or time limit required or approved by the town.
   B.   Hearing: Any permittee whose permit is revoked may, upon request,
receive a hearing before the town council or person designated by the council.
The council, after such hearing, may reinstate the permit or take any other
action that it deems proper. (1977 Code § 12.08.040)
7-3-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating a provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 07-002, 2-13-2007)
CHAPTER 4
MOVING BUILDINGS
SECTION:
7-4-1: Permit Required
7-4-2: Application
7-4-3: Restrictions On Issuance
7-4-4: Duties Of Permittee
7-4-5: Revocation
7-4-6: Penalty
7-4-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall move, remove or relocate any building or structure within or
into the Town without first having obtained a moving permit from the Town.
(1977 Code § 12.20.010)
7-4-2: APPLICATION:
   A.   Form: Every application for a permit to move, remove or relocate any
building or structure in the Town shall be made to the Town Clerk/Treasurer, in
writing, upon forms furnished by the Town.
   B.   Required Information: Every application shall set forth the following
information:
      1.   Address of present location of the structure;
      2.   Address of new location;
      3.   Type of construction (frame, masonry, masonry veneer, etc.);
      4.   Length, width and height of building or structure;
      5.   Specific route over which the building or structure is to be moved;
      6.   Type of occupancy (dwelling, garage, office, etc.) for both old and
new location;
      7.   Proposed moving date and time of day.
   C.   Additional Information: The Town may require any additional information
which it shall find necessary to make a fair determination of whether a permit
should issue. (1977 Code § 12.20.020)
7-4-3: RESTRICTIONS ON ISSUANCE:
The following restrictions and conditions shall be observed before the issuance
of a permit as required by this Chapter:
   A.   Compliance With Zoning And Building Requirements: No permit shall be
issued to any person to move or relocate any building or structure upon another
building site unless such use, building or proposed conversion thereof conforms
to zoning and building requirements of the Town.
   B.   Prohibited Conditions: No permit shall be issued to any person to move,
remove or locate any building or structure which is so constructed or in such
condition as to be dangerous or unsafe, or which is infested with pests or is
unsanitary or which, if it be a dwelling or habitation, is unfit for human
habitation, or which is so dilapidated, defective, or in such a condition of
deterioration or disrepair that its relocation at the proposed site would
create a safety or health hazard or would cause substantial damage or material
detriment to the property in the immediate vicinity of the proposed site.
   C.   Consent Of Fire And Police Departments: Every such application shall be
accompanied by the written consent of the Chiefs of the Fire and Police
Departments, who shall be notified of the route to be taken and when the
removal or relocation shall be made.
   D.   Route: The Town Clerk/Treasurer shall specify in the permit the route
to be taken in the moving of a building, such means to be used to prevent the
street pavement from being subjected to abnormal stresses, and the limit of
time which such building or structure shall be upon the streets or alleys.
   E.   Town Fire Alarm Circuit Or Box: No circuit or box of the Town fire
alarm shall be disturbed in any manner except with the permission of the Chief
of the Fire Department.
   F.   Occupied Building: No building or structure which is being moved upon
or over any street, alley or property of the town shall be occupied as living
quarters while such building or structure is in transit.
   G.   Adequate Moving Equipment: No permit, as required by this chapter,
shall be issued unless the applicant shows that he has adequate machinery,
appliances and equipment to safely complete the proposed moving. (1977 Code §
12.20.030)
7-4-4: DUTIES OF PERMITTEE:
Every permittee under this chapter shall:
   A.   Use Designated Route: Move a building only over streets designated for
such use in the written permit;
   B.   Change In Date And Time: Notify the town clerk/treasurer, in writing,
of a desired change in moving date and hours as proposed in the application;
   C.   Damage To Town Property: Notify the town clerk/treasurer, in writing,
of any and all damage done to property belonging to the town within twenty four
(24) hours after the damage or injury has occurred;
   D.   Warning Lights: Cause warning lights to be displayed during the hours
of darkness on every side of the building, while standing on a street, in such
manner as to warn the public of the obstruction, and shall at all times erect
and maintain barricades across the streets in such manner as to protect the
public from damage or injury by reason of the moving or removal of the
building;
   E.   Remove Building From Streets: Remove the building from the town streets
after four (4) days of such occupancy, unless an extension is granted by the
town;
   F.   Original Building Site: Remove all rubbish and materials and fill all
excavations to existing grade at the original building site so that the
premises are left in a safe and sanitary condition;
   G.   Utilities: Properly disconnect all utilities, plug the sanitary sewer
with a concrete plug and have the water department disconnect the water
service. (1977 Code § 12.20.040)
7-4-5: REVOCATION:
The building official of the town or the chief of police is authorized and
empowered to revoke any permit granted under the terms of this chapter if it
shall become known to him that the permittee is, in any manner, failing to
comply with the terms of the permit or this chapter or, when in the opinion of
the official, public convenience and safety require such revocation. (1977 Code
§ 12.20.050)
7-4-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating a provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 07-002, 2-13-2007)
CHAPTER 5
PUBLIC TREES
SECTION:
7-5-1: Title; Purpose
7-5-2: Definitions
7-5-3: Tree Commission
7-5-4: Park Commissioner
7-5-5: Species, Cultivars, Or Varieties Of Trees
7-5-6: Protection Of Trees
7-5-7: Protection Of Public
7-5-8: Penalty
7-5-1: TITLE; PURPOSE:
   A.   Short Title: The ordinance adopted pursuant hereto shall be known as,
and be cited and referred to as the TOWN OF MANHATTAN TREE ORDINANCE.
   B.   Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to regulate public trees within
the town of Manhattan, to provide for their planting, protection, maintenance
and removal, establishing a tree commission and delegating to the park
commissioner the duty of assuring orderly development of public trees. (Ord.
275, 5-1-2001)
7-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their
derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with
the content, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the
plural include the singular and words in the singular include the plural. The
word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directory.
BOULEVARD: That part of the public right of way not covered by sidewalk or
other paving, lying between the property line and the curb line of any street.
In the absence of a curb, the curb line of a street shall be deemed to be the
edge of that portion of the public right of way maintained and open to the use
of the public for the purpose of vehicular travel.
PARK COMMISSIONER: The designated official for the town of Manhattan assigned
to carry out the enforcement of this chapter.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, or company of
any kind.
PROPERTY LINE: The outer edge of a street or highway right of way.
PROPERTY OWNERS: The person owning such property as recorded at the clerk and
recorder's office in Gallatin County, state of Montana.
PUBLIC PLACES: This shall include all other grounds owned by the town of
Manhattan.
PUBLIC TREES: All shade and ornamental trees growing on any street or any
public areas.
STREET: The entire width of every public way or right of way when a part
thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of
vehicular and pedestrian traffic.
TOPPING: The severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches
(3") in diameter within the crown of the tree to such a degree so as to remove
the normal tree canopy and disfigure the tree.
TOWN: The town of Manhattan, Gallatin County, state of Montana. (Ord. 275, 5-1-
2001)
7-5-3: TREE COMMISSION:
   A.   Creation; Membership: There shall be created a commission to be known
and designated as the "Tree Commission" which consists of the park board,
composed of seven (7) citizens of the town of Manhattan. Six (6) of said
members shall be appointed by the mayor with consent of the council. The
seventh member shall be the park commissioner and a member of the council,
appointed by the mayor.
   B.   Compensation: All members of the commission shall serve without pay.
   C.   Appointment And Term: The six (6) members appointed by the mayor shall
be appointed as follows: Three (3) for three (3) years, and three (3) for four
(4) years, and serve until their successors are duly appointed and approved by
the council.
Successors to those members appointed by the mayor shall thereafter be
appointed for terms of four (4) years. Vacancies caused by death, resignations,
or otherwise, shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as
original appointments are made.
   D.   Duties: To study the problems and determine the needs of the town of
Manhattan in connection with its tree planting and maintenance program. To
assist the properly constituted officials of the town of Manhattan as well as
the council and citizens of the town in the dissemination of news and
information regarding the selection, planting and maintenance of public
property, and to make such recommendations from time to time to the town
council, as to desirable legislation concerning the tree program and activities
for the town. To provide regular and special meetings at which the subject of
trees insofar as it relates to the town may be discussed by the members of the
commission, officers and personnel of the town and its several divisions, and
all others interested in the tree program.
   E.   Meetings And Organization: Within a reasonable time after the
appointment of said commission and the approval of the members thereof, upon
call of the mayor, said commission shall meet and organize by the election of a
chairman. The said commission shall then provide for the adoption of rules and
procedures and for the holding of regular and special meetings as said
commission shall deem advisable and necessary in order to perform the duties
set forth. (Ord. 275, 5-1-2001)
7-5-4: PARK COMMISSIONER:
   A.   Work On Public Trees: All work on public trees will comply with the
"Tree Ordinance for the Town of Manhattan".
   B.   Authority: The park commissioner or his/her designated representative
shall have the authority and jurisdiction of regulating the planting,
maintenance and removal of public trees on streets and other publicly owned
property to ensure safety or preserve the aesthetics of such public sites.
   C.   Duty: The park commissioner or his/her designated representative shall
have the authority, and it will be his/her duty, to supervise or inspect all
work performed under the terms of this chapter.
   D.   Park Commissioner's Authority In Granting Permits: The park
commissioner or his/her designated representative shall have the authority to
affix reasonable conditions to the granting of a permit in accordance with the
terms of this chapter.
   E.   Permits Required For Work On Public Trees: No person shall plant,
spray, perform major pruning, remove or otherwise disturb any public tree
without a tree work permit (see appendix attached to ordinance 275 on file in
the office of the town clerk) issued by the town. The person receiving the
permit shall abide by the arboricultural specifications and standards of
practice as outlined in the appendix attached to ordinance 275 on file in the
office of the town clerk, and provide evidence of public liability insurance in
an amount to be appropriated by the park commissioner (tree commission).
   F.   Removal Of Public Trees, Replacement, And Allocation Costs:
      1.   No person or property owner may remove a public tree from the
boulevard for the purpose of construction, or for any other reason without
first obtaining a permit from the town council of the town of Manhattan.
      2.   Public trees removed under subsection F1 of this section must be
replaced as deemed appropriate by the park commissioner. The person or property
owner shall bear the cost of maintenance, removal and replacement of all public
trees removed.
   G.   Appeal To Mayor: Any person may make a written appeal from any ruling
or order by the park commissioner to the mayor, who shall make a final
decision. (Ord. 275, 5-1-2001)
7-5-5: SPECIES, CULTIVARS, OR VARIETIES OF TREES:
   A.   Permitted:
      1.   The tree commission (park board) shall prepare a list of trees
acceptable for planting in the public sites of the town of Manhattan. See
appendix for approved tree species for the town of Manhattan attached to
ordinance 275 on file in the office of the town clerk. Undesirable trees shall
not be recommended for general planting and their use, if any, shall be
restricted to special locations where, because of certain characteristics of
adaptability or landscape effect, they can be used to an advantage.
      2.   Only desirable long lived trees of good appearance, beauty,
adaptability, and generally free from injurious insects or disease shall be
planted in public sites. The tree commission, in conjunction with the park
commissioner, shall review at least once every two (2) years the species,
cultivars or varieties for any reason and to determine if certain new species,
cultivars, or varieties of proven dependability and value should be added.
   B.   Planting:
      1.   Location, Placement And Spacing:
         a.   Guidelines for the location, placement and spacing of street and
public trees will be based on the tree's size, class (small, medium, large) and
the obstacle (curbs, intersections, etc.). The required planting distances are
listed in the appendix as guidelines for location, placement and spacing of
landscape trees attached to ordinance 275 on file in the office of the town
clerk.
         b.   All planting on unpaved or paved streets without curbs must have
the special permission of the park commissioner who shall determine the tree's
location so it will not be injured or destroyed when the street is curbed and
paved, or sidewalks added. Planting distance shall be three (3) to five feet
(5') from the outside edge of the street. (Ord. 275, 5-1-2001)
7-5-6: PROTECTION OF TREES:
   A.   Damage To Public Trees: Unless specifically authorized by the park
commissioner, it is unlawful for any person to intentionally damage, cut,
carve, transplant, or remove any public tree; attach any rope, wire, nails, or
other contrivance to any public tree; allow any gaseous liquid or solid
substance which is harmful to such tree to come in contact with them; or set
fire or permit any fire to burn when such fire or the heat thereof could injure
any portion of any public tree.
   B.   Protection Of Trees:
      1.   All trees on a street or other publicly owned property near any
excavation or construction of any building, structure or street work, shall be
guarded with a good substantial fence, frame or box. All building material,
dirt, or other debris shall be kept outside the barrier.
      2.   It is unlawful for any person to excavate any ditches, tunnels,
trenches, or lay a drive within a radius of ten feet (10') of any public tree
without first obtaining permission from the park commissioner. Maintenance or
repair work on existing underground utilities will be permitted. Excavation for
new utilities and structures within a radius of ten feet (10') of any public
tree will not be permitted unless it is determined by the park commissioner
that it will not adversely affect the tree.
      3.   It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or
town personnel to top any public tree. An international society of
arboriculture (ISA) certified arborist shall be present at all times when work
is being performed. All other personnel utilized for work on or with trees or
shrubs shall be trained to perform the work properly and safely. Trees severely
damaged by storms or other causes or certain trees under utility wires or other
obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from
this chapter by the town council.
   C.   Removal Of Public Trees: No trees shall be removed from public places
unless they are dead, diseased, constitute a hazard to life or property, are a
public nuisance, or because a revision of planting plans necessitates. (Ord.
275, 5-1-2001)
7-5-7: PROTECTION OF PUBLIC:
   A.   Public Protection: To protect the public from danger, suitable street
and sidewalk barriers, high cones, or signs must be used when pruning, removing
or spraying trees. Flashing signals or flares must be placed on all barriers or
obstructions remaining in the street after dark. All safety devices must
conform to the standards as set forth in "The Manual Of Uniform Traffic Control
Devices" distributed by the federal highway administration, U.S. department of
transportation.
   B.   Stumps: The stumps of all removed public trees shall be cut to at least
three inches (3") below the ground, and soil shall be replaced and the area
leveled. Certain species may require the stump to be treated to prevent it from
resprouting. If the area where the tree is removed is to be paved, the stump
shall be removed to meet general construction standards.
   C.   Spraying: Suitable precautions shall be taken to protect and warn the
public that spraying is being done to public trees. Spraying will be done only
for the control of specific diseases or insects, with the proper materials in
the necessary strength, and applied at the proper time to obtain the desired
control. All spraying practices shall conform to federal, state and local
regulations and must be performed by a pesticide applicator properly licensed
by the state of Montana, department of agriculture. (Ord. 275, 5-1-2001)
7-5-8: PENALTY:
   A.   Removal Of Violation Trees; Procedure: Whenever any tree is planted or
set out in violation of the provisions of this chapter, the Manhattan town
council may remove or cause removal of the same. The Manhattan town council
will first notify the property owner(s), in writing, of the town's intention to
remove the tree(s) and give the property owner(s) a reasonable period of time
(not to exceed 45 days) within which to remove the tree(s). If the property
owner(s) does/do not comply within the specified time, the town council will
cause the removal of the tree(s) and the total cost thereof will be added to
the taxes levied against the real property of the owner(s). (Ord. 275, 5-1-
2001)
   B.   Violation: Any person violating a provision of this chapter for which
another penalty has not been provided shall, upon conviction thereof, be
punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 07-002, 2-13-2007)
CHAPTER 6
FREE PUBLIC LIBRARY
SECTION:
7-6-1: Established; Operation
7-6-2: Board Of Trustees
7-6-3: Management; Annual Accounting
7-6-1: ESTABLISHED; OPERATION:
A library shall be established within the corporate limits of the Town and
shall be operated as a joint Town-County library under the laws of the State.
School District No. 3 shall also be a participant in all respects in the
operation of the library. The Town of Manhattan, Gallatin County and School
District No. 3 shall enter into a contract and other such agreements necessary
for the operation of the free public library. (2000 Code)
7-6-2: BOARD OF TRUSTEES:
   A.   Selection: The Board of Trustees of the joint Town-County library shall
be selected according to the agreement described in this Chapter.
   B.   Compensation; Expenses: The Trustees shall serve without compensation
but their actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their
official duties may be paid from library funds.
   C.   Officers: Trustees shall meet and elect a chairman and such other
officers as they consider necessary for one-year terms.
   D.   Powers And Duties: The Board Of Trustees shall have the same powers and
duties as the Board of Trustees of a city library or county library authorized
by the laws of the State.
   E.   Term: The term of a Trustee shall not exceed five (5) years. A Trustee
shall serve no more than two (2) full terms in succession. (2000 Code)
7-6-3: MANAGEMENT; ANNUAL ACCOUNTING:
The Council shall appoint a person to manage the library and file with the Town
Council, at the end of each fiscal year, a statement accounting for the funds
received and spent. (1977 Code § 2.36.010)

7-7-1: Owner Of Property
7-7-2: Alley Discontinued

Addition, equally distant from 4th Street and Broadway and parallel thereto, as
shown on the recorded plat thereof, the same being a strip twenty feet (20') in
width and four hundred feet (400') in length. (1977 Code § 12.36.020)

CHAPTER 10
STREET MAINTENANCE DISTRICT
SECTION:
7-10-1: Created; Boundaries
7-10-2: Purpose
7-10-3: Initial Cost
7-10-4: Assessment
7-10-1: CREATED; BOUNDARIES:
Pursuant to Montana Code Annotated section 7-12-4401 et seq., the town council
hereby creates one street maintenance district. The boundaries of the district
are described as follows:
All lots and parcels of land within the corporate limits of the town of
Manhattan. It is the intention that the street maintenance district shall
consist of all tracts and parcels of land within the town limits of the town of
Manhattan. It is the intention that the boundaries of the town of Manhattan
constitute the boundaries of this street maintenance district. In the event
through annexation or otherwise, tracts or parcels of land are added to the
town of Manhattan or are removed from the corporate boundaries of the town of
Manhattan, said tracts and parcels of land shall likewise either be added to or
removed from this street maintenance district. (Ord. 258, 8-10-1999)
7-10-2: PURPOSE:
The town council desires to create the street maintenance district as a method
to provide funding for the maintenance of streets and alleys within the town of
Manhattan. Maintenance for the purposes of this chapter and subsequent
proceedings includes, but is not limited to, sprinkling, graveling, oiling,
chip sealing, seal coating, overlaying, treating, general cleaning, sweeping,
flushing, snow removal, leaf and debris removal, repair of culverts adjacent to
or under streets and the repair and replacement of street beds and the widening
of alleys. (Ord. 258, 8-10-1999)
7-10-3: INITIAL COST:
It is intended that the initial cost for this street maintenance district shall
be approximately thirty eight thousand two hundred dollars ($38,200.00).
   A.   Project A: A street maintenance project on Park Avenue one and one-half
(11/2) blocks west of Broadway, sixteen thousand two hundred dollars
($16,200.00).
   B.   Project B: A street maintenance project to replace a culvert under
Lexington Avenue, twenty two thousand dollars ($22,000.00). (Ord. 258, 8-10-
1999)
7-10-4: ASSESSMENT:
It is the intention in assessing for the street maintenance district to assess
against all developed property that has a permanent structure and either town
water or sewer service an annual assessment in an amount to be determined by
the town council each year. The formula used for computing this assessment is
an amount per thousand square feet of property. The town council shall then
determine annually what the owner of each developed tract or parcel shall pay
as an assessment. Property owners will each pay seventy one dollars sixty five
cents ($71.65) for each developed parcel for fiscal year 1999-2000. The formula
for the assessment further provides that for any lots or parcels of land owned
by the town of Manhattan, the Manhattan School District, or any railway company
that owns tracts or parcels of land within the district, rather than utilizing
the entire square footage of a lot or parcel in determining the assessment, the
footprint of all permanent structures that are serviced by either water or
sewer will be the subject of the square footage computation. (Ord. 258, 8-10-
1999)
CHAPTER 11
PARKS, TRAILS AND OPEN SPACES
SECTION:
7-11-1: Purpose
7-11-2: Board Of Park Commissioners
7-11-2-1: Membership Of Park Board
7-11-3: Park Rules
7-11-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of this chapter to enhance the public's recreational
experience and encourage the use of the town's public parks, trails, and open
spaces within the jurisdictional limits of the town, while at the same time
establishing rules intended to manage and protect these lands and the people
using these lands. These lands will be administered by the town, acting through
its park commission. (Ord. 10-001, 4-13-2010)
7-11-2: BOARD OF PARK COMMISSIONERS:
The board of park commissioners ("board") for the town of Manhattan shall have
all of the powers and duties as set forth in sections 7-16-4222 through 4228,
Montana Code Annotated, including, but not limited to, the following:
   A.   To make all rules necessary to protect and promote the growth of trees
and plants in parks, boulevards, and public places under the care and control
of the board;
   B.   To make all rules for the use of parks by the public, subject to
approval by the town council; and
   C.   To provide penalties for the violation of the rules, subject to
approval by the town council.
The rules authorized by this section have the force of town ordinances and may
be enforced as ordinances of the town are enforced. (Ord. 10-001, 4-13-2010)
7-11-2-1: MEMBERSHIP OF PARK BOARD:
   A.   The board shall be composed of seven (7) members, all of whom reside
within the town or within the zoning jurisdiction of the town. One member shall
be a member of the town council and will be the park commissioner. The park
commissioner shall be appointed by the mayor. The board members shall be
appointed by the mayor with the approval of a majority of the town council.
   B.   The six (6) members appointed by the mayor shall be appointed as
follows: three (3) for three (3) years, and three (3) for four (4) years. If,
in the event that a term is vacated prematurely such that all terms will expire
at the same time, the council shall have the discretion to appoint for
staggered terms until such revolving terms are again established.
   C.   The board members shall not be entitled to a salary but may be
reimbursed for expenses incurred as a result of their work on the board,
including, but not limited to, mileage and per diem.
   D.   The board may employ personnel to assist in its functions, upon
approval from the town council.
   E.   The board shall comply with the requirements of sections 7-1-201(11),
(12), (13) and (14), Montana Code Annotated. (Ord. 10-001, 4-13-2010)
7-11-3: PARK RULES:
Other than set forth below, additional rules may be adopted from time to time
by resolution of the town council.
   A.   Definition: "Parks" shall mean all parks, trails, and open spaces owned
or leased by the town of Manhattan and any private land dedicated for public
use.
   B.   Camping And Overnight Parking:
      1.   It is unlawful to camp, sleep, or park overnight in any park or
parking lot associated with the park.
      2.   The town of Manhattan may grant an exception to this provision for
special public events.
   C.   Motorized Vehicles:
      1.   No person shall operate a motor vehicle within the boundaries of a
town park except in parking lots.
      2.   This rule does not apply to emergency or maintenance vehicles or
vehicles necessary for use by the handicapped.
      3.   No one shall clean, wash, or perform any motor vehicle maintenance
in any park.
      4.   No one shall drain or dump waste from any vehicle in any park.
   D.   Fires:
      1.   No person shall ignite or maintain a fire within a park except in a
designated barbecue unit or the ice skating warming barrel.
   E.   Pets:
      1.   Horses are not permitted in any park.
      2.   Dogs will be on leashes in any park except in designated off leash
areas such as Linear park in the Farmstead Addition.
   F.   Littering:
      1.   Littering in parks is prohibited.
      2.   All food and animal waste shall be disposed of in a garbage can or
other receptacle designed for such purposes.
   G.   Amusement For Gain:
      1.   No amusement for gain or for which a charge is made can be conducted
in a park without a permit granted by the town of Manhattan.
      2.   Such amusement must be conducted in accordance with all park rules.
   H.   Firearms, Projectiles, Golf, Archery, Etc.:
      1.   All firearms are prohibited except duly authorized law enforcement
personnel.
      2.   No one shall hit golf balls, engage in archery, or throw spears in
any park.
   I.   Sound Amplification:
      1.   No one shall use, operate, or play any device producing sound at a
volume that is audible at a distance of over thirty feet (30') except if a
permit is granted by the town of Manhattan.
   J.   Posting Of Signs:
      1.   No one shall post, paste, paint, or affix any placard, bill, notice,
or sign upon any structure or thing within any part of a park.
   K.   Fireworks:
      1.   Fireworks are prohibited in all parks.
   L.   Trail Use:
      1.   Pedestrians, bicycles, skateboards, roller skates or rollerblades
can use all trails.
      2.   No motorized vehicles shall be allowed on the trails, except as set
out above.
   M.   Alcoholic Beverages:
      1.   The possession of alcoholic beverages is prohibited in all parks
except those issued a permit.
      2.   Members of groups or organizations, or individuals may request an
alcoholic beverage permit issued by the town of Manhattan.
   N.   Penalties: Violation of this section shall be a municipal infraction,
punishable as set forth in
title 1, chapter 4 of this code.
(Ord. 10-001, 4-13-2010)
CHAPTER 12
CAMPING ON PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY
(Rep. by Ord. 24-006, 12-11-2024)
TITLE 8
FRANCHISES
CHAPTER 1
POWER COMPANY FRANCHISE
SECTION:
8-1-1: Grant Of Franchise
8-1-2: Extension Of Mains And Pipes
8-1-3: Liability For Interruption Of Supply
8-1-4: Liability For Damages
8-1-5: Manner Of Performing Work; Changes In Grade Or Plan
8-1-6: Town Held Harmless
8-1-7: Assignment
8-1-8: Adoption Of Necessary Ordinances
8-1-9: Reservation Of Rights
8-1-10: Forfeiture
8-1-1: GRANT OF FRANCHISE:
There is hereby granted to the Montana Power Company, a corporation, its
successors and assigns (hereinafter called the "Grantee"), the right, privilege
and franchise for the full period of fifty (50) years from and after September
8, 1980, and thereafter until and unless otherwise provided by ordinance to
construct, equip, lay, maintain and operate in, under, upon, over and across
the streets, avenues, alleys, highways, bridges, casements and other public
places in the Town, as now or hereafter constituted, mains, pipes, conduits,
manholes, reducing and regulating stations and all other appurtenances and
accessories for the purpose of transporting, conveying, distributing, supplying
and selling natural gas or artificial gas, or a mixture of natural and
artificial gas for light, heat, power and other purposes, at rates fixed and
allowed by the Public Service Commission of Montana, and Grantee agrees to file
with the Town Clerk/Treasurer the schedule of rates thus fixed and allowed.
(1977 Code § 12.30.010)
8-1-2: EXTENSION OF MAINS AND PIPES:
The Grantee shall extend its gas mains and pipes to such parties of the Town as
the consumption of gas shall justify. (1977 Code § 12.30.020)
8-1-3: LIABILITY FOR INTERRUPTION OF SUPPLY:
The Grantee, at all times during the existence of this franchise, shall use its
best efforts to obtain and supply a continuous, sufficient and adequate
quantity of gas for use by the Town and its inhabitants; provided, however,
that Grantee shall in nowise be liable to the Town or to its inhabitants
because of the interruption or discontinuance of the supply of gas by causes
beyond the reasonable control of Grantee. (1977 Code § 12.30.030)
8-1-4: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES:
Grantee shall not discontinue the distribution of gas through its distributing
system, or any portion thereof, for an unreasonable length of time for the
purpose of making repairs and extensions, but Grantee shall not be liable to
the Town or to any consumers for damages caused by such temporary
discontinuance or interruption of the delivery of gas; provided, that such
repairs and extensions are made with reasonable diligence. (1977 Code §
12.30.040)
8-1-5: MANNER OF PERFORMING WORK; CHANGES IN GRADE OR PLAN:
   A.   Manner Of Performing Work: All work done in, under, upon, over and
across the present and future streets, avenues, alleys, highways, bridges,
easements and other public places in the Town by Grantee for the purpose of
carrying out the provisions of this franchise shall be done and performed in a
good and workmanlike manner. When any street, alley or other public place in
said Town is excavated or damaged by Grantee by reason of such work, the
Grantee shall restore such street, alley or public place to its former
condition as early as practicable.
   B.   Changes In Grade Or Plan: If at any time a change in the grade or plan
of any street, alley or public place shall be made by order of the proper Town
officials, the Grantee shall, without expense to the Town, make such changes in
the location of its pipes and facilities as the change of the grade or plan of
the street, alley or public place makes necessary, which said changes shall be
made as soon as possible after said Grantee shall have received notice from the
proper Town official having the same in charge. (1977 Code § 12.30.050)
8-1-6: TOWN HELD HARMLESS:
Grantee shall hold the Town harmless from all costs and damages which shall or
may accrue to the Town by reason of the neglect, default or misconduct of the
Grantee in connection with the exercise of its rights hereunder. (1977 Code §
12.30.060)
8-1-7: ASSIGNMENT:
Grantee is hereby given the right and authority to make assignments of this
right, privilege or franchise, and its rights hereunder, all assignees to be
bound to the same extent as the original Grantee. (1977 Code § 12.30.070)
8-1-8: ADOPTION OF NECESSARY ORDINANCES:
The Town shall pass all ordinances necessary or suitable to protect the
property and rights of said Grantee and to enable said Grantee to enforce any
of its reasonable rules and regulations for the management, operation and
control of the service hereunder, and shall pass any reasonable ordinance or
ordinances that may be necessary or suitable in order fully to confirm to said
Grantee the rights herein or hereby granted or intended so to be. (1977 Code §
12.30.080)
8-1-9: RESERVATION OF RIGHTS:
Nothing in this Chapter contained shall be held or construed to grant any
exclusive rights or privileges, but the Town reserves to itself the right at
any time to make such other grants or extend such other privileges to any other
person, company or corporation for the use of its streets, alleys or other
public places or any thereof, for the purposes in this Chapter expressed or for
any other valid purpose as the Town Council may by ordinance from time to time
determine. (1977 Code § 12.30.090)
8-1-10: FORFEITURE:
Failure on the part of Grantee to comply in any substantial respect with any of
the provisions of this franchise shall be grounds for forfeiture thereof, but
no such forfeiture shall take effect if the reasonableness or the propriety
thereof is protested by Grantee until and unless a court of competent
jurisdiction (with right of appeal in either party) shall have found that said
Grantee has failed to comply in a substantial respect with any of the
provisions of this franchise, and Grantee shall have six (6) months after the
final determination of said question to make good the default before a
forfeiture shall result, with the right in the Town Council, at its discretion,
to grant such additional time to the Grantee for compliance, as necessities in
the case may require. (1977 Code § 12.30.100)
TITLE 9
WATER AND SEWER
CHAPTER 1
SEWER USE, RATES AND CHARGES
SECTION:
9-1-1: Supervisor
9-1-2: Connection Required
9-1-3: Connection Permit
9-1-4: Connection Of Sewer
9-1-5: Costs Of Relocation
9-1-6: Cesspools
9-1-7: Prohibited Deposits
9-1-8: Lien Against Property
9-1-9: Sewer Charges And Assessments
9-1-10: Rates
9-1-11: Rate Increase
9-1-12: Wastewater System Impact Fee
9-1-13: Penalty
9-1-1: SUPERVISOR:
The mayor, by and with the consent of the town council, shall have general
supervision of all sewers of the town, both public and private. (Ord. 13-001,
7-11-2013)
9-1-2: CONNECTION REQUIRED:
Except as otherwise provided herein, every owner or occupant of lands,
buildings or premises abutting the streets or alleys in which a town sewer is
now or may hereafter be constructed, shall cause to be constructed a sewer or
drain pipe in the manner hereinafter required, which shall connect such lands,
buildings or premises and all vaults, cesspools, ditches, water closets, sinks
and pipes there or thereon used as a receptacle or conductor of wastewater,
with such nearest accessible sewer. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013; amd. Ord. 22-003,
9-8-2022)
9-1-3: CONNECTION PERMIT:
   A.   Application For Connection Permit: All persons desiring to make
connection with the public sewer system shall make application to the town for
a sewer connection permit and must pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for such
inspection and hookup, plus any costs of installation incurred.
   B.   Connection Requirements: All connections must comply with the following
requirements:
      1.   Diameter: Private connections must be not less than four inches (4")
in diameter and shall be of a substantial material as that used in the
construction of the public sewer with which said connection shall be made;
      2.   Individual: All service in private dwellings must be individual;
      3.   Fall: The fall must be not less than two percent (2%);
      4.   Turns: All turns must be not less than one-eighth (1/8) bends;
      5.   Soil Or Iron Pipe: There must be a soil or iron pipe through the
wall in all cases;
      6.   Joints: Wherever a smaller lateral leads from a larger, it must be
bushed and all joints must be swabbed very clean.
      7.   Sewer Gate Valves: All connections into a structure which does not
have a connection to the town's water system must include a sewer gate valve,
in accordance with industry standards and specifications and such gate valve
must be installed at a point within the main sewer line easement. (Ord. 13-001,
7-11-2013)
9-1-4: CONNECTION OF SEWER:
   A.   Provided By Town: The town shall construct or cause to be constructed
that part of the connecting sewer beginning at the point of jointure and
extending to the property line of the applicant.
   B.   Provided By Property Owner: The property owner shall provide
construction materials and shall construct the sewer line from their property
line to inside the structure.
   C.   Materials: All materials used in construction of sewers within the town
and the jurisdictional area of the town covered by the planning board shall
conform to the standards approved by the town council and applications shall be
approved before installation of materials. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
9-1-5: COSTS OF RELOCATION:
All subdivisions and relocations shall be referred to the town engineer for
review and all costs shall be at the expense of the developer. (Ord. 13-001, 7-
11-2013)
9-1-6: CESSPOOLS:
be erected or maintained upon any property or premises owned or occupied by
him, abutting any street or alley in which a public sewer has been or may be
constructed, any cesspool, water closet or other receptacle or conductors of
wastewater. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013; amd. Ord. 22-003, 9-8-2022)
9-1-7: PROHIBITED DEPOSITS:
No person shall deposit any garbage, rubbish, dead animals or any substance
having a tendency to obstruct the flow of a sewer in any flush tank, manhole or
sewer opening. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
9-1-8: LIEN AGAINST PROPERTY:
If any owner or occupant of land, buildings or premises abutting an aforesaid
street or alley shall fail, refuse or neglect to perform any necessary work
required by this chapter, the town shall cause such work to be done and the
cost of the construction of the same shall be assessed against such property
and the amount thereof shall constitute a lien against such property, and such
assessment shall be collected and the lien enforced by suit in the name of the
town, or by any officer, contractor to whom it may be directed, that payment be
made in any court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
9-1-9: SEWER CHARGES AND ASSESSMENTS:
The town council has the responsibility to determine if the sewer charges
presently being assessed for the town are insufficient to pay for the cost of
maintenance, repairs and to establish a reserve for additions, and to assist in
the payment of sewer bonds under the present rate schedule, it is necessary to
raise the sewer charges for each user in the town. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
9-1-10: RATES:
   A.   User Rates: The town council will establish and change the wastewater
rates and charges by resolution after notice and hearing as provided in
sections 69-7-111 and 112, Montana Code Annotated (1999).
   B.   Industrial Waste: Industrial wastes hereinafter being established in
the town shall be charged the same monthly rates or shall have a rate
contingent upon the volume of sewer discharged, the BOD, oil and grease, and
suspended solids concentration in relation to the standard domestic
concentrations. The assumptions for standard domestic BOD loading will be two
hundred fifty milligrams per liter (250 mg/l), two hundred fifty milligrams per
liter (250 mg/l) for suspended solids, twenty five (25) milligrams per liter
(25 mg/l) for oil and grease, and a residential home per day discharging rate
of three hundred fifty (350) gallons. The following formula shall apply:
 
 Industrial Rate =
$15.45 + $15.45 ( Excess V) + (V x Excess BOD x $1.14 K1)
 V
+ (V x Excess SS x $1.14 x K1) + (V x Excess oil and grease x $2.28 x K1)
 
$1.14 is the dollar per pound charge for BOD
$1.14 is the dollar per pound charge for SS
$2.28 is the dollar per pound charge for oil and grease
K1 is a constant equal to 8.33 x 10-6 which converts the units to dollars per
month.
V is the monthly volume in gallons, equal to 10,500 gallons.
Excess V is the monthly sewage flow from industry in excess of 10,500 gallons.
Excess BOD is the monthly BOD concentration greater than 250 milligrams per
liter.
Excess SS is the SS concentration greater than 250 milligrams per liter.
Excess oil and grease is the oil and grease concentration greater than 25
milligrams per liter.
   C.   Disputes: The rates, charges and rentals hereinabove specified shall be
deemed prima facie fair, reasonable and equitable. In any case where any
contention is made that said rates are unfair, inequitable, or unreasonable,
the party objecting thereto shall apply to the town superintendent, stating the
facts and grounds of complaint, and the town superintendent shall investigate
and report with recommendations to the town council. The town superintendent
may also report to said town council any cases where the amount or character of
the sewage from any plant, building, or premises is such that collection and
disposal thereof is substantially more expensive than average sewage, and give
recommendations as to higher rates to be imposed for the collection and
disposal of sewage. The town superintendent shall consider each and all of such
complaints and reports, and communicate his findings in respect thereto to the
town council within one month after the filing of such complaint. The town
council shall have the right to order public hearings as to any such matter,
and if convinced that an adjustment of sewerage rates or charges for such
plant, building, or premises is necessary to provide equality with those
charged to others, it shall so provide by law amendatory hereto.
   D.   Special Agreement Or Arrangement: No statement contained in this
chapter shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement
between the town and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of
unusual strength or character may be accepted by the town for treatment.
   E.   Liability For Charges: The owner of each premises to which wastewater
service is available from a main line owned or operated by the town shall be
liable for payment of the charge hereinabove prescribed. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-
2013)
9-1-11: RATE INCREASE:
The town council may increase the wastewater fees as necessary by resolution
from time to time in accordance with section
9-1-10 of this chapter. Any proposal for a rate increase will be provided to
the Montana consumer council prior to any hearing on the proposal. (Ord. 13-
001, 7-11-2013)
9-1-12: WASTEWATER SYSTEM IMPACT FEE:
   A.   Fee Increases: The town council may increase the wastewater system
impact fees as necessary from time to time by resolution after notice and
hearing as provided in sections 7-1-4128 and 7-1-4131, Montana Code Annotated
(1999).
   B.   Continuation Of Connection Permit: The wastewater system impact fee
shall have no effect upon the current practice of charging customers for
additional expenses the town incurs in making a new connection into the town's
wastewater collection system main. The practice of charging the new customer
for these incidental expenses of materials and manpower shall continue.
   C.   Capitol Improvement Fund: All monies collected through this wastewater
system impact fee shall be deposited directly into the capital improvement fund
which will be called a reserve for replacement. Said account shall be used only
for expansion of the wastewater (sewer) system. Said account shall not be used
for replacement of lines or maintenance of existing lines and/or facilities.
(Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
9-1-13: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter for which another penalty
has not been provided shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as set forth
in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
CHAPTER 2
SEWER REGULATIONS
SECTION:

9-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used
in this chapter shall be as follows:
AASHTO: The American Association Of State Highway And Transportation Officials.
ASA: The American Standards Association.
ASTM: The American Society For Testing Materials.
AWWA: The American Waterworks Association.
BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in
five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C) expressed in milligrams per
liter.
BUILDING DRAIN: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system
which receives the discharge from waste, and other drainage pipes inside the
walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning three
feet (3') outside the inner face of the building wall.
BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or
other place of disposal, also called house connection.
GARBAGE: The animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking and serving of foods.
INDUSTRIAL CUSTOMER: A user discharging any waste stronger than residential
strength requiring more treatment than wastes from sanitary conveniences. Any
waste with a higher concentration than from a residential user with respect to
suspended solids and five (5) day twenty degree centigrade (20°C) biochemical
oxygen and oil and grease demand is classified as an industrial waste.
INDUSTRIAL WASTES: The wastewater from all industrial commercial sources other
than residential, trade or business as distinct from domestic or sanitary
wastes.
OSHA: The occupations safety health administration.
pH: The logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration. The
concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams, per liter of solution.
Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of seven (7) and a hydrogen ion
concentration of 10-7.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or
group.
PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and
dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles
will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public
sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2") (1.27 cm) in any
dimension.
PUBLIC SEWERS: The sewers constructed in streets, alleys, roadways and
easements, and are the sewers to which the building sewers connect. All public
sewers are under the control of the town.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer that carries liquid and water carried wastes from
residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions together
with minor quantities of ground, storm and surface waters that are not admitted
intentionally.
SEWAGE: The spent water of a community. The preferred term is "wastewater".
SLUG: Any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given
constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer
than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty four (24)
hour concentration or flows of normal operation. This slug will be considered
as adversely affecting the collection system and/or performance of the
wastewater treatment works.
STORM DRAIN OR STORM SEWER: A drain or sewer for conveying water, groundwater,
subsurface water, or unpolluted water from any source.
SUSPENDED SOLIDS (SS): Total suspended matter that either floats on the surface
of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater or other liquids, and that is
removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "Standard Methods For The
Examination Of Water And Wastewater" and referred to as nonfilterable residue.
TOWN: The town of Manhattan, Montana.
UNPOLLUTED WATER: Water of quality equal to or better than the effluent
criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water
quality standards, and would not be benefitted by discharge to the sanitary
sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided.
WASTEWATER: The spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it
may be a combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from residences,
commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with any
groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present.
WASTEWATER TREATMENT WORKS: An arrangement of devices and structures for
treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous
with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "wastewater
pollution control plant". (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
9-2-2: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED:
   A.   Prohibited Deposits: It shall be unlawful for any person to place,
deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private
property within the town, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the town,
any human or animal excrement, garbage or objectionable waste.
   B.   Discharge Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural
outlet within the town or in any area under the jurisdiction of the town, any
wastewater or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been
provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this chapter.
   C.   Construction Of Privy, Septic Tank, Cesspool: Except as hereinafter
provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault,
septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of
wastewater.
   D.   Connection Required: Except as otherwise provided herein, the owners of
all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment,
recreation, or other purposes, situated within the town and abutting on any
street, alley or right of way in which there is now located or may in the
future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the town, is hereby
required at the owner's expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein,
and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within ninety (90) days after
date of official notice to do so, provided the town determines that a service
line can reasonably be connected to the public sewer.
   E.   Interim Systems: In the event there is no capacity in the town’s public
sewer system, an interim on site wastewater treatment system may be constructed
on property and used until such time as the town’s public sewer system has
sufficient capacity for the property if such property and system meet the
following requirements:
      1.   There is no available capacity in the town’s public sewer system.
      2.   The parcel being subdivided is located within the boundaries of the
town.
      3.   The parcel to be subdivided is over twenty (20) acres and the
minimum lot size after subdivision is two (2) acres or greater.
      4.   The zoning for the new parcels will be Light Industrial (I-1). No
residential lots will be allowed an interim wastewater treatment system.
      5.   The proposed interim wastewater treatment system does not adversely
impact the town’s existing water or sewer infrastructure.
      6.   The proposed interim wastewater treatment system does not adversely
impact neighboring property.
      7.   The proposed interim wastewater treatment system does not prohibit
the town from installing public infrastructure (e.g. water mains and wells).
      8.   The system shall be reviewed and approved by the State of Montana
Department of Environmental Quality, Gallatin County City-County Health
Department, and the Town of Manhattan. Official system approval will be the
jurisdiction of the State of Montana Department of Environmental Quality and/or
Gallatin County City-County Health Department. The town has the right to deny
any interim wastewater treatment system it finds does not meet these
requirements regardless of State or County approval.
      9.   The developer of any subdivision or development that intends to use
an interim wastewater treatment system must also install the infrastructure for
a town owned wastewater collection system in accordance with the town
specification and master plans that are in effect at the time the system is
designed and installed. Once capacity in the town’s sewer is available, the
interim wastewater system shall be discontinued, permanently abandoned from all
uses, and removed/reclaimed as required or specified by the town, Gallatin
City-County Health Department, and Montana Department of Environmental Quality.
The responsibility for abandoning, removing/reclaiming, and switching from the
interim wastewater treatment system is with the developer, the Owner’s
Association for the subdivision or development and the lot owner.
      10.   The Owner’s Association shall have sixty (60) days to switch the
town’s sewer system from the date the town notifies the Owner’s Association
that capacity is available. The Owner’s Association shall call for an
inspection by the town to verify the interim wastewater treatment system has
been discontinued before any connection to the town is allowed. Failure to
switch to the town’s system or failure to call for an inspection as set out
above shall result in the town assessing the individual lots with the costs
incurred by the town as a result of the failure of the Owner’s Association to
make the switch and obtain the necessary verification. Such assessment shall
become a lien against the property if not paid within thirty (30) days of
notice of the assessment.
      11.   Once switched to the town’s sewer system, each lot shall be
assessed, and required to pay, the sewer impact fee that is in place at the
time of the switch. Failure to pay the impact fee will result in a lien against
the property that may be collected as set out in Section
9-1-8 of this Code.
      12.   The design and construction of the interim system and town owned
system shall allow for turnkey operation upon the requirement to connect to the
town owned system. The system shall be designed to discharge raw wastewater
meeting the requirements of the Manhattan Town Code, Section
9-2-9.
(Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013; amd. Ord. 22-003, 9-8-2022)
9-2-3: PIPE:
Piping used for building sewers shall be a minimum of four inches (4") and
shall conform to the following specifications:
   A.   Cast Iron Pipe And Fittings:
      1.   Cast iron pipe and fittings shall conform to the ASTM specification
A-74 and shall be heavy strength.
      2.   Cast iron pipe shall conform to the requirements of ASA A-21.6
specifications for cast iron pipe centrifugally spun in metal mold or ASA A-
21.8 specifications for cast iron pipe centrifugally spun in sand lined molds.
   B.   Vitrified Clay Sewer Pipe: Vitrified clay sewer pipe shall conform to
the requirements of ASTM specification C-200 for extra strength clay sewer
pipe.
   C.   Unglazed Vitrified Clay Sewer Pipe: Unglazed vitrified clay sewer pipe
shall conform to the requirements of ASTM specifications C-200 for extra
strength clay sewer pipe. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
9-2-4: JOINTS:
   A.   Polyvinyl Chloride Pipe: Jointing material for polyvinyl chloride pipe
shall be rubber compression rings or solvent weld.
   B.   Joints Between Unlike Materials: Joints between any unlike type
material shall be made of an adaptor type coupling or caulked joint packed with
oakum or hemp and filled with molten lead. The proper adapters may be used
providing the adaptor is furnished with stainless steel compression rings.
(Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
9-2-5: APPLICATION; REQUIREMENTS FOR SERVICE:
   A.   Application For Service: All applications for service must be made to
the town and must be signed by the owner of the property or his authorized
agent. The application will detail the type of dwelling served, commercial,
industrial or domestic, the length, grade, and size of sewer, and the block and
lot locations in the town. There shall be sufficient information such that the
town engineer or town superintendent can effectively determine the feasibility
of the proposed sewer.
   B.   Written Consent Required: If the building sewer is to be connected to a
sewer built by private parties, or is to pass through property not owned by the
applicant, the written consent of the owner shall be procured and filed with
the application. The engineer's or superintendent's approval shall be required
before construction begins. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
9-2-6: RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Joints: All joints shall be watertight, and inspected by the town
engineer, town superintendent, or an authorized agent, prior to backfilling of
trenches.
   B.   Contractor's Certificate: The contractor shall supply the town a
certificate to be endorsed by the engineer or inspector specifying and
attesting to the material used, the watertight nature of the sewer and
connection to the existing sewer as provided in this chapter. In no case will
the contractor be allowed to connect a building sewer to the outlet of a septic
tank or cesspool and discharge the waste into the public system. (Ord. 13-001,
7-11-2013)
9-2-7: MINIMUM GRADES:
Building sewer grades shall have a minimum grade from the building to the
public sewer of not less than 1.25 percent (0.125 feet in 10 feet) for four
inch (4") pipe; 0.62 percent (0.062 feet in 10 feet) for six inch (6") pipe;
and 0.40 percent (0.040 feet in 10 feet) for eight inch (8") pipe. (Ord. 13-
001, 7-11-2013)
9-2-8: HOOKUP INSPECTION FEE:
A minimum fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged for inspection of each
service connection. Special conditions may be established by the town in the
case of multiple hookups. (Ord. 13-001, 7-11-2013)
9-2-9: USE; DISCHARGE TO PUBLIC SEWERS:
   A.   Unpolluted Drainage: No person shall discharge or cause to be
discharged any unpolluted waters such as stormwater, groundwater, roof runoff,
subsurface drainage or cooling water to any sanitary sewer.
   B.   Prohibited Discharges: No person shall discharge or cause to be
discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public
sewers:
      1.   Flammable Or Explosive: Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or
other flammable or explosive liquid, solid, or gas.
      2.   Toxic Or Poisonous: Any waters containing toxic or poisonous solids,
liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with
other wastes, to injure or interfere with any waste treatment process,
constitute a hazard to humans, or animals, create a public nuisance, or create
any hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant.
      3.   pH: Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than
9.0 or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard
to structures, equipment and personnel of the wastewater works.
      4.   Solid Or Viscous Substances: Solid or viscous substances in
quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in
sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the wastewater
facilities such as, but not limited to, ashes, bones, cinders, sand, mud,
straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground
garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper
dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage
grinders.
   C.   Harmful Materials/Substances: The following described substances,
materials, waters or wastes shall be limited in discharges to the town systems
to concentrations or quantities which will not harm either the sewers,
wastewater treatment process or equipment, will not have an adverse effect on
the receiving stream, or will not otherwise endanger lives, limb, public
property, or constitute a nuisance. The town council may set limitations lower
than the limitations established in the regulations below if, in their opinion,
such more severe limitations are necessary to meet the above objectives. In
forming their opinion as to the acceptability, the town council will give
consideration to such factors as the quantity of subject waste in relation to
flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers,
the wastewater treatment process employed, capacity of the wastewater treatment
plant, degree of treatability of the waste in the wastewater treatment plant,
and other pertinent factors. The limitations or restrictions on materials or
characteristics of waste or wastewaters discharged to the sanitary sewer which
shall not be violated without approval of the town council are as follows:
      1.   Temperature: Wastewater having a temperature higher than one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) (65°C).
      2.   Oils: Wastewater containing more than ten milligrams per liter (10
mg/l) of petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oils or products of mineral
oil origin.
      3.   Oil, Fat Or Grease: Wastewater from any source containing floatable
oils, fat, or grease of more than twenty five milligrams per liter (25 mg/l).
      4.   Improperly Shredded Garbage: Any garbage that has not been properly
shredded (see section
9-2-1 of this chapter). Garbage grinders may be connected to sanitary sewers
from homes, hotels, institutions, restaurants, hospitals, catering
establishments, or similar places where garbage originates from the preparation
of food in kitchens for the purpose of consumption on the premises or when
served by caterers.
      5.   Objectionable Substances: Any waters or wastes containing the
following or similar objectionable substances to such a degree that any such
material received in the composite wastewater at the wastewater treatment works
exceeds the following limits or the limits established by the town
superintendent for such materials:
Iron     5.0 mg/l
Nickel   1.0 mg/l
Chromium 3.0 mg/l
Lead     0.1 mg/l
Copper   1.0 mg/l
Cadmium  0.02 mg/l
Zinc     2.5 mg/l
Boron    1.0 mg/l
 
      6.   Radioactive: Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half- life
or concentration as may exceed limits established by applicable state or
federal regulations.
      7.   Slug: Quantities of flow, concentrations, or both which constitute a
"slug" as defined herein.
      8.   Substances Not Amenable To Treatment: Waters or wastes containing
substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the wastewater
