(facility) but is not authorized to sell marijuana or marijuana products to
consumers under any circumstances.
   MEDICAL MARIJUANA DISPENSARY: The location from which a registered
cardholder may obtain marijuana or marijuana products.
   NUDE MODEL STUDIO: Any place where a person who repeatedly or regularly
appears in a state of nudity or displays "specified anatomical areas" is
provided to be observed, sketched, drawn, painted, sculptured, photographed or
similarly depicted by other persons for consideration.
   NUDITY OR A STATE OF NUDITY: The appearance of a human bare buttock, anus,
anal cleft or cleavage, pubic area, male genitals, female genitals or vulva,
with less than a fully opaque covering; or a breast with less than a fully
opaque covering or any part of the areola; or human male genitals in a
discernibly turgid state even if completely and opaquely covered.
   PERSON: An individual, proprietorship, partnership, corporation, association
or other legal entity.
   PREMISES: The real property upon which the adult oriented business is
located, and all appurtenances thereto and buildings thereon, including, but
not limited to, the adult oriented business, the grounds, private walkways and
parking lots and/or parking garages adjacent thereto, under the ownership,
control or supervision of the licensee.
   SEMINUDE OR SEMINUDITY: The appearance of the female breast below a
horizontal line across the top of the areola at its highest point. This
definition shall include the entire lower portion of the human female breast,
but shall not include any portion of the cleavage of the human female breast
exhibited by a dress, blouse, skirt, leotard, bathing suit or other wearing
apparel provided the areola is not exposed in whole or in part.
   SEXUAL ENCOUNTER CENTER: A business or commercial enterprise that, as one of
its principal business purposes, offers for any form of consideration:
      1.   Physical contact in the form of wrestling or tumbling between
persons of the opposite sex; or
      2.   Activities or physical contact between persons of the opposite sex
and/or persons of the same sex when one or more of the persons is in a state of
nudity or seminudity.
   SPECIFIED ANATOMICAL AREAS: 1. The human male genitals in a discernibly
turgid state, even if fully and opaquely covered;
      2.   Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic
region, buttocks or a female breast below a point immediately above the top of
the areola.
   SPECIFIED CRIMINAL ACTIVITY: Any of the following offenses:
      1.   Prostitution or promotion of prostitution; dissemination of
obscenity; sale, distribution or display of harmful material to a minor; sexual
performance by a child; possession or distribution of child pornography; public
lewdness, indecent exposure; indecency with a child, sexual assault;
molestation of a child; incest; endangering the welfare of children, or any
similar sex related offenses to those described above under the criminal or
penal code of this state, or other states or other countries;
      2.   For which:
         a.   Less than two (2) years have elapsed since the date of conviction
or the date of release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever
is the later date, if the conviction is of a misdemeanor offense;
         b.   Less than five (5) years have elapsed since the date of
conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for the conviction,
whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a felony offense;
         c.   Less than five (5) years have elapsed since the date of the last
conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for the last
conviction, whichever is the later date, if the convictions are for two (2) or
more misdemeanor offenses or combination of misdemeanor offenses occurring
within any twenty four (24) month period;
      3.   The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on
the disqualification of the applicant.
   SPECIFIED SEXUAL ACTIVITIES: Means and includes any of the following:
      1.   The fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic
region, buttocks, anus or female breast, whether covered or uncovered;
      2.   Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including
intercourse, oral copulation or sodomy;
      3.   Masturbation, actual or simulated; or
      4.   Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the
activities set forth in subsections 1 through 3 of this definition.
   SUBSTANTIAL ENLARGEMENT OF AN ADULT ORIENTED BUSINESS: The increase in floor
areas occupied by the business by more than twenty five percent (25%), as the
floor areas existed as of the passage date hereof.
   TESTING LABORATORY: A marijuana testing laboratory which provides testing of
representative samples of marijuana and marijuana products and provides
information about the chemical composition and potency of a sample, as well as
the presence of molds, pesticides or other contaminates.
   TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP OR CONTROL OF AN ADULT ORIENTED BUSINESS: Means and
includes any of the following:
      1.   The sale, lease or sublease of the business;
      2.   The transfer of securities that form a controlling interest in the
business, whether by sale, exchange or similar means; or
      3.   The establishment of a trust, gift or other similar legal devise
that transfers the ownership or control of the business, except for transfer by
bequest or other operation of law upon the death of the person possessing the
ownership or control.
(Ord. 295, 11-10-2003; amd. Ord. 23-001, 1-12-2023)

CHAPTER 2
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
10-2-1: Zoning Administrator
10-2-2: Zoning Permit
10-2-3: Schedule Of Fees
10-2-4: Discontinuance Of Violations
10-2-5: Complaint Procedures
10-2-6: Manhattan Master Plan
10-2-1: ZONING ADMINISTRATOR:
   A.   Office Established: The town council shall appoint a zoning
administrator who shall administer and enforce the provisions of this title.
   B.   Duties: It is the intent of this title that the zoning administrator
shall check all zoning permits for compliance with this Title. It is the intent
of this Title that the Building Official shall check all construction and
associated plans and permits.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 24-004, 5-9-2024)
10-2-2: ZONING PERMIT:
   A.   Required:
      1.   Building, Structure: No footprint or height of any building or
structure within the town can be changed and no building or other structure can
be erected without a valid zoning permit issued by the zoning administrator.
      2.   Compliance Required For Issuance: No such zoning permit shall be
issued except in conformity with all of the provisions of this title.
      3.   Change In Use: No use of any building, structure or land shall be
changed for nonresidential purposes until a zoning permit can be obtained.
      4.   Enclosed Area: Only those structures or buildings which have an
enclosed area of more than two hundred (200) square feet are required to obtain
a zoning permit under the building code and ordinances of the town.
   B.   Application:
      1.   Required: No new building shall be constructed or existing building
altered within the town unless the person desiring to construct or alter the
building has made application to the town of Manhattan building official and
zoning administrator for proper permitting per International Code Conference
rules and regulations, the Manhattan Town Code and the building code as adopted
by the state of Montana to construct or alter said building.
      2.   Contents: All applications must show the lot upon which the
construction is to be made, the size, nature and extent of the construction or
alteration, including at a minimum scaled:
         a.   Plans, elevations, and building sections indicating dimensions
and building materials.
         b.   Dimensioned setback from the street and all lot lines.
         c.   Utility connections.
         d.   Parking spaces if required per this title.
   C.   Filing Of Plans: All applications for zoning permits for new
construction shall:
      1.   Be accompanied by plans, in duplicate, drawn to scale, showing the
actual dimensions and shape of the lot to be built upon.
      2.   Show the legal description of the parcel, the exact sizes and
locations of the lot and of buildings already existing, if any, and the
location and dimensions of the proposed buildings or alterations.
      3.   Include such other information as lawfully may be required by the
zoning administrator or this title, including existing or proposed building and
land.
      4.   Show the number of families, housekeeping units or rental units the
building is designed to accommodate.
      5.   Show conditions existing on the lot.
      6.   Show such other matters as may be necessary to determine conformance
with, and provide for the enforcement of this title.
      7.   One copy of the plans shall be returned to the applicant by the
clerk/treasurer of the town council, after the building official and zoning
administrator has marked such copy either as approved or disapproved. The
second copy of the plans similarly marked shall be retained by the clerk/
treasurer.
   D.   Issuance; Denial Of Application: If the application is in conformance
with this title and any amendments thereto, the town council shall issue a
permit for the construction or alteration of said building; but if they are not
in conformance with this title, no permit shall be given by the town council
and thereafter, no construction or alteration may be made unless authorized by
the board of adjustment as hereinafter provided for.
   E.   Term: All permits expire within one year after date of issue unless
construction has begun, this includes site improvements, or an extension of the
permit is granted by the zoning administrator.
   F.   Conformity Of Construction And Use: Zoning permits issued on the basis
of plans and applications approved by the zoning administrator authorize only
the use, arrangement and construction set forth in such approved plans and
applications, and any other use, arrangement or construction at variance with
that authorized shall be deemed a violation of this title, and punishable by
section
10-1-3 of this title.
   G.   Expiration And Cancellation:
      1.   If the work described in any zoning permit has not been
substantially completed within one year of the date of issuance thereof, such
permit shall expire and be canceled by the zoning administrator or building
official and written notice thereof shall be given to the persons affected,
together with notice that further work, as described in the canceled permit,
shall not proceed unless and until a new zoning permit has been obtained.
   H.   Appeals: Any person or persons, jointly or severally aggrieved by any
decision of the zoning administrator or building official may present to the
Board of Adjustments an appeal petition specifying the grounds for the appeal.
Such petition shall be presented to the Board of Adjustments within thirty (30)
days after the filing of the zoning administrator or building official.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. 2000 Code; Ord. 14-001, 5-14-2014)
10-2-3: SCHEDULE OF FEES:
   A.   Established: The town council shall establish a schedule of fees,
charges and expenses and a collection procedure for zoning permits, appeals,
variances and other matters pertaining to this title. The schedule of fees
shall be filed in the office of the town council, and may be altered or amended
only by the town council.
   B.   Payment Required: No permit, zone change, or variance shall be issued
unless or until such costs, charges, fees or expenses have been paid in full,
nor shall any action be taken by the board of adjustment until preliminary
charges and fees have been paid in full.
   C.   Home Occupation Permits: The town council shall establish a schedule of
fees, charges and expenses to process home occupation permit applications. No
permit shall be reviewed or issued unless or until such fee is paid in full.
The amount of the fee shall be set, and amended as necessary, by resolution.
   D.   Exception To Zoning Permit Fees: There shall be no zoning permit fee
assessed for a zoning permit when such permit is reviewed in conjunction with
and as part of a building inspection conducted in accordance with title 12 of
this code.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. 2000 Code; Ord. 298, 8-9-2004; Ord. 09-001, 8-11-
2009; Ord. 24-004, 5-9-2024)
10-2-4: DISCONTINUANCE OF VIOLATIONS:
If the zoning administrator or other appointed officials shall find that any
provision of this title is being violated, he/she shall notify, in writing, the
person responsible for such violation and order corrective action. He/she shall
order discontinuance of illegal use of land, structures or buildings; removal
of illegal buildings or structural changes thereto; discontinuance of any
illegal work being done; or shall take any other action authorized by this
title to ensure compliance therewith or to prevent its violation. (Ord. 253,
12-1-1998)
10-2-5: COMPLAINT PROCEDURES:
   A.   Right To File: Whenever a violation of this title occurs or is alleged
to have occurred, any person may file a written complaint.
   B.   Filing: Such complaint stating fully the causes and basis thereof shall
be filed with the town council.
   C.   Investigation: The town council shall record properly such complaint
and immediately investigate.
   D.   Findings: Upon completion of the investigation, the town council shall
record its findings with the clerk/treasurer of the town council.
   E.   Service On Owner: If a violation has occurred, the town council, upon
recording its findings with the clerk/treasurer of the town council, shall give
instruction to the chief of police to serve the owner of the property with a
copy of the complaint and a copy of the findings of the town council.
   F.   Appearance Before Council: The owner shall then appear in front of the
town council at its next meeting to discuss an acceptable remedy to the
violation.
   G.   Failure To Comply: If the owner does not agree to correct the violation
or fails to correct the violation within the period provided by the town
council, the town attorney may file formal charges and prosecute the owner as
provided in section
10-1-3 of this title.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 24-004, 5-9-2024)
10-2-6: MANHATTAN MASTER PLAN:
An ordinance by the town council that in July 2004, the town of Manhattan
growth policy was adopted and was updated in July of 2012, is hereby adopted in
whole. A copy of the 2012 updated Manhattan growth policy is on file in the
town offices. (Ord. 14-001, 5-14-2014)
CHAPTER 3
BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT
SECTION:
10-3-1: Established; Purpose; Appointment
10-3-2: Officers; Support Staff; Records
10-3-3: Powers And Duties
10-3-4: Procedure For Appeals, Variances
10-3-4-1: Application; Fee
10-3-4-2: Investigation
10-3-4-3: Hearing; Notice
10-3-4-4: Approval Criteria
10-3-4-5: Required Findings Of The Board Of Adjustments
10-3-4-6: Additional Recommendations
10-3-4-7: Issuance Restrictions
10-3-4-8: Appeal, Time Limitations
10-3-4-9: Effective Date Of Decisions
10-3-1: ESTABLISHED; PURPOSE; APPOINTMENT:
   The Board of Adjustment is established to act on appeal and variance
applications as detailed in this Chapter. The Board shall consist of five (5)
members appointed by the Mayor for three (3) year terms (staggering terms),
subject to confirmation by the Town Council. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-3-2: OFFICERS; SUPPORT STAFF; RECORDS:
   A.   Officers: At the first meeting each year, the Board shall appoint one
of its members to serve as chairman and one member to serve as vice chairman.
   B.   Zoning Administration: The Zoning Administrator shall be at the
disposal of the Board to receive and process applications of appeal and
variance and to give advice to the Board.
   C.   Office: The Board’s office shall be that of the Town Hall and all files
of the Board shall be held therein.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 24-004, 5-9-2024)
10-3-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   The Board shall set its operating rules in accordance with Montana Code
Annotated sections 76-2-321 through 76-2-328, and shall have the following
powers:
   A.   Hear And Decide Appeals: To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged
there is error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by an
administrative official in the enforcement of the provisions of this Title, or
any amendment thereto.
   B.   Authorize Variances: To authorize variances in specific cases such
variance from the terms of this Title as will not be contrary to the public
interest, where owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the
provisions of this Title will result in unnecessary hardship and so that the
spirit of this Title be observed and substantial justice done. The Board may,
after public notice and hearing, approve, conditionally approve or deny any
request to grant variances.
   C.   Reverse Decision Of Administrative Officer: The concurring vote of four
(4) members of the Board shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement,
decision or determination of any administrative official, or to decide in favor
of the applicant on any matter upon which it is required to pass under this
Title, or to effect any variation of this Title.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 24-004, 5-9-2024)
10-3-4: PROCEDURE FOR APPEALS, VARIANCES:
10-3-4-1: APPLICATION; FEE:
Written applications for appeals or variances shall be filed in the office of
the Clerk/Treasurer of the Town Council. Notwithstanding any other provisions
of this Title, the uniform filing fee of each application is for the purpose of
defraying expenses incidental to proceedings. No application will be regarded
as having been filed until such fee has been paid. The fee schedule may be
obtained from the office of the Clerk/Treasurer of the Town Council. (Ord. 253,
12-1-1998)
10-3-4-2: INVESTIGATION:
The Board of Adjustment shall cause to be made such investigation of facts
bearing on the application as will provide necessary information to assure that
the action on each such application is consistent with the intent and purpose
of this Title. During time of appeal all construction shall cease and shall not
commence until approved by the Board of Adjustment. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-3-4-3: HEARING; NOTICE:
   A.   Hearing Required: There shall be a hearing for each application of
appeal or variance. The hearing shall be held at the appointed time and place.
Testimony shall be taken by the Board of Adjustment from persons interested in
such application.
   B.   Notice Of Hearing: Notice of hearing shall be published once in a
newspaper of general circulation within the Town at least fifteen (15) days and
not more than thirty (30) days prior to the hearing date. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-3-4-4: APPROVAL CRITERIA:
Before any variance can be granted, the Board of Adjustment shall make findings
of fact setting forth and showing that the following circumstances exist:
   A.   Rezone: In considering all proposed variances to this Title, the Board
shall, before making any finding in a specified case, first determine that the
proposed variance will not amount to a rezone and constitute a change in the
district boundaries shown on the Official Zoning Map.
   B.   Special Conditions And Circumstances: Special conditions and
circumstances exist which are peculiar to the land such as size, shape,
topography or location, not applicable to other lands in the same district and
that literal interpretation of the provisions of this Title would deprive the
property owner of rights commonly enjoyed by other properties similarly
situated in the same district under the terms of this Title.
   C.   Actions Of Applicant: The special conditions and circumstances do not
result from the actions of the applicant. This includes a failure to complete
due diligence in the purchase of any property reviewed for a variance.
   D.   No Special Privilege: Granting of the variance will not confer a
special privilege to subject property that is denied other lands in the same
district.
   E.   Not Detrimental To Public Welfare: The granting of the variance will
not be materially detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to the
property or improvements in the vicinity and zone in which subject property is
situated.
   F.   Reasonable Use Of Land: The Board of Adjustment shall further make a
finding that the reasons set forth in the application justify the granting of
the variance, and that the variance is the minimum variance that will make
possible the reasonable use of the land.
   G.   Harmony With Intent Of Title: The Board of Adjustment shall further
make a finding that the granting of the variance will be in harmony with the
general purpose and intent of this Title and will not be injurious to the
neighborhood, or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare.
   H.   Profitability: The fact that property may be utilized more profitably
will not be an element of consideration before the Board of Adjustment.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 24-004, 5-9-2024)
10-3-4-5: REQUIRED FINDINGS OF THE BOARD OF ADJUSTMENTS:
Before any appeals can be granted the Board of Adjustment shall make findings
of fact setting forth and showing that any one of the following circumstances
exist:
   A.   Misinterpretation of this Title: In considering an appeal of a decision
of the zoning administrator or building official the Board of Adjustments shall
find that the zoning administrator or building official made an interpretation
of this title that is inconsistent with the plain reading of this text.
   B.   Error on part of the Building Official or Zoning Administrator: The
Board of Adjustments finds that the building official or zoning administrator
made an error in their decision.
   C.   Incomplete Review: The Board of Adjustments finds that the building
official or zoning administrator decision occurred without properly reviewing
all elements of the decision that was made.
   D.   Injurious to Adjacent Landowners or Applicant: The Board of Adjustment
finds that a decision made by the building official or zoning administrator was
injurious to adjacent landowners or the applicant.
   E.   Public Welfare and Safety: The Board of Adjustments finds that a
decision made by the building official or zoning administrator was
contradictory to the general welfare and safety of the public.
   F.   Harmony with Intent of Title: The Board of Adjustments finds that a
decision made by the building official or zoning administrator was not
harmonious with the intent of this title or any additional titles of the
Manhattan Town Code.
(Ord. 24-004, 5-9-2024)
10-3-4-6: ADDITIONAL RECOMMENDATIONS:
   In granting any variance, the Board of Adjustment may prescribe appropriate
conditions and safeguards that will ensure that the purpose and intent of this
Title shall not be violated. Violation of such conditions, and safeguards, when
made part of the terms under which the variance is granted, shall be deemed a
violation of this Title and punishable under Section
10-1-3 of this Title.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 24-004, 5-9-2024)
10-3-4-7: ISSUANCE RESTRICTIONS:
   With respect to uses of land, buildings and other structures, this Title is
declared to be a definition of the public interest by the Town Council, and the
spirit of this Title will not be observed by any variance which permits a use
not generally permitted in the district involved, or any use expressly or by
implication prohibited by terms of this Title in the district. Therefore, under
no circumstances shall the Board of Adjustment grant a variance to permit a use
not generally permitted in the district involved, or any use expressly or by
implication prohibited, by the terms of this Title in such district.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 24-004, 5-9-2024)
10-3-4-8: APPEAL, TIME LIMITATIONS:
   Any person or persons, jointly or severally aggrieved by any decision of the
Board of Adjustment, or any officer, department, board or bureau of the Town,
may present to a court of record a petition, duly verified, setting forth that
such decision is illegal, in whole or in part, specifying the grounds of the
illegality. Such petition shall be presented to the court within thirty (30)
days after the filing of the decision of the office of the Board.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 24- 004, 5-9-2024)
10-3-4-9: EFFECTIVE DATE OF DECISIONS:
   The decision of the Board of Adjustment shall be final except as provided in
Section
10-3-4-7 of this Chapter and if a zoning permit is not obtained for the subject
property within six (6) months from the date of the Board’s decision, the
variance shall be automatically canceled and become null and void.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 24-004, 5-9-2024)
CHAPTER 4
ZONING MAP AND DISTRICTS 1
SECTION:
10-4-1: Zoning Map Adopted
10-4-2: Interpretation Of Boundaries
10-4-3: District Classifications
10-4-4: Prohibition Of Marijuana Businesses
 
Notes
1 1. See also chapter 17 of this title.
10-4-1: ZONING MAP ADOPTED:
The town and the one mile jurisdictional area is divided into districts, or
zones, as shown on the official zoning map which, together with all explanatory
matter thereon, is adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this
title. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-4-2: INTERPRETATION OF BOUNDARIES:
Where uncertainty exists with respect to boundaries of any of the aforesaid
districts as shown on the zoning map, the following rules shall apply:
   A.   Centerlines: Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately
the centerlines of streets or highways, street lines or highway right of way
lines shall be construed to be such boundaries.
   B.   Lot Lines: Where district boundaries are so indicated that they
approximately follow the lot lines, such lot lines shall be construed to be
such boundaries.
   C.   Parallel To Centerlines: Where district boundaries are so indicated
that they are approximately parallel to the centerlines of highways, such
district boundaries shall be construed as being parallel thereto and at such
distance therefrom as indicated on the zoning map. If no distance is given,
such dimension shall be determined by the scale of the map.
   D.   Railroad Lines: Where the boundary of a district follows a railroad
line, such boundary shall be deemed to be located in the middle of the main
tracks of such railroad line. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-4-3: DISTRICT CLASSIFICATIONS:
For the purpose of this title, the town and the one mile jurisdictional area is
divided into the following use districts:
AG  Agricultural district
RR  Rural residential district
R-1 Low density residential district
R-3 Medium density residential district
RT  Residential transitional district
CBD Central business district
NHB Neighborhood highway business district
L-1 Light industrial district
P-O Parks and open space district
 
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-4-4: PROHIBITION OF MARIJUANA BUSINESSES:
   A.   As authorized by Title 16, Chapter 12, MCA, and based on the
affirmative vote of the electors of the Town of Manhattan, the following
marijuana businesses are permanently prohibited from opening or operating
within the boundaries of the town:
      1.   Cultivator;
      2.   Manufacturer;
      3.   Medical marijuana dispensary;
      4.   Adult use dispensary;
      5.   Testing laboratory; and
      6.   Marijuana transporter facility.
   B.   Violation of this section is a municipal infraction and shall be
punished as set out in Title 1, Chapter 4 of the Town Code.
(Ord. 23-001, 1-12-2023)
CHAPTER 5
AG AGRICULTURAL DISTRICT
SECTION:
10-5-1: Purpose
10-5-2: Permitted Uses
10-5-3: Conditional Uses
10-5-4: Lot Area
10-5-5: Floor Area

10-5-1: PURPOSE:
The intent of the agricultural district, AG, is to discourage small tract
development in areas of agriculture importance and in areas of environmental
concern. It is intended that through the use of this district, agricultural
pursuits will be encouraged and environmental concerns protected. (Ord. 253,
12-1-1998)
10-5-2: PERMITTED USES:
In all the AG districts, no building or land shall be used and no building or
structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged which is arranged, intended or
designed for other than one of the uses listed below:
Accessory uses and buildings, including single- and multi- family dwellings to
house employees working on the farm or ranch.
   Agricultural uses.
   Daycare home (meeting state requirements).
   Home occupations.
Public and private parks.
Sales, on the premises, of products produced thereon.
Single-family dwellings (including modular and manufactured homes).
Veterinary clinics. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-5-3: CONDITIONAL USES:
The following uses may be permitted as conditional uses in the AG district:
Bus barns and bus garages.
Churches or similar places of worship.
Commercial kennels.
Daycare center (meeting state requirements).
Drive-in theaters.
Fishing clubs.
Golf courses.
Group daycare homes (meeting state requirements).
Horse trailers, livestock trailers, and agricultural related trailers.
Hunting clubs.
Private and public schools.
Recreational vehicle parks.
Retail sales of nonmotorized RV type trailers.
Riding academies.
Sales and rental of agricultural equipment. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord.
260, 11-2-1999; 2000 Code; Ord. 266, 8-1-2000; Ord. 293, 10-14-2003)
10-5-4: LOT AREA:
The minimum lot area in this district shall be determined by existing soil
conditions, ground water conditions and other physical limitations for
residential development. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-5-5: FLOOR AREA:
The minimum floor area for a principal single-family residence shall not be
less than one thousand two hundred (1,200) square feet of floor area. The
footprint, exclusive of the garage, for a principal single-family residence
shall not be less than nine hundred (900) square feet of floor area. (Ord. 253,
12-1-1998)
10-5-6: BUILDING HEIGHT:
The maximum building height for buildings designed and constructed for human
occupancy shall be twenty four feet (24') 1 . All other agriculture related
structures may exceed this height. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
 
Notes
1 1. See definition of "building height" in subsection 10-1-5B of this title.
10-5-7: LOT FRONTAGE:
There shall be a minimum lot frontage of not less than five hundred seventy
five feet (575'). (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-5-8: YARDS:
   A.   Front Yards: There shall be a front yard having a depth of not less
than thirty five feet (35').
   B.   Rear Yards: There shall be a rear yard having a depth of not less than
twenty five feet (25').
   C.   Side Yards: There shall be side yards having a depth of not less than
twenty five feet (25'). (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-5-9: ANIMAL ENCLOSURES; SETBACKS:
Except for pastures, any stable, barn, hutch, pen, shed or other such structure
built to enclose or house animals or fowl shall be not less than fifty feet
(50') from any structure used for human occupancy, and shall be set back not
less than fifty feet (50') from any property line. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)

ARTICLE B. R-1 LOW DENSITY RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT
SECTION:
10-6B-1: Purpose
10-6B-2: Permitted Uses
10-6B-3: Conditional Uses
10-6B-4: Lot Area
10-6B-5: Building Height
10-6B-6: Lot Frontage
10-6B-7: Floor Area
10-6B-8: Yard Restrictions
10-6B-9: Accessory Buildings And Structures
10-6B-10: Yard Encroachments
10-6B-11: Building Information
10-6B-12: Recycled Materials
10-6B-1: PURPOSE:
The low density residential district, R-1, is established for the purpose of
low density dwelling control and to allow certain public facilities. It is
intended that no use be permitted in this district that will tend to devalue
property for residential purposes or interfere with the health, safety, order
or general welfare of persons residing in the district. Regulations are
intended to control density of population and to provide adequate open space
around buildings and structures in the district to accomplish these purposes.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-6B-2: PERMITTED USES:
In an R-1 district, no building or land shall be used and no building or
structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged which is arranged, intended or
designed for other than one of the uses listed below:
Accessory uses.
Daycare home (meeting state requirements).
Home occupations by permission of the town council.
Public parks, playgrounds, recreation areas and community buildings and
facilities owned and operated by a public agency.
Single-family dwellings excluding manufactured homes, trailers, semitrailers or
house trailers.
Temporary structures incidental to construction work, but only to a maximum of
one year. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-6B-3: CONDITIONAL USES:
In an R-1 low density residential zone, the following uses may be permitted,
provided they are reviewed and approved as required in chapter 11 of this
title:
Accessory residential units. (See subsection 10-11-9A3 of this title.)
Bed and breakfast.
Churches or similar places of worship.
Daycare center (meeting state requirements).
Eldercare facility.
Golf courses.
Group daycare home (meeting state requirements).
Guesthouse.
Modular homes. (See subsection 10-11-9A2 of this title.)
Residential planned unit developments. (Permitted but reviewed. See chapter 10
of this title.)
Townhouse, two (2) units.
Two-family dwellings, may only be located on corner lots and limited to one per
block. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. 2000 Code; Ord. 06-002, 1-16-2006; Ord. 20-
001, 7-9-2020)
10-6B-4: LOT AREA:
   A.   Minimum Lot Area: The minimum lot area shall be not less than ten
thousand (10,000) square feet for a single-family dwelling except for lots that
are in the original plat of Manhattan where a minimum of seven thousand (7,000)
square feet for a single- family dwelling is permitted. For a two-family
dwelling (duplex), there shall be a minimum lot area of twelve thousand
(12,000) square feet. Duplexes may only be located on corner lots. The lot area
covered by all building structures shall not exceed thirty five percent (35%)
of the total lot area. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 06-002, 1-16-2006; Ord.
14-001, 5-14-2014)
   B.   Penalties For Violations: Any person violating a provision of this
section for which another penalty has not been provided shall, upon conviction
thereof, be punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 07-002, 2-13-2007)
10-6B-5: BUILDING HEIGHT 1 :
No building shall exceed twenty four feet (24') in height or more than two (2)
stories in height, except for one or more of the following uses or exceptions:
chimneys, fire towers, tanks, water towers, spires, church steeples, radio and
television towers or necessary mechanical appurtenances may be erected to
exceed the maximum height limitations if approved by the board of adjustment.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
 
Notes
1 1. See definition found in section 10-1-5 of this title.
10-6B-6: LOT FRONTAGE:
There shall be a minimum lot frontage of not less than seventy five feet (75')
except for lots that are in the original plat of Manhattan where a minimum of
fifty feet (50') is permitted. (Ord. 14-001, 5-14-2014)
10-6B-7: FLOOR AREA:
Each single-family unit shall have a minimum of one thousand two hundred
(1,200) square feet of floor area. The footprint, exclusive of the garage, for
a single-family unit shall not be less than nine hundred (900) square feet of
floor area. Each multi-family living unit shall have a minimum floor area of
nine hundred (900) square feet. The footprint, exclusive of the garage, for
each multi-family unit shall not be less than six hundred (600) square feet of
floor area. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-6B-8: YARD RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Front Yard: There shall be a front yard having a depth of not less than
twenty five feet (25'). However, in blocks where residential buildings have
been erected on forty percent (40%) or more of the lots, the front yard shall
not be less than the average front yard thus established. Corner lots shall
have a minimum setback of twenty five feet (25') on the frontage with the
narrowest width and fifteen feet (15') on the frontage with the longest width.
Lots abutting on cul-de-sacs shall have a front yard of not less than twenty
five feet (25') to the closest point of the structure.
   B.   Rear Yard: There shall be a rear yard having a depth of not less than
twenty feet (20'). Rear yards having a depth of not less than ten feet (10')
may be approved by the town council if the lot has no alley.
   C.   Side Yard: There shall be a side yard having a depth of not less than
eight feet (8'). (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-6B-9: ACCESSORY BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES:
By approval of the town council, detached buildings not used for residential
purposes may be approved for abutment on alleys. In case of no alley, accessory
buildings and structures may be approved within ten feet (10') of the property
line. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-6B-10: YARD ENCROACHMENTS:
Every part of a required yard shall be open to the sky, unobstructed by any
part of any structure with the exception of the following:
   A.   Projections: Projection of sills, belt courses, cornices and ornamental
features which do not project more than twelve inches (12") from the principal
building.
   B.   Unenclosed Porch; Uncovered Steps: Open unenclosed porch or uncovered
steps may project into the front yard for a distance not to exceed ten feet
(10').
   C.   Terraces, Uncovered Porches, Platforms, Ornamental Features: Terraces,
uncovered porches, platforms and ornamental features which do not extend more
than three feet (3') above the floor level of the ground story may project into
a required rear yard provided these projections be at least five feet (5') from
the property line.
   D.   Allowed In All Yards: Driveways, parking spaces, sidewalks, uncovered
patios and terraces of noncombustible materials and ornamental objects are
allowed in all yards. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-6B-11: BUILDING INFORMATION:
Building must be built on site and of new materials. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-6B-12: RECYCLED MATERIALS:
Use of recycled materials needs a conditional use. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)

10-6C-1: PURPOSE:
The medium density residential district, R-3, is intended to provide for the
new construction of single and duplex residential structures. It should provide
for a variety of housing types to serve the varied needs of families within the
district. Modular and manufactured homes are permitted within this district on
individual lots, provided they are new, meet current building codes and are
placed on permanent foundations. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 06-002, 1-16-
2006)

structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged, which is arranged, intended or

Bed and breakfast.

Home occupations by permission of the town council.

thousand five hundred (8,500) square feet. The maximum lot coverage in the R-
3 zoning district shall be forty percent (40%). (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord.
06-002, 1-16-2006)
   B.   Lot Distribution: Each block shall have a minimum of ninety percent

   C.   Penalties For Violations: Any person violating a provision of this

SECTION:
10-6D-1: Purpose
10-6D-2: Permitted Uses
10-6D-3: Conditional Uses
10-6D-4: Lot Area
10-6D-5: Building Height
10-6D-6: Lot Frontage

10-6D-8: Yard Restrictions

10-6D-10: Yard Encroachments

10-6D-12: Off Street Parking And Loading
10-6D-13: Hours Of Operation
10-6D-14: Open Storage
10-6D-15: Performance Standards
10-6D-1: PURPOSE:
The residential transitional district, RT, is intended to provide an acceptable
range of land uses and controls for limited office and commercial development
on residential properties, provided that the residential character is
maintained and driveway access is controlled. The permitted uses are limited to
low intensity office and service uses characterized by low traffic generation
and little or no customer contact on the premises. In order to maintain the
residential qualities of the surrounding areas, stringent development and
activity standards are imposed. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-2: PERMITTED USES:
In the RT district, no building or land shall be used and no building or
structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged, which is arranged, intended or
designed for other than on the uses listed below:
   A.   Any use permitted in the R-1 zone including residential occupancy of a
portion of the office/commercial development permitted in the RT district.
   B.   The following personal service establishments:
      1.   Photographic, art, and musical studios.
      2.   Offices for personal service businesses which perform their services
off the premises.
   C.   The following business service establishments:
      1.   Business and management consulting services and similar consulting
services.
      2.   Telemarketing and telephone message services.
      3.   Computer and data processing services.
      4.   Market research, advertising, and public relations.
      5.   Medical, dental and optical laboratories without individual patient
visitors.
      6.   Real estate appraisal, abstract title research, mortgage brokerages
and other real estate related businesses except sales offices.
      7.   Stenographic services and temporary office worker placement
services.
      8.   Miscellaneous business services which require only incidental client
contact on the premises.
   D.   The following professional office establishments:
      1.   Accounting and bookkeeping offices.
      2.   Engineering and architectural firms.
      3.   Attorney's offices.
      4.   Miscellaneous professional offices which require only incidental
client contact on the premises. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-3: CONDITIONAL USES:
In the RT district the following uses may be permitted, provided they are
reviewed and approved as required in chapter 11 of this title:
   A.   Any conditional use permitted in the R-1 zone except modular homes.
   B.   The following business service establishments:
      1.   Insurance and real estate sales offices.
   C.   The following public, quasi-public and governmental uses:
      1.   Preschools and daycare centers. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-4: LOT AREA:
   A.   Minimum Lot Area: The minimum lot area shall be not less than ten
thousand (10,000) square feet except for lots that are in the original plat of
Manhattan where a minimum of seven thousand (7,000) square feet is permitted.
   B.   Percentage Of Lot Coverage: The lot area covered by all buildings and
structures shall not exceed forty percent (40%) of the total lot area.
   C.   Penalties For Violations: Any person violating a provision of this
section for which another penalty has not been provided shall, upon conviction
thereof, be punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
No building shall exceed twenty four feet (24') in height or more than two (2)
stories in height, except for one or more of the following uses or exceptions:
Chimneys may be erected to exceed the maximum height limitations if approved by
the town council. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-6: LOT FRONTAGE:
There shall be a minimum lot frontage of not less than seventy five feet (75')
except for lots that are in the original plat of Manhattan where a minimum of
fifty feet (50') is permitted. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-7: FLOOR AREA:
No minimum floor area is prescribed except that residential units shall meet
the minimum floor area requirements of the R-1 district. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-
2017)
10-6D-8: YARD RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Front Yard: There shall be a front yard having a depth of not less than
twenty five feet (25'). However, in blocks where residential buildings have
been erected on forty percent (40%) or more of the lots, the front yard shall
not be less than the average front yard thus established. Corner lots shall
have a minimum setback of twenty five feet (25') on the frontage with the
narrowest width and fifteen feet (15') on the frontage with the longest width.
Lots abutting on cul-de-sacs shall have a front yard of not less than twenty
five feet (25') to the closest point of the structure.
   B.   Rear Yard: There shall be a rear yard having a depth of not less than
twenty feet (20'). Rear yards having a depth of not less than ten feet (10')
may be approved by the town council if the lot has no alley.
   C.   Side Yard: There shall be a side yard having a depth of not less than
eight feet (8'). (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-9: ACCESSORY BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES:
By approval of the town council, detached buildings not used for residential
purposes may be approved for abutment on alleys. In case of no alley, accessory
buildings and structures may be approved within ten feet (10') of the property
line. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-10: YARD ENCROACHMENTS:
Every part of a required yard shall be open to the sky, unobstructed by any
part of any structure with the exception of the following:
   A.   Projections: Projection of sills, belt courses, cornices and ornamental
features which do not project more than twelve inches (12") from principal
building.
   B.   Unenclosed Porch, Uncovered Steps: Open unenclosed porch or uncovered
steps may project into the front yard for a distance not to exceed ten feet
(10').
   C.   Terraces, Uncovered Porches, Platforms, And Ornamental Features:
Terraces, uncovered porches, platforms and ornamental features which do not
extend more than three feet (3') above the floor level of the ground story may
project into a required rear yard provided these projections be at least five
feet (5') from the property line.
   D.   Allowed In All Yards: Driveways, parking spaces, sidewalks, uncovered
patios and terraces of noncombustible materials and ornamental objects are
allowed in all yards. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-11: SIGNS:
   A.   Signage in the RT zone shall be in accordance with all elements of
chapter 15, "Sign Regulations", of this title.
   B.   Changeable copy signs are not permitted in RT zones.
   C.   In the RT district a maximum total area of all signs on a lot shall be
eight (8) square feet. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-12: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
   A.   Off street parking and loading shall be provided in accordance with
chapter 13, "Off Street Parking And Loading", of this title.
   B.   In no case shall such off street parking be permitted anywhere in front
of the building, whether in the front yard, the interior side yard, the corner
side yard or any buildable area in front of the building.
   C.   All open parking areas must be set back a minimum of five feet (5')
from the rear and side yards and effectively screened by wall, fence or
landscaping within the five foot (5') setback.
   D.   Parking lot lights shall be no more than fifteen feet (15') high and
shall be limited by the following factors:
      1.   An average lighting level of 1.0 foot-candle with a minimum of 0.75
foot-candle.
      2.   A uniformity ratio of not greater than four to one (4:1).
      3.   Lighting shall be provided by cutoff type fixtures located in such a
manner that light will not spill onto adjoining properties.
      4.   All parking lot lighting shall be extinguished no later than thirty
(30) minutes after the close of business. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-13: HOURS OF OPERATION:
Hours of public operation for any use shall be restricted to the hours of seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-14: OPEN STORAGE:
All nonresidential operations, including the storage of materials and
merchandise, shall be conducted in a fully enclosed building or entirely within
a solid, opaque wall or fence which conceals the operations from visibility for
the adjoining properties. (Ord. 17-001, 2-9-2017)
10-6D-15: PERFORMANCE STANDARDS:
   A.   Site Plan Review: A site plan review by the zoning commission and town
council approval is required for any land development or use in an RT zone. Any
building and site development must comply strictly with the approved site plan.
      1.   The site plan shall indicate the locations of proposed and existing
buildings and structures and any proposed new additions to existing structures.
      2.   The site plan shall indicate all areas dedicated to water drainage
and detention including the calculations necessary to demonstrate that one
hundred percent (100%) of a 100-year, 24-hour, water event will be retained on
site.
      3.   The site plan shall indicate landscape buffering to the adjacent
residential areas and such other buffering or features as are necessary or
appropriate to maintain the residential character of the premises and to fit
harmoniously with the character of adjoining and surrounding properties.
      4.   All buffering shall be as close to one hundred percent (100%)
opacity as possible, including during the initial planting stage of such
landscaping.
      5.   The site plan shall indicate where two (2) or more adjacent lots are
developed driveways are to be consolidated.
   B.   Building And Structures Review: All buildings and structures proposed
for construction and located within an RT zoning district shall be reviewed by
the zoning commission and approved by the town council prior to any land
development, commencement of construction, or use.
      1.   All buildings and structures shall be so designed and constructed so
that their exterior appearance is in conformance with the general appearance of
the residential district's architectural character.
      2.   All buildings and structures must be scaled to that which reflects a
residential character with regard to size, roof slope and window placement, so
as to fit harmoniously with the character of adjacent residential areas.
      3.   All exterior building facades shall be of high quality materials
that may include, but are not limited to, brick, natural stone, wood, plaster
and glass.
      4.   The following images are representative of the visual
characteristics commonly found in residential buildings and appropriate for the
residential transitional district. These images are not intended to be
prescriptive but are intended to be illustrative of the general appearance of
residential like buildings intended for the RT district with regard to scale,
size, roof slope and window placement.

CHAPTER 7
BUSINESS AND INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS
ARTICLE A. CBD CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT
SECTION:
10-7A-1: Purpose
10-7A-2: Permitted Uses
10-7A-3: Conditional Uses
10-7A-4: Prohibited Uses
10-7A-5: Building Height
10-7A-6: Lot Area And Width
10-7A-7: Setbacks
10-7A-8: Lot Coverage
10-7A-9: Off Street Parking And Loading
10-7A-10: Sign Regulations
10-7A-11: Landscaping Regulations
10-7A-1: PURPOSE:
The intent of the central business district, CBD, is to provide an adequate
area for the town's principal business, government, service and cultural
activities. Permitted uses in this district are those that are appropriate in a
relatively high density, intensively developed commercial center. The district
should be developed as an attractive, functional and convenient commercial
environment, and provide the mix of activities necessary to maintain the
downtown character. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7A-2: PERMITTED USES:
The following uses shall be permitted:
Accessory uses customary to the permitted uses on a lot.
Any use permitted in the R-3 zone.
Automobile parking lots and garages.
Bars and cocktail lounges.
Bus and other passenger transportation terminals.
Educational establishments other than "schools" as defined in subsection 10-1-
5B of this title.
Financial institutions.
Hotels and motels.
Medical and veterinary clinics.
Meeting and lodge halls.
Museums, libraries, galleries.
Offices, private and public.
Recreation and amusement establishments and facilities.
Repair and maintenance services conducted entirely indoors.
Research and development laboratories and institutions.
Residential uses above the ground floor level or at the rear of a lot.
Restaurants.
Retail sales.
Service establishments.
Telecommunications facilities.
Temporary buildings for and during construction only.
Theaters and auditoriums. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 291, 8-12-2003)
10-7A-3: CONDITIONAL USES:
Automobile service stations.
Casinos.
Drive-up windows at permitted use establishments.
Manufacturing.
"Schools" as defined in subsection 10-1-5B of this title.
Wholesale sales. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7A-4: PROHIBITED USES:
Manufactured home and travel trailer sales and service.
Salvage yards.
Storage, other than as an accessory use to a permitted use on a lot. (Ord. 253,
12-1-1998)
10-7A-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
"Building height" as defined in this title shall not exceed thirty six feet
(36'). (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7A-6: LOT AREA AND WIDTH:
No minimum lot area or width is prescribed. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7A-7: SETBACKS:
No minimum setbacks are required in this district. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7A-8: LOT COVERAGE:
No maximum lot coverage is prescribed in this district. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7A-9: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
   A.   Nonresidential Uses: No off street parking shall be required for
nonresidential uses in this district.
   B.   Residential Uses: Off street parking for residential uses shall be
provided in accordance with chapter 13 of this title.
   C.   Off Street Loading: Off street loading shall be provided in accordance
with chapter 13 of this title. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7A-10: SIGN REGULATIONS:
All signs must conform with chapter 15 of this title. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998;
amd. 2000 Code)
10-7A-11: LANDSCAPING REGULATIONS:
All required landscaping must conform to the adopted landscaping regulations
for this district. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
ARTICLE B. NHB NEIGHBORHOOD HIGHWAY BUSINESS DISTRICT
SECTION:
10-7B-1: Purpose
10-7B-2: Permitted Uses
10-7B-3: Conditional Uses
10-7B-4: Prohibited Uses
10-7B-5: Building Height
10-7B-6: Lot Area And Width
10-7B-7: Setbacks
10-7B-8: Lot Coverage
10-7B-9: Off Street Parking And Loading
10-7B-10: Sign Regulations
10-7B-11: Landscaping Regulations
10-7B-1: PURPOSE:
The intent of the neighborhood highway business district (NHB), is to
accommodate business uses that require more space than is normally available in
the central business district, or whose operations require convenient highway
access, and which may serve the traveling public as well as residents. (Ord.
253, 12-1-1998; amd. 2000 Code)
10-7B-2: PERMITTED USES:
The following uses shall be permitted:
Accessory uses customary to the permitted uses on a lot.
Automobile parking lots and garages.
Automobile service stations.
Bars and cocktail lounges.
Bus and other passenger transportation terminals.
Educational establishments and schools.
Financial institutions.
Greenhouses and nurseries.
Hotels and motels.
Medical and veterinary clinics.
Meeting and lodge halls.
Museums, libraries, galleries.
Offices, private and public.
Recreation and amusement establishments and facilities.
Repair and maintenance services.
Research and development laboratories and institutions.
Residential uses above the ground floor level or at the rear of a lot.
Restaurants.
Retail sales.
Service establishments.
Telecommunications facilities.
Temporary buildings for and during construction only.
Theaters and auditoriums. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 291, 8-12-2003)
10-7B-3: CONDITIONAL USES:
Adult oriented businesses.
A.   Classification:
      Adult arcades;
      Adult bookstore.
      Adult cabarets.
      Adult motels.
      Adult motion picture theaters.
      Adult theaters.
      Escort agencies.
      Nude model studios.
      Sexual encounter centers.
B.   Requirements For An Adult Oriented Business Permit:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an adult oriented
business without first obtaining a conditional use permit pursuant to chapter
11 of this title for a neighborhood highway business district as set forth in
this article and an adult oriented business operator's license ("operator's
license") issued by the town pursuant to sections
3-10-1 and
3-10-3 of this code.
      2.   Such conditional use permit is subject to the following:
   a. Obtainment of a valid adult oriented business operator's license issued
by the Manhattan police department;
   b. Any person who operates an adult oriented business and has employees who
work and/or perform services on the premises of the adult oriented business
must at all times keep a current list of all employees that will be provided to
the Manhattan police department as described herein; and
   c. Any person employed with an adult oriented business must ensure their
presence on a list of all employees to be provided to the Manhattan police
department as described herein.
      3.   It shall be a defense to subsections B2b and B2c of this section if
the employment is of limited duration and for the sole purpose of repair and/or
maintenance of machinery, equipment or the premises.
      4.   Any person violating a provision of this subsection B for which
another penalty has not been provided shall, upon conviction thereof, be
punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code.
Casinos.
Manufacturing, other than as an accessory use to a permitted use on a lot.
Miniwarehouse/self-storage units.
Planned unit developments. (See chapter 10 of this title.)
Wholesale sales. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 295, 11-10-2003; Ord. 05-004,
9-13-2005; Ord. 07-002, 2-13-2007; Ord. 13-002, 10-10-2013; Ord. 14-001, 5-14-
2014)
10-7B-4: PROHIBITED USES:
Residential uses at the ground floor level abutting a public street.
Salvage yards.
Storage, other than as an accessory use to a permitted use on a lot or
miniwarehouse/self-storage units as a conditionally approved use. (Ord. 253,
12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 13-002, 10-10-2013; Ord. 14-001, 5-14-2014)
10-7B-5: BUILDING HEIGHT:
"Building height" as defined in this title shall not exceed thirty six feet
(36'). (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7B-6: LOT AREA AND WIDTH:
No minimum lot area or width is prescribed. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7B-7: SETBACKS:
   A.   Front: A front yard setback of at least twenty five feet (25') shall be
provided on all public street and highway frontages.
   B.   Side: No minimum side yard setback is prescribed in this district.
   C.   Rear: A minimum setback of ten feet (10') from the rear property line
shall be required. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7B-8: LOT COVERAGE:
No maximum lot coverage is prescribed in this district. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7B-9: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
Off street parking and loading shall be provided in accordance with chapter 13
of this title. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7B-10: SIGN REGULATIONS:
All signs must conform with chapter 15 of this title. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998;
amd. 2000 Code)
10-7B-11: LANDSCAPING REGULATIONS:
   A.   Landscape Zone Required: A landscape zone of not less than ten feet
(10') shall be provided along the entire frontage abutting public streets and
highways, other than that frontage utilized for vehicular and pedestrian
ingress and egress.
   B.   Planting: All landscape zones shall be planted in accordance with the
landscape regulations applicable to this district. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
ARTICLE C. L-1 LIGHT INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT
SECTION:
10-7C-1: Purpose
10-7C-2: Permitted Uses
10-7C-3: Conditional Uses
10-7C-4: Prohibited Uses
10-7C-5: Building Height
10-7C-6: Lot Area And Width
10-7C-7: Yards
10-7C-8: Off Street Parking And Loading
10-7C-9: Sign Regulations
10-7C-1: PURPOSE:
The intent of the light industrial district, L-1, is to provide for high
quality settings and facilities for the development of a variety of compatible
employment opportunities. These areas should be developed so as to recognize
the impact on surrounding or adjacent development and contribute to the overall
image of the community. Compatibility with adjacent land uses and zoning is
required.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 22-002, 6-9-2022)
10-7C-2: PERMITTED USES:
In an L-1 district, no building or land shall be used and no building or
structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged, which is arranged, intended or
designed for other than one of the uses listed below:
Accessory uses.
Building contractors establishments.
Building materials sales.
Cabinet shops.
Electric utility facilities.
Enclosed warehousing.
Grain elevators.
Greenhouses and nurseries.
Machine shops and welding shops.
Manufacturing of light consumer goods (i.e., electronic equipment, appliances,
furniture, beverages).
Medical and veterinary clinics.
Miniwarehouse/self-storage units:
   A.   Lot area with width: Two (2) acres with a minimum width of one hundred
fifty feet (150').
   B.   Lot coverage: Minimum aisle width between buildings shall be twenty six
feet (26').
   C.   All paving providing access to the lot and aisles shall be asphalt.
   D.   The storage facilities complex shall be surrounded by a chainlink fence
approximately eight feet (8') in height.
   E.   Outdoor storage of automobiles, boats and recreation vehicles is
permitted if they are within the fenced area. Outdoor exterior storage shall be
limited to ten percent (10%) of the indoor storage area. Parked vehicles shall
not interfere with traffic movement through the complex and shall meet the
minimum setbacks of the district.
   F.   One office and dwelling unit is permitted as an accessory use to
provide for a full time caretaker.
Outside storage if accessory to permitted use and if screened from street and
surrounding properties by solid fence or dense plantings at least six feet (6')
high.
Paint shops.
Physical therapy centers.
Professional offices.
Repair and service establishments for light consumer goods (i.e., automobiles,
appliances, furniture).
Research and development laboratories.
Restaurants.
Sign shops.
Signs.
Telecommunications facilities.
Temporary buildings for and during construction, only.
Vehicle and boat sales.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 291, 8-12-2003; Ord. 13-002, 10-10-2013; Ord.
14-001, 5-14-2014; Ord. 22-002, 6-9-2022)
10-7C-3: CONDITIONAL USES:
In the L-1 district, the following uses may be permitted provided they are
reviewed and approved as required in chapter 11 of this title:
   Caretaker facilities.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 22-002, 6-9-2022)
10-7C-4: PROHIBITED USES:
All uses of land, buildings and structures and industrial processes that are
noxious or injurious by reason of production or emission of dust, smoke or
refuse matter, odor, gas fumes, noise, vibration or substances or conditions.
Before issuing a zoning permit, the town council may request that the board of
adjustment review the proposed use to determine whether the use is noxious or
injurious. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7C-5: BUILDING HEIGHT 1 :
No building shall exceed thirty six feet (36') in height or more than two (2)
stories in height, except for one or more of the following uses or exceptions:
chimneys, fire towers, tanks, water towers, spires, church steeples, radio and
television towers or necessary mechanical appurtenances may be erected to
exceed the maximum height limitations if approved by the board of adjustment.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 14-001, 5-14-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. See definition of "building height" in subsection 10-1-5B of this title.
10-7C-6: LOT AREA AND WIDTH:
Lot area for the L-1 district shall not be less than ten thousand (10,000)
square feet with a minimum width of fifty feet (50'). (Ord. 14-001, 5-14-2014)
10-7C-7: YARDS:
Every lot shall have the following minimum yards:
   A.   Front Yard: Front yard, twenty feet (20'). (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
   B.   Rear Yard: Rear yard, ten feet (10') clear area. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998;
amd. Ord. 14-001, 5-14-2014)
   C.   Side Yard: Side yard, five feet (5').
   D.   Lots Facing Or Adjacent To Another District: When a lot is adjacent or
faces upon another district, the yards shall meet the requirements of the
adjoining district, and buildings shall be screened with a decorative fence or
plantings. When a lot abuts another street or alley side or the rear, a yard of
at least fifteen feet (15') shall be provided on the street or alley side with
landscaping similar to that found in the adjoining district. (Ord. 14-001, 5-
14-2014)
10-7C-8: OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING:
Off street parking and loading space shall be provided in accordance with
chapter 13 of this title. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-7C-9: SIGN REGULATIONS:
All signs must conform with chapter 15 of this title. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998;
amd. 2000 Code)
CHAPTER 8
P-O PARKS AND OPEN SPACE DISTRICT
SECTION:
10-8-1: Purpose
10-8-2: Permitted Uses
10-8-3: Conditional Uses
10-8-4: Lot Area
10-8-5: Building Height
10-8-6: Floor Area
10-8-7: Lot Frontage
10-8-8: Yards
10-8-9: Accessory Buildings And Structures
10-8-1: PURPOSE:
The intent of the parks and open space district, P-O, is to provide for parks
and play areas as well as public and quasi- public uses. Some may be permitted
in other districts, but for the larger uses will be designated P-O. (Ord. 253,
12-1-1998)
10-8-2: PERMITTED USES:
In a P-O district, no building or land shall be used and no building or
structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged, which is arranged or intended
or designed for other than one of the uses listed below:
Accessory uses.
Museums, cultural facilities and libraries.
Parks, playgrounds, ball fields and publicly owned open space.
Public buildings, i.e., fire and police stations, etc.
Schools (public and quasi-public). (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-8-3: CONDITIONAL USES:
In a P-O district, the following uses may be permitted, provided they are
reviewed and approved as required in chapter 11 of this title.
Ambulance service.
Golf courses.
Hospitals and nursing homes. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-8-4: LOT AREA:
There shall be no minimum lot area requirements. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-8-5: BUILDING HEIGHT 1 :
No building shall exceed thirty six feet (36') in height or more than two (2)
stories in height, except for one or more of the following uses or exceptions:
chimneys, fire towers, tanks, water towers, spires, church steeples, radio and
television towers or necessary mechanical appurtenances may be erected to
exceed the maximum height limitations if approved by the board of adjustment.
(Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. Ord. 14-001, 5-14-2014)
 
Notes
1 1. See definition of "building height" in section 10-1-5 of this title.
10-8-6: FLOOR AREA:
There shall be no minimum floor area requirements. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-8-7: LOT FRONTAGE:
There shall be no minimum lot frontage requirements. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-8-8: YARDS:
All buildings and improvements must observe the minimum setback as required by
the adjoining district. There shall be no minimum setback requirements for
buildings and improvements that do not adjoin another district. (Ord. 253, 12-
1-1998)
10-8-9: ACCESSORY BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES:
By approval of the town council, detached buildings not used for the parks and
open space purposes, may be approved for abutment on alleys only. (Ord. 253,
12-1-1998)
CHAPTER 9
MANUFACTURED HOME PARKS
SECTION:
10-9-1: Purpose
10-9-2: Definitions
10-9-3: Applicability
10-9-4: Permitted Uses
10-9-5: Supplemental Regulations
10-9-6: Permits
10-9-7: Licenses
10-9-8: Design Standards
10-9-9: Approval As Conditional Use
10-9-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for manufactured home park
development at appropriate locations and to establish standards for development
in order to integrate manufactured homes into an area without adversely
affecting surrounding properties and to provide safeguards for residents of
manufactured homes. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
Manufactured home parks are permitted as a conditional use in the R-3 medium
density residential district and as part of a planned unit development (PUD).
Manufactured home parks are not permitted in any other district. (Ord. 14-001,
5-14-2014)
10-9-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, definitions in section
10-1-5 of this title apply, except for the following terms:
DENSITY: The number of manufactured home units per acre.
LOT: The total area reserved within a manufactured home park for the placement
of one manufactured home and the exclusive use of its occupants.
RECREATIONAL AREA: An area including open space, playgrounds, buildings and
apparatus designed for recreational activities set aside for the use of the
manufactured home park residents.
SITE: The entire gross area of the manufactured home park. (Ord. 253, 12-1-
1998)
10-9-3: APPLICABILITY:
This chapter shall govern all manufactured homes which are moved into any
manufactured home park within the zoning jurisdiction of the town. The
provisions of this chapter shall also apply to all manufactured homes which
have remained unoccupied for a period of ninety (90) consecutive days. (Ord.
253, 12-1-1998)
10-9-4: PERMITTED USES:
"Manufactured homes" as defined in section
10-1-5 of this title.
Accessory buildings and uses customarily incidental thereto. No part of any
manufactured home park shall be used for nonresidential purposes, except such
uses that are required for direct servicing and well being of park residents
and for management and maintenance of the park. Nothing in this chapter shall
be deemed as prohibiting the sale of a manufactured home located on a
manufactured home stand and connected to the pertinent utilities.
Signs as follows:
   A.   One entry and one exit sign at each access drive onto a public right of
way. In no case shall a sign be larger than two (2) square feet of surface
area, nor shall it have flashing lights or moving parts.
   B.   One identification sign on each major street frontage, approved in
conjunction with the final site plan for the manufactured home park. In no case
shall such a sign be larger than forty (40) square feet in surface area, nor
stand higher than the height limitation within the district of the proposed
location of the manufactured home park. Such signs shall have no flashing
lights or moving parts. Such signs shall be no closer to a public right of way
line than twenty feet (20'). (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-9-5: SUPPLEMENTAL REGULATIONS:
The regulations in this Chapter shall not be interpreted so as to supersede or
amend any State or Federal regulation pertaining to manufactured home park
development. In cases of conflict between the provisions of applicable
regulations, the more restrictive shall apply. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998; amd. 2000
Code)
10-9-6: PERMITS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, alter, or extend any
manufactured home park unless the necessary valid permits have been issued by
agencies of the State and Town. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-9-7: LICENSES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any manufactured home park
unless said person holds a valid license issued by the Town. (Ord. 253, 12-1-
1998)
10-9-8: DESIGN STANDARDS:
Any person desiring to establish or enlarge a manufactured home park shall meet
or exceed the following design standards:
   A.   Ambient Conditions: The manufactured home park site shall not be
exposed to smoke, dust, noise, odors, or other adverse influences which might
create damage to property or bring harm to occupants of the park.
   B.   Site Size: Minimum size for a manufactured home park shall be five (5)
acres with a minimum of twenty five (25) lots.
   C.   Density: The maximum density of a manufactured home park shall be
regulated by separation requirements, lot area requirements, and recreation
area requirements as set forth in this Title. In no case shall the density of a
manufactured home park exceed the density of the district in which it is
located.
   D.   Site Coverage: Maximum manufactured home lot coverage shall not exceed
thirty three percent (33%). Coverage shall mean any manmade apparatus.
   E.   Lot Size: Minimum lot area shall be six thousand (6,000) square feet
with no less than sixty feet (60') of lot width where both Municipal or
community water and sanitary sewer systems are available. Where community
systems are not available, lot size will be determined by soil and water
conditions and approved by the State Board of Health.
   F.   Exterior Setbacks: All manufactured homes and accessory buildings shall
be set back not less than twenty feet (20') from all property lines except
front property lines and street property lines. Front and street setbacks shall
be the same as the front yard requirements of the district in which the
manufactured home park is to be located.
   G.   Interior Setbacks: Within the manufactured home park, manufactured
homes shall be located a minimum of twenty five feet (25') apart side to side,
a minimum of fifteen feet (15') apart rear to rear, or end to end, or side to
rear, a minimum of fifteen feet (15') from any interior roadway and twenty five
feet (25') from any public roadway. Any accessory structure such as attached
awnings, carports, etc., shall, for the purpose of this Chapter, be considered
a part of the manufactured home.
   H.   Height: Maximum height for any structure within a manufactured home
park shall be that of the district in which the park is to be located.
   I.   Unit Size: The minimum square footage of a manufactured home unit
allowable under this Title shall be eight hundred (800) square feet, with a
minimum width of fourteen feet (14').
   J.   Streets: All manufactured home parks shall be provided with safe and
convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets and throughout the
manufactured home park.
      1.   Exterior Access: All manufactured home parks shall have direct
access to a dedicated collector street.
      2.   Interior Circulation: Streets within the manufactured home park
should be of adequate width to accommodate any contemplated parking and
expected traffic load but, in all cases, shall meet at least the following
minimum requirements:
         a.   Streets with parallel parking on two (2) sides: forty feet (40')
wide, curb face to curb face.
         b.   Streets with parallel parking on one side: thirty two feet (32')
wide, curb face to curb face.
         c.   Streets with no parallel parking: twenty four feet (24') wide,
curb face to curb face.
         d.   All dead-end streets shall be limited to a maximum length of five
hundred feet (500') and shall be provided with a cul-de-sac of at least one
hundred feet (100') in diameter.
         e.   Minimum access width to each manufactured home stand shall be
sixteen feet (16').
   K.   Parking: Off-street parking spaces shall be provided in convenient
locations and in sufficient numbers to meet the needs of the occupants of the
manufactured home park and their guests. However, in no case shall the number
of off-street parking spaces be less than two (2) spaces per lot, plus an
additional space for each four (4) lots. The minimum size of each parking space
shall be ten feet in width by twenty feet in length (10' x 20').
   L.   Sidewalks: Concrete sidewalks with a minimum width of five feet (5')
shall be provided along all exterior streets.
   M.   Recreational Area: A minimum of eleven percent (11%) of the gross site
area shall be reserved for park and recreational development. Such areas shall
be central in location and shall be furnished with trees, grass, benches,
recreational equipment, and other facilities for use by park residents. The
design and furnishings of the recreational area shall be subject to approval by
the Planning Board as part of the zoning application review.
   N.   Perimeter Planting Strip: A planting strip of not less than twenty feet
(20') in width shall be provided along the perimeter of the manufactured home
park. The planting strip shall be developed with a mixture of hardy deciduous
and coniferous plant material, grass or ground cover, and maintained thereafter
in a neat and orderly manner.
   O.   Utilities:
      1.   All utilities, including connections provided to individual lots,
shall meet the requirements of the Town.
      2.   All electric, telephone, gas and other lines within the manufactured
home park shall be underground.
      3.   When exterior television antenna installation is necessary, a master
antenna shall be installed and extended to individual stands by underground
lines. Such master antenna shall be so placed as not to be a nuisance to park
residents or surrounding properties. Cable television, when used, shall have
the cable located underground.
   P.   Trash And Garbage: Facilities for the storage and disposal of trash and
garbage in a sanitary and lawful manner shall be provided in each manufactured
home park.
   Q.   Lighting: Street and yard lights, attached to standards approved by the
Planning Board, shall be provided in sufficient number and intensity to permit
the safe movement of vehicles and pedestrians at night, and shall be located so
as to prevent glare on surrounding properties and public rights of way.
   R.   Fire Protection: The water supply system serving the manufactured home
park shall comply with the rules and regulations of the local fire protection
authority, or the system shall meet the standards for adequate fire protection
established by the National Fire Protection Association, whichever is more
stringent. All fire protection systems are subject to approval by the Town Fire
Chief. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-9-9: APPROVAL AS CONDITIONAL USE:
Approval of a manufactured home park shall be obtained through the conditional
use permit procedure as specified in Chapter 11 of this Title. (Ord. 253, 12-1-
1998)
CHAPTER 10
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENTS
SECTION:
10-10-1: Purpose
10-10-2: Special Conditions
10-10-3: Review And Approval Procedures; Criteria
10-10-4: Duration Of Approval
10-10-5: Review Criteria
10-10-6: Appeals
10-10-7: Responsibility For Impact Mitigation
10-10-1: PURPOSE:
Through the use of the planned unit development (PUD), the Town intends to
promote flexibility and innovation in the development of land and the design of
development projects within the zoning jurisdiction of the Town. The purpose of
this Chapter is to promote the following community objectives:
   A.   To ensure that growth and development is in accordance with the Town's
adopted Master Plan;
   B.   To promote logical development patterns of residential, commercial,
office, industrial and public uses;
   C.   To improve the design, quality and character of new development;
   D.   To ensure that new development will maintain and enhance the identity
and historical development patterns of the Town, and preserve historic
resources where feasible;
   E.   To minimize adverse environmental impacts of new development and to
protect special urban and natural features;
   F.   To protect existing neighborhoods from the harmful encroachment of
incompatible development;
   G.   To ensure adequate provision of public services such as water, sewer,
electricity, open space and public parks and police and fire protection;
   H.   To avoid inappropriate development of lands and to provide adequate
drainage and reduction of flood damage; and
   I.   To protect the public health, safety and welfare. (Ord. 253, 12-1-1998)
10-10-2: SPECIAL CONDITIONS:
   A.   Land Uses: An applicant may request approval of a planned unit
development having one or more principal uses or structures on a single parcel
of ground or contiguous parcels of ground. Any use or combination of uses may
be allowed in a planned unit development, provided such uses are consistent
with the Town's Master Plan and with the provisions of Section
10-10-1 of this Chapter. It is not intended that this Chapter apply to zone
change requests for single parcels where the proposed use and site plan are
fully consistent with the district regulations of this Title.
