and content and its supplements are met, to assure that it conforms to the
conditions of approval for preliminary plat. Any significant change may require
the holding of a public hearing for review.
   A.   Examination By Land Surveyor: The town council shall require that final
subdivision plats be reviewed for errors and omissions in calculation or
drafting by an examining land surveyor before recording with the Gallatin
County clerk and recorder. When the survey data shown on the plat meets the
conditions set forth by the MSPA and the Montana uniform standards for
monumentation and final subdivision plats, the examining land surveyor shall so
certify on the plat. No land surveyor having a financial or personal interest
in a plat shall act as an examining land surveyor regarding that plat.
   B.   Certificate Of Abstract: A certificate of abstract indicating all
delinquent taxes, trustees, lien holders, owners of record, claimants of
record, rights of way and easements must be provided with the preliminary plat.
The certificate of abstract must be dated not more than one year before the
application is submitted. The town may provide for the review of the abstract
or certificate of title of the land in question by the town attorney.
   C.   Guarantee Of Public Improvements: As a condition of the approval of the
final plat, the subdivider shall have installed all required improvements or
shall enter into a subdivision improvements agreement guaranteeing the
construction and installation of all such improvements. If the completion of
the subdivision improvements is to be deferred, then the projected cost of
completing the improvements and the financing arrangements must be specified.
The city engineer or consulting engineer designated by the town council shall
review and certify all public improvements have been installed in conformance
with the plans and specifications.
   D.   Supporting Documentation: The subdivider must disclose information on
the ownership of water rights, mineral rights, and development rights, if
separate from the ownership of the property to be subdivided. The subdivider is
also required to provide documentation on utility easements and legal access.
Copies of easements, right of way records or other documentation must be
submitted with the application to verify utility easements and legal access.
   E.   Approval, Or Denial: Approval, or denial may be granted for the entire
development. However, final plat approval may be granted to requested phases as
they are submitted. Final plat approval for each subsequent phase will be
contingent upon completion and acceptance by the town of all improvements in
each preceding phase.
   F.   Noxious Weed MOU: Prior to final plat approval, a memorandum of
understanding shall be entered into by the weed control district and the
developer. The memorandum of understanding shall be signed by the district and
the developer prior to final plat approval, and a copy of the signed document
shall be submitted to the planning department with the application for final
plat approval. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-3-7-4: APPROVAL; DISAPPROVAL:
   A.   Action By Town Council: The town council shall approve or disapprove
the final plat within forty-five (45) days of its presentation to the planning
board. The subdivision administrator and the planning board shall examine the
final subdivision plat and shall recommend approval only when it conforms to
the conditions of approval set forth on the preliminary plat and to the terms
of the MSPA and this title.
   B.   Basis For Decision: The town council shall examine every final
subdivision plat and shall approve it when, and only when, it conforms to the
conditions of approval set forth for the preliminary plat and to the terms of
the MSPA and this title.
   C.   Approval Certified; Disapproval, Reasons Stated: Approval shall be
certified by the town on the face of the final plat. If the final plat is
disapproved, the reasons for disapproval shall be stated in the records of the
town and noted on the final plat.
   D.   Return Of Disapproved Final Plat; Resubmittal: The final plat, along
with the reasons for disapproval, shall be returned to the subdivider within
ten (10) days of the action. The town will provide a written statement on the
reasons, evidence that justifies the denial or conditional approval, and
information describing the appeal process for the denial to the applicant. The
applicant may then make necessary corrections and resubmit the final plat for
approval.
   E.   Inaccurate Information; Withdrawal of Approval: The town council may
withdraw approval of a plat if it determines that information provided by the
subdivider, and upon which such decision was based, is inaccurate. (Ord. 24-
007, 12-11-2024)
11-3-7-5: FILING:
Within thirty (30) days of the approval of the final plat, the subdivider shall
submit for filing the approved final plat and supplementary documents with the
Gallatin County clerk and recorder. After approval, the plats may not be
altered in any manner. The Gallatin County clerk and recorder shall refuse to
accept any plat for record that fails to have approval in proper form or that
has been altered, and shall file the approved plat only if it is accompanied by
the documents specified in uniform standards for final subdivision plats. (Ord.
24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-3-7-6: CORRECTING OR AMENDING RECORDED FINAL PLATS:
   A.   Correcting Filed Recorded Plats: Corrections of drafting or surveying
errors that, in the town's opinion, will not materially alter the plat, its
land division, or the improvements to less than the standards contained herein,
may be made by the submission of a corrected final plat for the town's
approval. The plat shall be entitled "Corrected Plat of the (name of
subdivision) Subdivision" and the reason for the correction shall be stated on
the face of the plat.
   B.   Amending Final Plats:
      1.   Material Alterations:
         a.   Filing Amended Plat: Changes that materially alter the final plat
or any portion thereof or its land divisions or improvements shall be made by
the filing of an amended plat showing all alterations. Within a platted
subdivision, any division of lots which results in an increase in the number of
lots, or which redesigns or rearranges six (6) or more lots, must be reviewed
and approved by the town and an amended plat must be filed with the Gallatin
County clerk and recorder.
         b.   Procedures: The amended plat shall be subject to procedures for
major or minor subdivision, as is appropriate. The town may not approve an
amendment which will place the plat in nonconformance with the standards
contained, the MSPA, local zoning regulations, floodplain regulations, or any
other relevant regulation herein unless a public hearing is held on the plat
and a written variance from the standards is issued pursuant to section
11-10-2  of this title.
         c.   Consent Of Property Owners: The town council may not approve an
amendment unless it is consented to, in writing, by all affected property
owners.
         d.   Final Amended Plat Submitted: The final amended plat submitted
for approval shall comply with the Montana uniform standards for final
subdivision plats (ARM 8.94.3003) with the exception that the title shall
include the word "Amended", or "Amended Plat of the (name) Subdivision", or "
(name) Subdivision Amended".
      2.   Exemption From Amended Plat Review: Amended subdivision plats that
show the relocation of common boundaries and the aggregation of lots within
platted subdivisions where five (5) or fewer of the original lots are affected
within a platted subdivision filed with the Gallatin County clerk and recorder
are exempt from approval as subdivisions. An amended plat must be prepared
following the requirements of the Montana uniform standards for final
subdivision plats (ARM 8.94.3003) except that in place of the town's approval,
the landowner certifies that the approval of the town is not required pursuant
to MCA 76-3-207(2). (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-3-8: RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS; APPROVAL, CONTENT AND ENFORCEMENT BY GOVERNING
BODY:
   A.   Identification Of Covenants On Plat: The governing body may require
that some or all restrictive covenants governing the use of land within the
subdivision, whether proposed by the subdivider or required by the governing
body, be set forth in a separate heading identifying them as plat approval
covenants, and indicating: "These covenant(s) may not be repealed or amended
without prior written consent of the Town of Manhattan."
   B.   Required Language Under Certain Conditions: The governing body may
require that all restrictive covenants it has required as a condition of plat
approval contain the following language: "The Town of Manhattan is a party to
this restrictive covenant and may enforce its terms."
   C.   Common Property Deeded To Property Owners' Association:
      1.   Provisions Of Covenants And Bylaws: If common property is to be
deeded to a property owners' association, the covenants and bylaws which govern
the association must, at a minimum, provide for the:
         a.   Formation of a property owners' association concurrently with the
filing of the final subdivision plat. articles of incorporation shall be filed
with the secretary of state's office;
         b.   Mandatory membership for each property owner. Purchasers of
property may also be required to sign a waiver of right to protest the
formation of a maintenance district to maintain improvements;
         c.   Perpetual reservation of the common property when required under
section MCA 76-3-621(8)(a);
         d.   Payment of liability insurance premiums, local taxes, and the
cost of maintaining recreational or other facilities;
         e.   Placement of liens on the property of lot owners who are
delinquent in the payment of association fees and assessments;
         f.   Adjustment of assessments to meet changing needs;
         g.   Means of enforcing the covenants, and of receiving and processing
complaints;
         h.   Transition of control of the association from the declarant to
the homeowners;
         i.   Dissolution of the association and modification of the covenants
and restrictions after obtaining the governing body's approval of the change;
and
         j.   Regular maintenance of roads, parks, buildings, drainage
facilities, and other facilities controlled by the association.
      2.   Permanent Care And Maintenance Of Commonly Owned Open Spaces,
Facilities, Streets, etc.: The developer shall submit a legal instrument
setting forth a plan providing for the permanent care and maintenance of
commonly owned open spaces, recreational areas, facilities, private streets,
public and private wells and associated infrastructure, and parking lots. If
the property owners' association fails to install or maintain improvements
according to approved plans, the town may, at its option, complete construction
of improvements and/or maintain improvements. The town's representative,
contractors and engineers shall have the right to enter upon the property and
perform such work, and the property owners' association shall permit and secure
any additional permission required to enable them to do so. The town shall bill
the property owners' association for any costs associated with the installation
or maintenance of improvements.
   D.   Failure To Maintain Common Areas; Notice And Hearing: In the event the
organization or any successor organization established to own and maintain
commonly owned open spaces, recreational areas, facilities, private streets,
and parking lots, shall at any time fail to maintain the common areas or
facilities in reasonable order and condition in accordance with the approved
plan, the town council may cause written notice to be served upon such
organization or upon the owners of property in the development.
      1.   The written notice shall set forth the way the common areas or
facilities have failed to be maintained in reasonable condition. In addition,
the notice shall include the demand that the deficiencies noted be cured within
thirty (30) days thereafter and shall state the date and place of a hearing to
be held within fourteen (14) days of the notice. At the time of hearing, the
town council may modify the terms of the original notice as to deficiencies and
may extend the time within which the same may be cured.
      2.   If the deficiencies set forth in the original notice or
modifications are not cured within the time set, the town may enter upon such
common facilities and maintain the same for a period of one year, to preserve
the taxable values of properties within the development and to prevent the
common facilities from becoming a public nuisance.
      3.   Such entry and maintenance shall not vest in the public any right to
use the common facilities not dedicated to public use. Before the one-year
period expires, the council shall, upon its own initiative or upon written
request of the organization theretofore responsible for maintenance, call a
public hearing and give notice of such hearing to the organization responsible
for maintenance or the property owners of the development. At the hearing, the
organization responsible for maintenance and/or the residents of the
development may show cause why maintenance by the town should not be continued
for a succeeding year. If the town council determines that it is not necessary
for the town to continue such maintenance, the town shall cease such
maintenance at the time established by the town council. Otherwise, the town
shall continue maintenance for the next succeeding year subject to a similar
hearing and determination at the end of each year thereafter.
      4.   The cost of maintenance by the town shall be a lien against the
common facilities of the development and the private properties within the
development. The town council shall have the right to make assessments against
properties, public or private, in the development on the same basis that the
organization responsible for maintenance of the facilities could make such
assessments. Any unpaid assessment shall be a lien against the properties
responsible for the same, enforceable the same as a mortgage against such
property. The town may further foreclose its lien on the common facility or
private property by certifying the same to the county treasurer for collection
as in the case of collection of general property taxes.
      5.   Should the property owners' association request that the town assume
permanent responsibility for maintenance of facilities, all facilities shall be
brought to town standards prior to the town assuming responsibility. The
assumption of responsibility must be by action of the town council and all
costs to bring facilities to town standards shall be the responsibility of the
property owners' association. The town may create special financing mechanisms
so that those properties within the area affected by the property owners'
association continue to bear the costs of maintenance. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-
2024)
11-3-9: PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS AGREEMENT; GUARANTY:
As a condition of approval of the final plat, the subdivider must have
installed all required improvements or have entered into a subdivision
improvements agreement guaranteeing the construction, installation, and
maintenance of all required improvements. No construction or placement of
structures on the lots may occur until improvements related to public health
and safety, such as roads or firefighting facilities, have been installed and
engineering plans have been filed. A model subdivision improvements agreement
can be found on the town website or at town hall. The alternative methods of
guaranteeing public improvements, the procedures, and requirements for securing
an agreement, and suggested conditions for maintenance are set out in section
11-12-2. If the subdivider chooses to enter into a subdivision improvements
agreement, guaranteeing the public improvements through a bond or letter of
credit, three (3) bids for the cost of installation of the public improvements
shall be obtained by the subdivider. The amount of the guarantee shall be one
hundred fifty percent (150%) of the highest bid. The bond timeline shall run as
necessary to install all required improvements. The timeline for such bond
shall be reviewed and approved by the town council, town attorney, town
engineer, and other relevant agents as determined by the town council. As the
public improvements are installed, the subdivider shall provide a letter to the
governing body indicating such, and including a copy of the engineered plans.
The town engineer designated by the governing body shall review and certify all
public improvements have been installed in conformance with the plans and
specifications. Prior to the release of the guarantee, a copy of the plans,
stamped by the project surveyor or engineer in accordance with their licensing
provisions, shall be filed in the clerk and recorder's office with reference to
the final subdivision plat. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-3-10: AMENDING APPROVED PRELIMINARY PLATS BEFORE FINAL PLAT APPROVAL:
   A.   If the subdivider proposes to change the preliminary plat after the
preliminary plat approval but before the final plat approval, the subdivider
shall submit the proposed changes to the subdivision administrator for review.
      1.   Within five (5) working days of receiving the proposed changes, the
subdivision administrator shall determine whether the changes to the
preliminary plat are material.
      2.   If the subdivision administrator determines the changes are
material, the subdivision administrator shall require the subdivider to begin
the subdivision review process again, starting with the preapplication meeting,
and require payment of a new application fee.
      3.   If the subdivision administrator determines the changes are not
material, the subdivision administrator shall accept the changes and notify the
subdivider and the governing body of its decision.
   B.   The following changes, although not an exhaustive list, may be
considered material:
      1.   Configuration or number of lots;
      2.   Road layout;
      3.   Water and/or septic proposals;
      4.   Configuration of park land or open spaces;
      5.   Easement provisions;
      6.   Designated access; or
      7.   Change to conditions of approval.
   C.   A subdivider whose proposed changes to the preliminary plat have been
deemed material by the subdivision administrator may appeal the subdivision
administrator's decision to the governing body by written notice within ten
(10) working days. The subdivider may request a hearing, and may submit
additional evidence to show that the changes to the preliminary plat are not
material.
   D.   If the subdivider and subdivision administrator determine that a
condition of approval is illegal or impossible to comply with due to
circumstances outside the subdivider's control, economic hardship
notwithstanding, the condition may be reviewed by the governing body through a
properly noticed public hearing to determine if the condition may be waived or
amended. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
CHAPTER 4
MAJOR SUBDIVISIONS
SECTION:
11-4-1: Preliminary Plats
11-4-1-1: Application Forms
11-4-1-2: Review Fees
11-4-1-3: Submittal
11-4-1-4: Public Hearings
11-4-1-5: Review
11-4-1-6: Approval, Conditional Approval, Or Disapproval
11-4-1-7: Approval Period
11-4-1-8: Amended Applications
11-4-1-9: Final Plats
11-4-1-10: Restrictive Covenants; Approval, Content And Enforcement By
Governing Body
11-4-1-11: Public Improvements Agreement; Guaranty
11-4-1-12: Amending Approved Preliminary Plats Before Final Plat Approval
11-4-1: PRELIMINARY PLATS:
Subdivisions that qualify for major subdivision review are those divisions of
land containing six (6) or more lots, or subdivisions of five (5) or fewer lots
that do not otherwise qualify for review as first minor subdivisions under MCA
76-3-609 and this title.
The preapplication process and initial review process set forth in chapter 3,
"General Procedures", of this title apply to this chapter. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-
2024)
11-4-1-1: APPLICATION FORMS:
The preliminary plat application form must be completed and signed by the
owners of record and subdivider. The application can be found on the town's
website or at town hall. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-4-1-2: REVIEW FEES:
   A.   The required review fee as presented in the fee schedule shall be paid
when the application is submitted. All checks shall be payable to the town. All
review fees are nonrefundable.
   B.   If additional costs of review are incurred by the town after the
application is submitted, the town shall bill the applicant for the additional
review costs, including, but not limited to, all consultant costs and fees;
costs and expenses incurred in conducting all public hearings; costs and fees
for examining the application and its contents; and the costs of mailing,
posting and publication of all necessary notices. Consultants may consist of
architects, attorneys, planners, land surveyors, engineers, and title examiners
as may be necessary to process the application.
   C.   If the bill for costs and fees is not paid to the town within thirty
(30) days of billing, the amount due shall become a lien on the property that
is the subject of the review. If, after a lien is filed on the property and the
bill remains unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days, the town may, at its sole
discretion, bring an action to foreclose the lien in accordance with MCA 71-3-
124. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-4-1-3: SUBMITTAL:
   A.   Time Of Submittal; Number Of Copies: One (1) copy of the completed
application form and all required documents of the preliminary plat together
with the appropriate review fee and one (1) copy of the preliminary plat in
twenty-four inches by thirty-six-inch (24" x 36") format, and an electronic
copy of all documents shall be submitted to the town clerk in accordance with
any deadlines established for submittal. All preliminary plat submissions must
conform to the procedures and standards contained in this title.
   B.   Required Information: The subdivider shall submit to the governing
body, or to the agent or agency designated by the governing body, a subdivision
application addressing these topics and containing the following information,
materials, and supplements, all described in more detail in Manhattan major
subdivision plat application administrative materials "A" provided by the
subdivision administrator, as applicable:
      1.   A completed and signed subdivision application form;
      2.   The required review fee;
      3.   A preliminary plat at a scale sufficient to legibly represent the
required data on the plat. The plat size shall be twenty-four inches by thirty-
six inches (24" x 36"). The preliminary plat shall conform to the design
standards set forth in chapter 6 of this title and shall contain the
information required by this title:
         a.   Name and location of the subdivision, scale, bar, north arrow,
and date of preparation.
         b.   The exterior boundaries of the tract and the location of all
section corners or legal subdivision corners of sections pertinent to the
subdivision boundary. If available, the names of plats and certificate of
survey numbers previously recorded adjacent to the exterior boundaries of the
subdivision.
         c.   All lots and blocks, designated by numbers, and the dimensions
and area of each lot.
         d.   All streets, alleys, avenues, roads and highways, and the width
of the rights of way, grades, and curvature of each with existing and proposed
street names, and proposed locations of intersections or other access points
for any subdivision requiring access to arterial or collector highways.
         e.   The approximate location, boundaries, dimensions and areas of any
parks, schools, common grounds, or other grounds dedicated for public use.
         f.   Any existing and proposed utilities located on or adjacent to the
tract including:
            (1)   The approximate location, size and depth of water mains,
sanitary and storm sewers, and fire hydrants.
            (2)   The approximate location of nearest water mains and sewer
lines where none are located on or adjacent to the tract.
            (3)   The approximate location of gas, electric and telephone
lines, and streetlights.
         g.   The approximate location of existing buildings, structures,
railroads, and improvements.
         h.   The approximate location and identity of all existing easements
and rights of way of record and proposed public and private easements and
rights of way on or adjacent to the tract, including description of their width
and purpose.
         i.   The location and description of all existing agricultural water
user facilities on or adjacent to the tract;
      4.   A vicinity map;
      5.   A topographic map;
      6.   Adjacent Property Owners: A certified list of names and addresses of
owners of record and purchasers under contract for deed of adjacent property.
      7.   A grading and drainage plan A complete grading and drainage plan
with accurate dimensions, course, and elevations, showing the proposed grades
of streets, bridges, ditches, culverts, and other drainage improvements;
      8.   Engineering plans for all public and private improvements;
      9.   Overall development plan if development is in phases;
      10.   Abstract of title (or title report);
      11.   Lien holders' acknowledgment of subdivision;
      12.   Documentation of legal and physical access;
      13.   Documentation of existing easements, including those for
agricultural water user facilities;
      14.   Existing covenants and deed restrictions;
      15.   Existing water rights to include adequate and legal water rights;
      16.   Existing mineral rights;
      17.   Proposed road plans and profiles;
      18.   Encroachment permits from Montana department of transportation or
the local jurisdiction (if required);
      19.   Proposed easements;
      20.   Proposed disposition of water rights to include the proposed use of
the water and the proposed water supply source;
      21.   Proposed disposition of mineral rights;
      22.   Park land dedication calculations;
      23.   Environmental assessment and/or summary of probable impacts;
         a.   Required: An environmental assessment shall accompany the
preliminary plat unless the subdivider has been exempted. Section 11-12-1-1of
this title provides the format of and questions to be addressed in the
environmental assessment.
         b.   Waived By Planning Board: The requirement for preparing an
environmental assessment pursuant to MCA 76-3-504(1), shall be waived by the
planning board when:
            (1)   The proposed subdivision is totally within an area covered by
the master plan adopted pursuant to MCA 76-1-606;
            (2)   Municipal zoning regulations have been adopted pursuant to
MCA 76-2-301 through MCA 76-2-328; and
            (3)   A long-range development program of the public works projects
including a capital improvements plan, has been adopted pursuant to MCA 76-1-
601(4).
         c.   Statement: When such an exemption is granted, the planning board
shall prepare and certify a written statement of the reasons for granting the
exemption. A copy of this statement shall accompany the preliminary plat of the
subdivision when it is submitted for review.
      24.   Transportation impact analysis or transportation plan;
      25.   Fire risk rating analysis and fire prevention plan;
      26.   Weed management plan and revegetation plan;
      27.   Property owners' association documents, including draft articles of
incorporation, declaration, and bylaws;
      28.   Covenants And Restrictions: Drafts of any covenants and
restrictions to be included in deeds or contracts for sales:
      29.   FIRM or FEMA panel map and letter identifying floodplain status,
unless provided by the Town;
      30.   Required water and sanitation information;
      31.   A form of subdivision improvements agreement, if proposed;
      32.   Letter requesting a revocation of agricultural covenants;
      33.   Letter indicating locations of cultural or historic resources;
      34.   Variance request or approval (if required);
      35.   Rezoning application or approval (if required);
      36.   Flood hazard evaluation (if required);
      37.   Letter identifying and proposing mitigation for potential hazards
or other adverse impacts as identified in the preapplication meeting and not
covered by any of the above required materials; and
      38.   Such additional relevant and reasonable information as identified
by the subdivision administrator during the preapplication meeting that is
pertinent to the required elements of this section.
   C.   Overall Development Plan:
      1.   Phased Development: When a tract of land is to be subdivided in
phases, the subdivider must provide an overall development plan indicating
intent for the entire development.
      2.   Based On Overall Plan: The preliminary plat submission,
environmental assessment, and other supplements must include the entire
development and follow the procedures and standards contained in this title and
plat review will be based on the overall development plan.
   D.   Review And Approval Period: Within sixty (60) working days or eighty
(80) working days if the proposed subdivision contains fifty (50) or more lots,
the town council shall approve, conditionally approve, or deny the proposed
subdivision in accordance with this title, unless the subdivider and the
subdivision administrator agree to an extension or suspension of the review
period, or a subsequent public hearing is held pursuant to this title. A
subdivision application is deemed submitted for review, and the sixty (60)
working day period begins when the subdivision administrator notifies the
subdivider or the subdivider's agent in writing that the application contains
sufficient information to conduct the review.
   E.   Withdrawal Of Application: An application may be withdrawn, in writing
or statement given at a public hearing, by the owners of record and subdividers
at any time during the review process. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-4-1-4: PUBLIC HEARINGS:
   A.   Hearings: The planning board and the governing body shall each hold a
public hearing on the subdivision application when a hearing is required by
these regulations.
   B.   Notice:
      1.   Publication: The planning board and governing body shall give notice
of times, dates, and locations of the hearings by publication in a newspaper of
general circulation in the county not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the
date of the hearings.
      2.   Certified Mail: The subdivider, each property owner of record, and
each purchaser under contract for deed adjoining the land included in the plat
shall be notified of the hearing by certified mail not less than fifteen (15)
days prior to the date of the hearings.
      3.   Posted Notice: A notice of the public hearing shall be posted at
conspicuous places on the proposed site by the subdivider. The town shall place
notice in conspicuous places around town to inform the public.
   C.   Planning Board Hearing: After the subdivision application is deemed to
have all the required elements and contain detailed, supporting information
that is sufficient to allow for review, and the subdivision administrator has
prepared a staff report, the planning board shall schedule and hold a public
hearing on the subdivision application. At the public hearing the planning
board shall recommend approval, denial, or approval with conditions to the town
council. The planning board shall add any conditions to the application that is
necessary to mitigate impacts to the criteria contained in MCA 76-3-608.
   D.   Town Council Hearing: After the planning board makes its
recommendation, the governing body shall hold a public hearing on the
subdivision application. Comments and documents regarding the subdivision shall
be submitted to the subdivision administrator, rather than to the governing
body directly, to be forwarded to the governing body. At the public hearing the
town council shall approve, deny, or approve with conditions the application.
The town council shall add any conditions to the application that is necessary
to mitigate impacts to the criteria contained in MCA 76-3-608.
   E.   Presentation Of New Information:
      1.   The governing body shall determine whether public comments or other
information presented to the governing body at a hearing held pursuant to MCA
76-3-605 constitutes relevant, new information regarding a subdivision
application or a substantial change to the design of the subdivision that has
never been submitted as evidence or considered by either the governing body or
its agent or agency and has a substantial effect on the governing body's
consideration of the application.
      2.   If the governing body determines that the information presented to
the governing body constitutes the information described in subsection
11-4-1-4 -E-1, the governing body may:
         a.   approve, conditionally approve, or deny the proposed subdivision
without basing its decision on the new information if the governing body
determines that the new information is either irrelevant or not credible or the
change to the design of the subdivision does not substantially impact the
analysis of potentially significant adverse impacts; or
         b.   schedule or direct its agent or agency to schedule a subsequent
public hearing for consideration of only the new information, including a
substantial change to the design of the subdivision for purposes of considering
its findings of fact and conclusions and any proposed conditions of approval
considering the new information that the governing body will rely on in making
its decision on the proposed subdivision.
      3.   If a public hearing is held as provided in subsection
11-4-1-4 -E-2-b, the sixty (60) working-day review period required in MCA 76-3-
604(4) is suspended and the new hearing must be noticed and held within forty-
five (45) days of the governing body's determination to schedule a new hearing.
After the new hearing, the sixty (60) working-day time limit resumes at the
governing body's next scheduled public meeting for which proper notice for the
public hearing on the subdivision application can be provided. The governing
body may not consider any information regarding the subdivision application
that is presented after the hearing when making its decision to approve,
conditionally approve, or deny the proposed subdivision.
         a.   Notice of the time, date and location of the subsequent hearing
shall be given by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the
county not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the subsequent
hearing.
         b.   At least fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the subsequent
hearing, notice of the subsequent hearing shall be given by certified mail to
the subdivider, each adjoining landowner to the land included in the
preliminary plat, and each purchaser under contract for deed of property
immediately adjoining the land included in the preliminary plat.
         c.   The governing body shall require that notice be posted at a
conspicuous place on the site of the proposed subdivision. The town shall place
notice in conspicuous places around town to inform the public. (Ord. 24-007,
12-11-2024)
11-4-1-5: REVIEW:
   A.   The basis for the governing body's decision to approve, conditionally
approve, or deny a proposed subdivision is whether the subdivision application,
preliminary plat, applicable environmental assessment, public hearing, planning
board recommendations, or additional information demonstrates that development
of the proposed subdivision meets the requirements of this chapter. A governing
body may not deny approval of a proposed subdivision based solely on the
subdivision's impacts on educational services or based solely on parcels within
the subdivision having been designated as wildland-urban interface parcels
under 76-13-145.
      1.   The governing body shall issue written findings of fact that weigh
the criteria in subsection
11-4-1-5 -(2), as applicable.
      2.   A subdivision proposal must undergo review for the following primary
criteria:
         a.   Except when the governing body has established an exemption or
except as provided in MCA 76-3-509, 76-3-609(2) or (4), or 76-3-616, the
specific, documentable, and clearly defined impact on agriculture, agricultural
water user facilities, local services, the natural environment, wildlife,
wildlife habitat, and public health and safety, excluding any consideration of
whether the proposed subdivision will result in a loss of agricultural soils;
         b.   Compliance With:
            (1)   The survey requirements provided for in MCA;
            (2)   The local subdivision regulations provided; and
            (3)   The local subdivision review procedure provided for in this
part;
            (4)   The provision of easements within and to the proposed
subdivision for the location and installation of any planned utilities; and
            (5)   The provision of legal and physical access to each parcel
within the proposed subdivision and the required notation of that access on the
applicable plat and any instrument of transfer concerning the parcel.
   B.   The governing body may require the subdivider to design the proposed
subdivision to reasonably minimize potentially significant adverse impacts
identified through the review required under subsection
11-4-1-4 -E-2 but may not require a set-aside of land or monetary contribution
for the loss of agricultural soils. Pursuant to MCA 76-3-620, the governing
body shall issue written findings to justify the reasonable mitigation required
under this subsection (2).
   C.   In reviewing a proposed subdivision under section
11-4-1-4 -E-2 and when requiring mitigation under
11-4-1-4 -E-2, a governing body may not unreasonably restrict a landowner's
ability to develop land, but it is recognized that in some instances the
impacts of a proposed development may be deemed unmitigable and will preclude
approval of the subdivision.
      1.   When requiring mitigation under section
11-4-1-4 -E-2 and consistent with MCA 76-3-620, a governing body shall consult
with the subdivider and shall give due weight and consideration to the
expressed preference of the subdivider.
   D.   A governing body may conditionally approve or deny a proposed
subdivision as a result of the water and sanitation information provided
pursuant to MCA 76-3-622 or public comment received pursuant to MCA 76-3-604 on
the information provided pursuant to MCA 76-3-622 only if the conditional
approval or denial is based on existing subdivision, zoning, or other
regulations that the governing body has the authority to enforce.
   E.   A governing body may not require as a condition of subdivision approval
that a property owner waive a right to protest the creation of a special
improvement district or a rural improvement district for capital improvement
projects that does not identify the specific capital improvements for which
protest is being waived. A waiver of a right to protest may not be valid for a
period longer than twenty (20) years after the date that the final subdivision
plat is filed with the county clerk and recorder.
   F.   A governing body may not approve a proposed subdivision if any of the
features and improvements of the subdivision encroach onto adjoining private
property without a valid easement or other legally binding agreement or if the
well isolation zone of any proposed well to be drilled for the proposed
subdivision encroaches onto adjoining private property unless the owner of the
private property authorizes the encroachment. For the purposes of this section,
"well isolation zone" has the meaning provided in MCA 76-4-102.
   G.   If a federal or state governmental entity submits a written or oral
comment or an opinion regarding wildlife, wildlife habitat, or the natural
environment relating to a subdivision application for the purpose of assisting
a governing body's review, the comment or opinion may be included in the
governing body's written statement under MCA 76-3-620 only if the comment or
opinion provides scientific information or a published study that supports the
comment or opinion. A governmental entity that is or has been involved to
acquire or assist others in acquiring an interest in the real property
identified in the subdivision application shall disclose that the entity has
been involved in that effort prior to submitting a comment, an opinion, or
information as provided in this subsection.
   H.   Findings of fact by the governing body concerning whether the
development of the proposed subdivision meets the requirements of this chapter
must be based on the record. The governing body's findings of fact must be
sustained unless they are arbitrary, capricious, or unlawful. (Ord. 24-007, 12-
11-2024)
11-4-1-6: APPROVAL, CONDITIONAL APPROVAL, OR DISAPPROVAL:
   A.   Action By Town Council: The town council shall approve, conditionally
approve, or disapproves the preliminary plat within sixty (60) working days of
determination of sufficiency for review, unless the subdivider consents to an
extension of the review period. If the town council disapproves or
conditionally approves the preliminary plat, it shall forward one copy of the
plat to the subdivider accompanied by a letter over the appropriate signature
stating the reason for disapproval or enumerating the conditions that must be
met to assure approval of the final plat.
   B.   Basis For Decision: The basis for the town council's decision to
approve, conditionally approve, or disapprove a subdivision shall be whether
the preliminary plat and supplements; environmental assessment; planner's
report; planning board recommendations; and additional information demonstrates
that development of the subdivision would meet the requirements of the MSPA,
these regulations, the Manhattan city-county growth policy, zoning regulations,
and this code.
      1.   Prerequisites To Approval: The governing body may not approve or
conditionally approve a subdivision application and preliminary plat unless the
proposed subdivision:
         a.   Provides easements for the location and installation of any
planned utilities;
         b.   Provides legal and physical access to each parcel within the
subdivision and the notation of that access on the applicable plat and any
instrument transferring the parcel;
         c.   Provides adequate and legal water rights;
         d.   Assures that all required public or private improvements will be
installed before final plat approval, or that their installation after final
plat approval will be guaranteed as provided by these regulations;
         e.   Assures that the requirements of MCA 76-3-504(1)(j) regarding the
disclosure and disposition of water rights have been considered and will be
accomplished before the final plat is submitted;
         f.   Assures that the requirements of MCA 76-3-504(1)(k) regarding
watercourse and irrigation easements have been considered and will be
accomplished before the final plat is submitted; and
         g.   Provides for the appropriate park dedication or cash in lieu.
      2.   Consideration; Standards: In approving, conditionally approving, or
denying a subdivision application and preliminary plat, the governing body
shall consider the prerequisites above, and whether the proposed subdivision
complies with:
         a.   These regulations, including, but not limited to, the standards
set forth in chapter 6 of this title;
         b.   Applicable zoning regulations;
         c.   Other applicable regulations;
         d.   The MSPA, including, but not limited to, the following impacts
and proposed mitigation strategies:
            (1)   Impact on agriculture;
            (2)   Impact on agricultural water user facilities;
            (3)   Impact on local services;
            (4)   Impact on the natural environment;
            (5)   Impact on wildlife;
            (6)   Impact on wildlife habitat;
            (7)   Impact on public health and safety; and
      3.   Consideration; Evidence: In making its decision to approve,
conditionally approve, or deny a proposed subdivision, the governing body may
consider and weigh the following, as applicable:
         a.   The subdivision application and preliminary plat;
         b.   The environmental assessment;
         c.   The summary of probable impacts and mitigation;
         d.   An officially adopted growth policy;
         e.   Comments, evidence, and discussions at the public hearing(s);
         f.   Subdivision administrator's staff report and recommendations;
         g.   Planning board recommendation; and
         h.   Any additional information authorized by law.
      4.   No Information Considered After Final Public Hearing:
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the governing body may not consider any
information regarding the subdivision application that is presented after the
final public hearing (which may include a subsequent hearing if any) when
making its decision to approve, conditionally approve, or deny the proposed
subdivision.
   C.   Findings Of Fact: In rendering its decision to approve, conditionally
approve, or deny the proposed subdivision, the town council shall issue a
written findings of fact that discusses and weighs the proposed subdivision's
compliance with this code and the MSPA.
   D.   Inaccurate Information; Withdrawal Of Approval: The town council may
withdraw approval of a plat if it determines that information provided by the
subdivider, and upon which such decision was based, is inaccurate.
   E.   Written Statement: When a preliminary plat is approved, denied, or
conditionally approved, the Town shall provide the subdivider a written
statement, with appropriate signature, and make the written statement available
to the public. The written statement shall:
      1.   Contain information regarding the appeal process for the denial or
imposition of conditions;
      2.   Identify the regulations and statutes that are used in reaching the
decision to approve, deny, or impose conditions and explain how they apply to
the decision;
      3.   Provide the facts and conclusions that the governing body relied
upon in making its decision and reference documents, testimony, or other
materials that form the basis of the decision;
      4.   Provide the conditions that apply to the preliminary plat approval
and that must be satisfied before the final plat may be approved; and
      5.   Set forth the time limit for approval.
   F.   Water And Sanitation; Special Rules:
      1.   Water and sanitation information provided during the application
review process, including public comment, may be used as a basis for a
conditional approval or denial of a subdivision only if the governing body
finds that the application does not comply with previously adopted subdivision,
zoning, floodplain, or other regulations.
      2.   For a proposed subdivision that will create one or more parcels
containing less than twenty (20) acres, the governing body shall require
approval by the DEQ as a condition of approval of the final plat. This approval
applies to the development of lots at the time of the approval and is no
guarantee that a source of water or a location for a septic system or drain
fields will be available when the lots are developed.
      3.   For a proposed subdivision that will create one or more parcels
containing twenty (20) acres or more, the governing body shall condition
approval of the final plat upon the subdivider demonstrating that there is an
adequate water source and at least one area for a septic system and a
replacement drain field for each lot. Septic systems are only allowed for
commercial subdivisions within town limits. Residential projects in the UGA and
PJA may propose the use of septic systems. This demonstration to the local
reviewing authority is to evaluate the ability to develop lots at the platting
stage and is no guarantee that a source of water or a location for a septic
system or drain fields will be available when the lots are developed.
      4.   The governing body shall collect public comments submitted regarding
water and sanitation information and shall make any comments submitted or a
summary of the comments submitted available to the subdivider within thirty
(30) days after conditional approval or approval of the subdivision application
and preliminary plat.
      5.   The subdivider shall, as part of the subdivider's application for
sanitation approval, forward the comments or the summary provided by the
governing body to the:
         a.   Reviewing authority provided in MCA, title 76, chapter 4, for
subdivisions that will create one or more parcels containing less than twenty
(20) acres; and
         b.   Local health department or board of health for proposed
subdivisions that will create one or more parcels containing twenty (20) acres
or more and less than one hundred sixty (160) acres. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-4-1-7: APPROVAL PERIOD:
   A.   Statement Of Approval: Upon approving or conditionally approving a
preliminary plat, the town council shall provide the subdivider with a dated
and signed statement of approval. This approval shall be in force for not more
than three (3) calendar years.
   B.   Extension: At the end of this period, the town council may, at the
written request of the subdivider at least thirty (30) days prior to the
expiration of the preliminary plat approval. If the applicant fails to petition
the town thirty (30) days prior to the expiration date the applicant must
restart the process and submit a new application. The town council may extend
its approval for a period of no more than one (1) year, except that the town
council may extend its approval for a period of more than one (1) year if that
approval period is included as a specific condition of a written subdivision
improvements agreement between the town and the subdivider or there is
reasonable evidence that something outside of the subdividers control shall
delay the project beyond a calendar year.
   C.   Additional Conditions: After the preliminary plat is approved, the town
council may not impose any additional conditions as a prerequisite to final
plat approval providing said approval is obtained within the original or
extended approval period. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-4-1-8: AMENDED APPLICATIONS:
   A.   If the subdivider changes the subdivision application or preliminary
plat after the subdivision administrator approves sufficiency but before the
planning board hearing, the subdivider shall submit the amended application to
the subdivision administrator for review.
      1.   Within five (5) working days of receiving the amended application or
preliminary plat, the subdivision administrator shall determine whether the
changes to the subdivision application or preliminary plat are material.
      2.   The sixty (60) working day review period is suspended while the
subdivision administrator considers whether the changes to the subdivision
application or preliminary plat are material.
      3.   If the subdivision administrator determines the changes are not
material, the sixty (60) working day review period resumes when the subdivision
administrator provides notice of the decision to the subdivider.
      4.   If the subdivision administrator determines the changes are
material, the subdivision administrator shall either require the subdivider to
schedule a new preapplication meeting and resubmit the application as a new
subdivision application or proceed with the sixty (60) working day review
period upon certification from the subdivision administrator that the
application is sufficient for review.
   B.   If the subdivider changes the subdivision application or preliminary
plat after the planning board hearing but before the governing body hearing,
the subdivider shall submit the amended application or preliminary plat to the
subdivision administrator for review.
      1.   Within five (5) working days of receiving the amended application or
preliminary plat, the subdivision administrator shall determine whether the
changes to the subdivision application or preliminary plat are material.
      2.   The sixty (60) working day review period is suspended while the
subdivision administrator considers whether the changes to the subdivision
application or preliminary plat are material.
      3.   If the subdivision administrator determines the changes are not
material, the sixty (60) working day review period resumes when the subdivision
administrator provides notice of the decision to the subdivider.
      4.   If the subdivision administrator determines the changes are
material, the subdivision administrator shall either:
         a.   Require the subdivider to begin the subdivision review process
again, starting with the preapplication meeting, and require payment of a new
application fee; or
         b.   Schedule a new planning board hearing to take comment on the
amended application or preliminary plat. Notice of the subdivision
administrator's determination to schedule a new planning board hearing shall be
provided. A supplemental staff report shall be prepared to address the changes
to the original application.
      5.   If a new planning board hearing is held, the sixty (60) working day
review period is suspended for the time between notice of the subdivision
administrator's determination and ten (10) working days after the date of the
second planning board hearing.
   C.   Material changes are considered the following, although not an
exhaustive list:
      1.   Configuration;
      2.   Increase in the density or number of lots;
      3.   Road layout;
      4.   Water and/or septic proposals;
      5.   Configuration of park land or open spaces;
      6.   Easement provisions; and
      7.   Designated access.
   D.   By making changes to a pending subdivision application or preliminary
plat, the subdivider consents to suspension of the review period as provided
above.
   E.   A subdivider whose subdivision application or preliminary plat has been
deemed materially changed by the subdivision administrator may appeal the
subdivision administrator's decision to the governing body by written notice
within ten (10) working days. The subdivider may request a hearing, and may
submit additional evidence to show that the changes to the preliminary plat are
not material.
      1.   The sixty (60) working day review period is suspended until the
governing body decision on the appeal is made.
      2.   If the governing body concludes that the evidence and information
demonstrate that the changes to the subdivision application or preliminary plat
are material, the governing body shall determine whether the subdivision
application should be resubmitted or scheduled for rehearing in front of the
planning board.
      3.   If the governing body concludes that the evidence and information
demonstrate that the changes to the subdivision application or preliminary plat
are not material, the sixty (60) working day review period resumes as of the
date of the decision.
      4.   By appealing the decision of the subdivision administrator, the
subdivider agrees to suspension of the sixty (60) working day review period
provided above. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-4-1-9:   FINAL PLATS:
The final plat shall be in accordance with the appropriate procedural
requirements contained in section
11-3-7  of this title. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-4-1-10:   RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS; APPROVAL, CONTENT AND ENFORCEMENT BY
GOVERNING BODY:
The restrictive covenants shall be in accordance with the requirements
contained in section
11-3-8  of this title. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-4-1-11:   PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS AGREEMENT; GUARANTY:
The public improvements agreement and guaranty shall be in accordance with the
requirements contained in section
11-3-9  of this title. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-4-1-12:   AMENDING APPROVED PRELIMINARY PLATS BEFORE FINAL PLAT APPROVAL:
Any proposal to amend a preliminary plat before final plat approval shall be in
accordance with the requirements contained in section
11-3-10  of this title. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
CHAPTER 5
MINOR SUBDIVISIONS
SECTION:
11-5-1: Preliminary Plats
11-5-1-1: Submission
11-5-1-2: Review Fee
11-5-1-3: Plat Review
11-5-1-4: Approval Period
11-5-2: Final Plats
11-5-2-1: Restrictive Covenants; Approval, Content And Enforcement By Governing
Body
11-5-2-2: Public Improvements Agreement; Guaranty
11-5-2-3: Amending Approved Preliminary Plats Before Final Plat Approval
11-5-1: PRELIMINARY PLATS:
   A.   First Minor Subdivision: A "first minor subdivision" is any proposed
minor subdivision from a tract of record that has not been subdivided or
created by a subdivision under the MSPA, or has not resulted from a tract of
record that has had more than five (5) parcels created from that tract of
record under MCA 76-3-201 or MCA 76-3-207, since October 1st, 2003. First minor
subdivisions shall be reviewed pursuant to this chapter.
   B.   Subsequent Minor Subdivisions: A "subsequent minor subdivision" is any
subdivision with five (5) or fewer lots that is not a first minor subdivision.
Subsequent minor subdivisions shall be reviewed as major subdivisions under
chapter 4 of this title unless exempted under section
11-5-1 -B-1. All the requirements and procedures of major subdivisions must be
followed for subsequent minor subdivisions. However, a park dedication is not
required.
      1.   Subsequent minors that meet the following criteria are reviewed
pursuant to chapter 11 of this title:
         a.   Are in a zoned area;
         b.   Has a will-serve letter from water and sewer system;
         c.   Has existing legal and physical access to each lot; and
         d.   Does not require a variance to subdivision regulations.
   C.   Preapplication And Initial Review Process: The preapplication process
and initial review process set forth in chapter 3, "General Procedures", of
this title apply to this chapter. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-5-1-1: SUBMISSION:
   A.   Time Of Submittal; Number Of Copies: An application for a minor
subdivision plat and all required documents together with the review fee, one
(1) copy of the preliminary plat in twenty-four inches by thirty-six-inch (24"
x 36") format, one (1) copies of plat supplements, and one (1) electronic copy
of all documents shall be submitted to town hall in accordance with any
deadlines established for submittal.
   B.   Required Information:
      1.   A completed and signed subdivision application form;
      2.   The required review fee;
      3.   A preliminary plat at a scale sufficient to legibly represent the
required data on the plat. The plat size shall be twenty-four inches by thirty-
six inches (24" x 36"). The preliminary plat shall conform to the design
standards set forth in chapter 6 of this title and shall contain the
information required by this title:
         a.   Name and location of the subdivision, scale, bar, north arrow,
and date of preparation.
         b.   The exterior boundaries of the tract and the location of all
section corners or legal subdivision corners of sections pertinent to the
subdivision boundary. If available, the names of plats and certificate of
survey numbers previously recorded adjacent to the exterior boundaries of the
subdivision.
         c.   All lots and blocks, designated by numbers, and the dimensions
and area of each lot.
         d.   All streets, alleys, avenues, roads and highways, and the width
of the rights of way, grades, and curvature of each with existing and proposed
street names, and proposed locations of intersections or other access points
for any subdivision requiring access to arterial or collector highways.
         e.   The approximate location, boundaries, dimensions and areas of any
parks, schools, common grounds, or other grounds dedicated for public use.
         f.   Any existing and proposed utilities located on or adjacent to the
tract including:
            (1)   The approximate location, size and depth of water mains,
sanitary and storm sewers, and fire hydrants.
            (2)   The approximate location of nearest water mains and sewer
lines where none are located on or adjacent to the tract.
            (3)   The approximate location of gas, electric and telephone
lines, and streetlights.
         g.   The approximate location of existing buildings, structures,
railroads, and improvements.
         h.   The approximate location and identity of all existing easements
and rights of way of record and proposed public and private easements and
rights of way on or adjacent to the tract, including description of their width
and purpose.
         i.   The location and description of all existing agricultural water
user facilities on or adjacent to the tract;
      4.   A vicinity map;
      5.   A topographic map;
      6.   Adjacent Property Owners: A certified list of names and addresses of
owners of record and purchasers under contract for deed of adjacent property.
      7.   A grading and drainage plan A complete grading and drainage plan
with accurate dimensions, course, and elevations, showing the proposed grades
of streets, bridges, ditches, culverts, and other drainage improvements;
      8.   Engineering plans for all public and private improvements;
      9.   Overall development plan if development is in phases;
      10.   Abstract of title (or title report);
      11.   Lien holders' acknowledgement of subdivision;
      12.   Documentation of legal and physical access;
      13.   Documentation of existing easements, including those for
agricultural water user facilities;
      14.   Existing covenants and deed restrictions;
      15.   Existing water rights;
      16.   Existing mineral rights;
      17.   Proposed road plans and profiles;
      18.   Encroachment permits from Montana department of transportation or
the local jurisdiction (if required);
      19.   Proposed easements;
      20.   Proposed disposition of water rights and proof of adequate water
supply for the proposed development;
      21.   Proposed disposition of mineral rights;
      22.   Transportation impact analysis or transportation plan;
      23.   Fire risk rating analysis and fire prevention plan;
      24.   Weed management plan and revegetation plan;
      25.   Property owners' association documents, including draft articles of
incorporation, declaration, and bylaws;
      26.   Covenants And Restrictions: Drafts of any covenants and
restrictions to be included in deeds or contracts for sales.
      27.   FIRM or FEMA panel map and letter identifying floodplain status,
unless provided by the town;
      28.   Required water and sanitation information;
      29.   A form of subdivision improvements agreement, if proposed;
      30.   Letter requesting a revocation of agricultural covenants;
      31.   Letter indicating locations of cultural or historic resources;
      32.   Variance request or approval (if required);
      33.   Rezoning application or approval (if required);
      34.   Flood hazard evaluation (if required);
      35.   Letter identifying and proposing mitigation for potential hazards
or other adverse impacts as identified in the preapplication meeting and not
covered by any of the above required materials; and
      36.   Such additional relevant and reasonable information as identified
by the subdivision administrator during the preapplication meeting that is
pertinent to the required elements of this section.
      37.   Sufficient documentary evidence from the public records
demonstrating that the subdivision will be the first minor subdivision from a
tract of record. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-5-1-2: REVIEW FEE:
The required review fee as presented in the fee schedule shall be paid when the
application is submitted. All checks shall be payable to the town. All review
fees are nonrefundable. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-5-1-3: PLAT REVIEW:
   A.   If the proposed subdivision is a first minor subdivision from a tract
of record and, when legal and physical access to all lots is provided, must be
reviewed as follows:
      1.   The governing body shall approve, conditionally approve, or deny the
first minor subdivision from a tract of record within thirty (35) working days
of a determination by the reviewing agent or agency that the application
contains required elements and sufficient information for review. The
determination and notification to the subdivider must be made in the same
manner as is provided in MCA 76-3-604(1) through (3).
      2.   The subdivider and the reviewing agent or agency may agree to an
extension or suspension of the review period, not to exceed one (1) year.
      3.   An application must include a summary of the probable impacts of the
proposed subdivision based on the criteria described in MCA 76-3-608(3).
      4.   The following requirements do not apply to the first minor
subdivision or a subsequent minor that meets section
11-5-1 -B-1 from a tract of record as provided:
         a.   The requirement to prepare an environmental assessment; and
         b.   The requirement to review the subdivision for the criteria
contained in MCA 76-3-608(3)(a) if the minor subdivision is proposed in the
portion of a jurisdictional area that has adopted zoning regulations that
address the criteria in MCA 76-3-608(3)(a).
      5.   The governing body or its authorized agent or agency may not hold a
public hearing or a subsequent public hearing under MCA 76-3-615 for a first
minor subdivision from a tract of record.
      6.   The governing body may adopt regulations that establish requirements
for the expedited review of the first minor subdivision from a tract of record.
The following apply to a proposed subdivision reviewed under the regulations:
         a.   Except as provided in section
11-5-1-3 -A, the provisions of MCA 76-3-608(3); and
         b.   The provisions of title 76, chapter 4, part 1, whenever approval
is required by those provisions.
   B.   Except as provided in MCA 76-3-616, any minor subdivision that is not a
first minor subdivision from a tract of record or a subsequent minor meeting
the criteria of section
11-5-1 -B-1, is a subsequent minor subdivision and must be reviewed as provided
in chapter 4 of this title.
   C.   Review and approval, conditional approval, or denial of a subdivision
under this chapter may occur only under those regulations in effect at the time
that a subdivision application is determined to contain sufficient information
for review.
      1.   If regulations change during the period that the application is
reviewed for required elements and sufficient information, the determination of
whether the application contains the required elements and sufficient
information must be based on the new regulations.
   D.   First and subsequent minor subdivisions must be reviewed using the
administrative process provided for in subsection
11-5-1-3 -E if the proposed subdivision:
      1.   Is in an area that is subject to and complies with zoning
regulations adopted pursuant to title 76, chapter 2, part 2 or 3, that, at a
minimum, address development intensity through densities, bulk, and dimensional
requirements, and use standards;
      2.   Has a will-serve letter from a municipal water and sewer service or
by a county water and/or sewer district created under MCA 7-13-2203 that
supplies both water and sewer services;
      3.   Has existing legal and physical access to each lot; and
      4.   Does not require a variance to any of the contents of the
subdivision regulations required in MCA 76-3-504(1)(g).
   E.   An administrative minor subdivision meeting the requirements of
subsection
11-5-1-3 -F is exempt from:
      1.   Submitting the summary of probable impacts based on criteria
described in MCA 76- 3-608(3) and the environmental assessment required in MCA
76-3-603;
      2.   The review criteria described in MCA 76-3-608(3)(a); and
      3.   The requirements of subsections (A) through (F) of section
11-5-1-3 .
   F.   For administrative minor subdivisions, the subdivision administrator
appointed by the governing body shall:
      1.   Assume all decision-making authority of the governing body provided
in MCA 76-3- 608;
      2.   Approve, conditionally approve, or deny an administrative minor
subdivision and issue a written statement pursuant to MCA 76-3-620 within
thirty (30) working days of a determination by the reviewing agent or agency
that the application contains required elements and sufficient information for
review as provided in MCA 76-3-604(1) through (3); and
      3.   Immediately on a determination that the application meets the
requirements of MCA 76-3-604(1) through (3), notify by first-class mail of the
pending application:
         a.   Each property owner of record whose property is immediately
adjoining the land included in the preliminary plat; and
         b.   Each purchaser under contract for deed of property immediately
adjoining the land included in the preliminary plat.
      4.   If a party identified in MCA 76-3-625(3) objects to a subdivision
administrator's decision to approve, conditionally approve, or deny an
administrative minor subdivision, the party may request in writing that the
subdivision administrator forward the application on to the governing body. The
governing body shall sustain the subdivision administrator's decision based on
the record unless the decision was arbitrary, capricious, or unlawful. The
governing body has fifteen (15) working days from the receipt of the request to
review a decision to approve, conditionally approve, or deny the administrative
minor subdivision and make a final determination.
   G.   As used in this section, "administrative minor subdivision" means a
subdivision meeting the requirements of section
11-5-1-3 -D and
11-5-1 -B-1. All the requirements of title 76, chapter 3, except those exempt
in subsections
11-5-1-3 -E and F, apply to an administrative minor subdivision. (Ord. 24-007,
12-11-2024)
11-5-1-6: APPROVAL PERIOD:
Upon approving or conditionally approving a preliminary plat, the town or
subdivision administrator shall provide the subdivider with a dated and signed
statement of approval. This approval shall be in force for not more than one
(1) calendar year. At the end of this period, the town may, at the request of
the subdivider, extend its approval for no more than one (1) calendar year. If
the subdivider does not extend the application per this title they have waived
the right to an extension. The town may, however, extend its approval for a
period of more than one (1) calendar year if that approval period is included
as a specific condition of subdivision improvements agreement between the town
and the subdivider or there is reasonable evidence that something outside of
the subdividers control shall delay the project beyond a calendar year. (Ord.
24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-5-2: FINAL PLATS:
The final plat shall be in accordance with the appropriate procedural
requirements contained in section
11-3-7  of this title. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-5-2-1: RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS; APPROVAL, CONTENT AND ENFORCEMENT BY GOVERNING
BODY:
The restrictive covenants shall be in accordance with the requirements
contained in section
11-3-8  of this title. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-5-2-2: PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS AGREEMENT; GUARANTY:
The public improvements agreement and guaranty shall be in accordance with the
requirements contained in section
11-3-9  of this title. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-5-2-3: AMENDING APPROVED PRELIMINARY PLATS BEFORE FINAL PLAT APPROVAL:
Any proposal to amend a preliminary plat before final plat approval shall be in
accordance with the requirements contained in section
11-3-10  of this title. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
CHAPTER 6
GENERAL DESIGN AND IMPROVEMENT STANDARDS
SECTION:
11-6-1: General Standards
11-6-2: Lands Unsuitable For Subdivision
11-6-3: Floodplain Provisions
11-6-4: Improvement Design
11-6-5: Lots
11-6-6: Blocks
11-6-7: Streets, Roads, Alleys And Access
11-6-8: Grading And Drainage
11-6-9: Water Supply Systems
11-6-10: Sewage Treatment System
11-6-11: Solid Waste
11-6-12: Utilities
11-6-13: Easements
11-6-14: Park Land Requirements
11-6-15: Fire Protection
11-6-16: Disposition Of Water Rights
11-6-1: GENERAL STANDARDS:
   A.   Compliance Required: All subdivisions approved by the town council
shall comply with the provisions of this section, except where granted a
variance. For subdivisions created by lease or rent, condominiums, and planned
unit developments, refer to chapters 7, 8 and 9 of this title.
   B.   Design And Development: The design and development of a subdivision
shall conform with the Manhattan city-county growth policy, Town of Manhattan
design standards and specifications policy, Town of Manhattan modifications to
Montana public works standard specifications and standard drawings for utility
improvements, this code, the Montana department of environmental quality
standards and other regulations. The design and development of subdivisions
shall provide satisfactory building sites which are properly related to
topography, and shall preserve the natural terrain, natural drainage, existing
topsoil, trees, and natural vegetation to the extent possible. (Ord. 24-007,
12-11-2024)
11-6-2: LANDS UNSUITABLE FOR SUBDIVISION:
Lands which the town council has found to be unsuitable for subdivision shall
not be subdivided for building or residential purposes unless the hazards are
eliminated or will be overcome by approved design and construction plans. These
unsuitable lands may have one or more of the following potential hazards:
   A.   Flooding;
   B.   Unstable soils;
   C.   High water table;
   D.   Polluted soils and/or ground water;
   E.   High voltage lines or high-pressure gas lines;
   F.   Vehicular traffic hazards, congestion; and
   G.   Lands placing unreasonable burdens on the public such as requirements
for the excessive expenditure of public funds or environmental degradation.
(Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-6-3: FLOODPLAIN PROVISIONS:
Land located in the floodway of a flood of one hundred (100) year frequency as
defined by title 76, chapter 5, Montana Code Annotated, or land deemed subject
to flooding as determined by the town council or designee shall not be
subdivided for building or residential purposes, or other uses that may
increase or aggravate flood hazards to life, health, or property. (Ord. 24-007,
12-11-2024)
11-6-4: IMPROVEMENT DESIGN:
Engineering and survey plans, specifications and reports required in connection
with public improvements and other elements of a subdivision required by the
town council shall be prepared by a registered professional engineer or a
registered land surveyor as their respective licensing laws allow in accordance
with the MSPA and this title. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-6-5: LOTS:
   A.   Building Site: Each lot shall contain a satisfactory building site,
which is properly related to topography and conforms to the Montana department
of environmental quality regulations, this code, and this title.
   B.   Prohibited Divisions:
      1.   No single lot shall be divided by a municipal boundary line.
      2.   No single lot shall be divided by a public street, alley, or utility
right of way or easement.
   C.   Access: Each lot shall have access to a public or private street.
Alleys may not be used to provide the primary means of access to a lot.
   D.   Corner Lots:
      1.   Driveway Access: Corner lots shall have driveway access to the same
street or road as interior lots.
      2.   Area: Corner lots shall be of sufficient area to provide acceptable
visibility for traffic safety.
   E.   Depth: No lot shall have an average depth greater than three (3) times
its average width.
   F.   Width: No lot shall have an average width greater than its average
depth.
   G.   Side Lot Lines: Side lot lines shall be at substantially right angles
to street or road lines and radial to curved street or road lines.
   H.   Through Lots: Through lots are prohibited except where essential to
provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to
overcome specific disadvantages of topography or orientation.
   I.   Lot And/or House Numbers: Lots and/or houses shall be clearly numbered
or otherwise identified. Numbers shall be a minimum of four inches (4") in
height and visible from the street. If adjacent to existing platted lots, lot
or house numbers shall correspond accordingly.
   J.   Penalty: Any person violating a provision of this chapter for which
another penalty has not been provided shall, upon conviction thereof, be
punished as set forth in section
1-4-2  of this code. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-6-6: BLOCKS:
   A.   Design: Blocks shall be designed to assure traffic safety and ease of
traffic control and circulation, to accommodate the special needs of the use
contemplated, and to take advantage of the area's topography.
   B.   Length: Unless impractical, block length must not be more than seven
hundred fifty feet (750').
   C.   Termination Of Streets: Blocks shall be wide enough to allow for two
(2) tiers of lots except where essential to provide separation of residential
development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific topography and
orientation constraints or unless the town council approves the design of
irregular shaped blocks indented by cul-de-sacs.
   D.   Pedestrian Walks: Rights of way for pedestrian walks, not less than ten
feet (10') wide, shall be required to provide access to schools, playgrounds,
shopping centers, transportation, and other community facilities.
   E.   Alleys: Alleys shall be required in all residential subdivisions where
prudent and utilities shall be placed in alleys when possible.
Penalty: Any person violating a provision of this section for which another
penalty has not been provided shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as
set forth in section
1-4-2  of this code. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-6-7: STREETS, ROADS, ALLEYS AND ACCESS:
   A.   Design:
      1.   Existing Conditions: The arrangement, type, extent, width, grade and
location of all streets and alleys shall be considered in their relation to
existing and planned streets and alleys, to topographical conditions and to
public convenience and safety, and in their relation to the proposed uses of
the land they will serve.
      2.   Design Specifications: Streets and alleys shall meet the design
specifications in the Town of Manhattan design standards and specifications
policy, Town of Manhattan modifications to Montana public works standard
specifications and standard drawings for utility improvements, and this code.
      3.   Termination Of Streets: Where streets terminate, either a cul-de-sac
or T turnaround must be provided at the terminus.
      4.   Soil Stability: In areas where the Gallatin County soil survey
designates severe limitations exist in soil stability, aggregate surfacing
thickness design of streets shall be based upon an analysis of subgrade
foundation strength.
      5.   Dedication To Public: All streets and alleys within a subdivision
shall be dedicated to the public.
