      6.   Alleys: A minimum twenty-foot (20') alley shall be required for fire
lane and utility easements.
      7.   Residential Driveways: Residential driveways in major subdivisions
shall not have direct access to primary highways. Where no reasonable option is
available, the Montana department of transportation may issue a road approach
permit.
      8.   Through Traffic: Local streets shall be designed to discourage
through traffic. This is not meant to discourage the continuance or connection
of the grid pattern present in Manhattan. Where possible all street shall
connect to the existing transportation network of Manhattan.
      9.   Arterial Highway Or Major Thoroughfare: Where a subdivision abuts or
contains an existing or proposed arterial highway or major thoroughfare, the
town council may require frontage roads, and prohibit access along the rear
property line, deep lots, or other appropriate actions to adequately protect
residential properties and to separate arterial and local traffic.
      10.   Existing Streets And Alleys: Streets and alleys which are a
continuation of existing streets and alleys outside the proposed subdivision
shall be aligned to ensure their center lines and boulevards coincide.
Continuation of existing streets and alleys shall have the right-of-way width
of at least that of the existing streets and alleys unless otherwise specified
by the town.
      11.   Half Streets: Half streets are prohibited except where essential to
the development of the subdivision and where the town council is assured that
it will be possible to require the dedication of the other half of the street
when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever an existing half street is
adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street must be
platted within such tract.
      12.   Names: Names of new streets aligned with existing streets shall be
the same as those of the existing streets. Street names for noncontinuous
streets shall not be duplicated nor be confused with existing street names.
Street names are subject to approval of the town council.
      13.   Intersections: The following items apply to intersections:
         a.   Streets shall intersect at ninety-degree (90°) angles, except
when topography precludes, and in no case shall the angle of intersection be
less than seventy-five degrees (75°) to the center line of the street being
intersected.
         b.   Two (2) streets meeting a third street from opposite sides must
be offset at least one hundred twenty-five feet (125') for local streets and
three hundred feet (300') for arterials or collectors.
         c.   Intersection design shall provide acceptable visibility for
traffic safety as indicated by the designed operating speeds on the individual
roadways.
         d.   Intersections of local streets with major arterials or highways
shall be kept to a minimum.
   B.   General Improvements:
      1.   Roadway Improvements: All roadway improvements including pavement,
curbs, gutters, sidewalks, and drainage shall be constructed in accordance with
the specifications and standards prescribed in the town specifications for
street improvements.
      2.   Sidewalks Or Walkways: Sidewalks or walkways shall be provided in
subdivisions of the town and shall be a minimum width of five feet (5') in
residential districts and ten feet (10') in commercial districts. Boulevards
shall conform with existing boulevards or when none exist, boulevards shall be
a minimum of four feet (4').
      3.   Streetlights: Streetlights shall be required by the town on all
streets within the subdivision. They shall be designed to meet the Town of
Manhattan design standards and specifications policy, Town of Manhattan
modifications to Montana public works standard specifications and standard
drawings for utility improvements and exceed the following minimum standards:
 
Location         Average Horizontal Foot Candles
Within Manhattan Town Limits
Entrance Streets 1.2
Minor Streets    0.9
 
      4.   Existing Trees And Vegetation: Existing trees and other vegetation
shall be preserved where possible. The Town may require plantings for
buffering, screening, or soil erosion protection.
      5.   Street Name and Traffic-Control Signs: Street name and traffic-
control signs shall be installed at all intersections and other appropriate
locations within the subdivision. The size, shape, height, and placement of
signs shall conform with the town sign specifications. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-
2024)
11-6-8: GRADING AND DRAINAGE:
   A.   Drainage System And Facilities:
      1.   Standards: The drainage system and facilities required for any
surface runoff affecting the subdivision shall meet the minimum drainage
standards of the Town of Manhattan design standards and specifications policy,
town of Manhattan modifications to Montana public works standard specifications
and standard drawings for utility improvements, the Montana department of
environmental quality and all other adopted regulations and are subject to the
approval of the town.
      2.   Subdivider To Provide: The subdivider shall provide suitable
drainage facilities (e.g., storm drains, ditches, or culverts) for any surface
runoff affecting the subdivision and any adjacent properties. These facilities
shall be in street rights of way or in perpetual easements of appropriate
widths and are subject to approval by the town.
      3.   Size; Specifications: Each drainage facility shall be large enough
to accommodate potential runoff from upstream drainage areas. The size of the
facility shall be calculated in accordance with the Town of Manhattan design
standards and specifications policy, Town of Manhattan modifications to Montana
public works standard specifications and standard drawings for utility
improvements. Other erosion control measures may be required as necessary.
      4.   Discharge Prohibited: Stormwater drainage systems, roof drainage,
building foundation drains and sump pumps, and groundwater dewatering systems
shall not discharge into any sanitary sewer facility.
   B.   Curbs And Gutters: Curbs and gutters shall be required in all
subdivisions. Where possible, curbs and gutters on adjoining properties shall
be extended to join new curbs and gutters.
   C.   Preparation Of Plans, Specifications And Reports: Plans,
specifications, and reports required with the grading and drainage plan shall
be prepared by a registered professional engineer or a registered land surveyor
as their respective licensing laws allow. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-6-9: WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS:
   A.   Installation Required: The subdivider shall install complete water
distribution facilities to adjoin the existing municipal system in accordance
with the requirements of the Town of Manhattan design standards and
specifications policy, Town of Manhattan modifications to Montana public works
standard specifications and standard drawings for utility improvements, the
Montana department of environmental quality, and this code.
   B.   Adequate And Legal Water Supply: The subdivider shall provide the town
with adequate and legal water supply or the town shall provide water supply
only if the town has a surplus of legal and adequate water supply and that the
inclusion of proposed development has no negative impacts to the distribution
system nor the capacity of water of the town's water supply system.
   C.   Plans And Specifications: The subdivider shall submit plans and
specifications for the proposed facilities to the town and to the Montana
department of environmental quality and shall obtain their approvals prior to
undertaking any construction. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-6-10: SEWAGE TREATMENT SYSTEM:
   A.   Installation Required: Except as otherwise provided in section
9-2-2  of this code, the subdivider shall install complete sanitary sewer
collection facilities to adjoin the existing municipal system in accordance
with the requirements of the Town of Manhattan design standards and
specifications policy, Town of Manhattan modifications to Montana public works
standard specifications and standard drawings for utility improvements, the
Montana department of environmental quality, and this code.
   B.   Plans And Specifications: The subdivider shall submit plans and
specifications for the proposed facilities to the town and to the Montana
department of environmental quality and shall obtain their approval prior to
undertaking any construction. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-6-11: SOLID WASTE:
The subdivider shall assure that provisions for collection and disposal of
solid waste are available and meet the regulations and minimum standards of the
Montana department of environmental quality. These means shall be in accordance
with current town procedures for collection and disposal. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-
2024)
11-6-12: UTILITIES:
   A.   Easements: The subdivider shall provide adequate and appropriate
easements for the construction of utilities within the subdivision. The
subdivider shall obtain any easements necessary to extend utilities to the
subdivision.
   B.   Underground Placement: Utilities shall be placed underground whenever
practical. Underground utilities, if placed in the street right of way, shall
be located between the roadway and the right of way line to simplify location
and repair of lines. Underground utility lines shall be installed after the
street has been brought to grade and before it is surfaced to minimize the
necessity for disturbing road surfacing to connect individual services.
   C.   Overhead Utility Lines: Overhead utility lines shall be located at rear
property lines, where practical.
   D.   Design: Utility facilities shall be designed by utility firms in
cooperation with the subdivider. Design is subject to all applicable laws and
rules and regulations of any regulatory authority having jurisdiction over such
facilities. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-6-13: EASEMENTS:
   A.   Required: Where required by the town or private utility company,
easements shall be provided for utilities, drainage and vehicular or pedestrian
access.
   B.   Location: Front setback utility easements must be ten feet wide, and
must always be provided unless written confirmation is submitted to the town
from all utility companies providing service indicating that a front setback
easement is not needed. Side and back yard utility easements, if required,
shall be centered along or adjacent to side and rear lot lines where possible.
If placed in the street, they shall be located between the roadway and the
right of way line.
   C.   Width: Utility easements shall be at least ten feet (10') along the
front yard and street frontage, twenty feet (20') wide along or adjacent to
rear lot lines and sixteen feet (16') wide for side lot lines unless otherwise
specified by the town.
   D.   Encroachment Permit: Where a utility will be in an existing, dedicated
right of way, an encroachment permit must be obtained from the local and/or
state road department having jurisdiction.
   E.   Watercourse, Drainageway, Channel, Ditch Or Stream:
      1.   Except as noted below, the subdivider shall establish within the
subdivision ditch easements that:
         a.   Are in locations of appropriate topographic characteristics and
sufficient width to allow the physical placement and unobstructed maintenance
of open ditches or belowground pipelines for the delivery of water for
irrigation to persons and land legally entitled to the water under an
appropriated water right or permit of an irrigation district or other private
or public entity formed to provide for the use of the water rights on the
subdivision lots;
         b.   Are a sufficient distance from the centerline of the ditch to
allow for construction, repair, maintenance, and inspection of the ditch; and
         c.   Prohibit the placement of structures or the planting of
vegetation other than grass within the ditch easement without the written
permission of the ditch owner.
      2.   The subdivider shall, unless otherwise provided under separate
written agreement or filed easement, show on the preliminary and final plat,
and file and record with the county clerk and recorder, ditch easements for the
unobstructed use and maintenance of existing water delivery ditches, pipelines,
and facilities in the proposed subdivision that are necessary to convey water
through the subdivision to lands adjacent to or beyond the subdivision
boundaries in quantities and in a manner that are consistent with historic and
legal rights. A minimum width of fifteen feet (15') is required on each side of
irrigation canals and ditches for maintenance purposes.
         a.   In addition to showing the location of the easement on the plat
with dashed lines, the following statement shall be on the final plat or an
accompanying document:
   F.   The undersigned hereby grants unto each person, firm or corporation
that has a documented water right or agricultural water user facilities as
shown on this plat, an easement for the maintenance and repair of said
agricultural water user facilities in, over and across the areas designated
water user facility easement.
   G.   Required Statement: In addition to showing the location of the utility
easement on the plat with dashed lines, the following statement shall be on the
final plat or an accompanying document:
"The undersigned hereby grants unto each person, firm, or corporation, whether
public or private, providing or offering to provide telephone, telegraph,
electrical power, gas, television, water or sewer service to the public, the
right to joint use of an easement for the construction, maintenance, repair and
removal of their lines and other facility, in, over, under and across each area
designated on this plat as "Utility Easement" to have and to hold forever."
(Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-6-14: PARK LAND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Cash Or Land Donation Required: A subdivider may dedicate to the town a
cash or land donation equal to eleven percent (11%) of the area of the land
proposed to be subdivided into parcels of one-half (½) acre or smaller.
   B.   Additional Requirements: When a subdivision is located totally within
an area for which density requirements have been adopted pursuant to the
Manhattan master plan or to title 10 of this code, the town may establish park
dedication requirements based on the community need for parks and the
development densities identified in the plan or ordinance. Park dedication
requirements established under this subsection is in lieu of those provided in
section
11-6-14 -A of this section, and may not exceed three one-hundredths (0.03) acre
per dwelling unit.
   C.   Exceptions: A park dedication may not be required for:
      1.   A minor subdivision;
      2.   Subdivision into parcels that are all nonresidential;
      3.   Subdivision exemptions per MCA 76-3-207;
      4.   A subdivision in which parcels are not created, except when that
subdivision provides permanent multiple spaces for recreational camping
vehicles, mobile homes, or condominiums; or
      5.   A subdivision in which only one additional parcel is created.
   D.   Suitable Locations; Determination of Donation: The town, in
consultation with the subdivider and the planning board or park board that has
jurisdiction, may determine suitable locations for parks and playgrounds and,
giving due weight and consideration to the expressed preference of the
subdivider, may determine whether the park dedication must be a land donation,
cash donation, or a combination of both. When a combination of land donation
and cash donation is required, the cash donation may not exceed the
proportional amount not covered by the land donation.
   E.   Dedicated Funds, Use Of: In accordance with the provisions of
subsections
11-6-14 -E-1 and
11-6-14 -E-2 of this section, the town shall use the dedicated money or land
for development, acquisition, or maintenance of parks to serve the subdivision.
      1.   Acquire, Develop Or Maintain Parks Or Recreational Areas: The town
may use the dedicated money to acquire, develop, or maintain, within its
jurisdiction, parks, or recreational areas or for the purchase of public open
space or conservation easements only if:
         a.   The park, recreational area, open space, or conservation easement
is within a reasonably proximity to the proposed subdivision; and
         b.   The town has formally adopted a park plan that establishes the
needs and procedures for use of the money.
      2.   Maintenance: The town may not use more than fifty percent (50%) of
the dedicated money for park maintenance.
   F.   Waiver: The town shall waive the park dedication requirement if:
      1.   Park And Recreational Uses:
         a.   The preliminary plat provides for a planned unit development or
other development with land permanently set aside for park and recreational
uses sufficient to meet the needs of the persons who will ultimately reside in
the development; and
         b.   The area of the land and any improvements set aside for park and
recreational purposes equals or exceeds the area of the dedication required
under subsection A of this section;
      2.   Long Term Protection:
         a.   The preliminary plat provides long term protection of critical
wildlife habitat; cultural, historical, or natural resources; agricultural
interests; or aesthetic values; and
         b.   The area of the land proposed to be subdivided, by virtue of
providing long term protection provided for in subsection
11-6-14 -F-2-a of this section, is reduced by an amount equal to or exceeding
the area of the dedication required under subsection A of this section; or
      3.   Equal To or Exceed Requirement: The area of the land proposed to be
subdivided, by virtue of a combination of the provisions of subsections
11-6-14 -F-1 and
11-6-14 -F-2 of this section, is reduced by an amount equal to or exceeding the
area of the dedication required under subsection A of this section.
      4.   Land Outside Subdivision: The subdivider provides for land outside
of the subdivision to be set aside for park and recreational uses sufficient to
meet the needs of the persons who will ultimately reside in the subdivision;
and the area of the land and any improvements set aside for park and
recreational uses equals or exceeds the area of dedication required under this
section.
   G.   Cash Donation Defined: For the purposes of this section, "cash
donation" is the fair market value of the unsubdivided, unimproved land after
it has been annexed and given an urban zoning designation. The town intends to
obtain the highest value for cash in lieu of park land that is allowable under
Montana law.
      1.   It shall be the responsibility of the developer to provide an
appraisal of the fair market value by a certified real estate appraiser of
their choosing. The appraisal fee shall be the responsibility of the developer.
      2.   When a land value must be established for cash in lieu of land
dedication, and the value of the land in an unsubdivided, unimproved, but
annexed and zoned condition cannot reasonably be determined, the developer may
provide an appraisal of residentially zoned property with a zoning designation
that allows the density of dwellings proposed for development.
      3.   The appraisal shall be conducted not sooner than ninety (90) days
prior to the submittal of an application for final plat or final site plan
approval.
   H.   Land Donation To School District: Subject to the approval of the local
governing body and acceptance by the school district trustees, a subdivider may
dedicate a land donation to the Manhattan school district, adequate to be used
for school facilities or buildings. The area dedicated to the school district
may be used for school facilities or buildings, including, but not limited to,
playgrounds or other recreational facility.
      1.   In approving a dedication of land to the school district the town
council shall make affirmative findings that:
         a.   Adequate public park land already exists within the vicinity of
the dedicating subdivision to meet service standards established by the town's
parks master plan;
         b.   The land is located within the town limits or within one mile of
town limits;
         c.   The school district has established a facility plan to
demonstrate how the dedicated property will be utilized;
         d.   The school district's facility plan shall describe any
coordination intended for joint use of the property by the school district and
the town; and
         e.   The option for cash in lieu of land described in this section
shall not be used in place of a land dedication to the school district.
      2.   It shall be noted in a certificate on the plat and in any deed to
the land that if the school district later chooses to dispose of the property,
it shall revert to the town to be used for park purposes. The land shall be
transferred to the town from the school district with clear title and in a
condition meeting the minimum development standards for parks. (Ord. 24-007,
12-11-2024)
11-6-15: FIRE PROTECTION:
All subdivisions shall be planned, designed, constructed, and maintained to
minimize the risk of fire and to permit the effective and efficient suppression
of fires to protect persons and property. All subdivisions must conform to
standards and specifications required by the town fire department. (Ord. 24-
007, 12-11-2024)
11-6-16: DISPOSITION OF WATER RIGHTS:
If a subdivision will create lots within the planning jurisdictional area of
the town, but not within town limits, averaging less than five (5) acres in
size, the subdivider shall submit evidence with the final plat that the
subdivider has:
   A.   Reserved all or a portion of the appropriation water rights owned by
the owner of the land to be subdivided and transfer these water rights to the
town for use by landowners within the subdivision;
   B.   If the land to be subdivided is subject to a contract or interest in a
public or private entity formed to provide for the use of a water right on the
subdivision lots, established a landowner's water use agreement administered
through a single entity. Any entity that is not affiliated with the town may
not operate a public or private water system within the town limits. If
proposed in the UGA or PJA an agreement to provide water service to the
proposed development must be filed with the Town of Manhattan prior to
preliminary plat approval. This agreement must specify how the water rights
will be administered and describe the rights and responsibilities of landowners
within the subdivision who have a legal right and access to the water; or
   C.   Reserved and severed all surface water rights from the land proposed
for subdivision. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
CHAPTER 7
EXPEDITED REVIEW FOR CERTAIN SUBDIVISIONS
SECTION:
11-7-1: Criteria
11-7-2:    Review Process
11-7-1: CRITERIA:
Except as provided in this chapter, a subdivision application, regardless of
the number of lots, that meets the requirements provided in section
11-7-1 -B is entitled to the expedited review process provided in this section
at the applicant's request.
   A.   A subdivision application that meets the requirements provided in
section
11-7-1 -B is exempt from:
      1.   The preparation of an environmental assessment as required in MCA
76-3-603; and
      2.   The review criteria listed in MCA 76-3-608(3)(a).
   B.   A subdivision qualifies for the expedited review process provided in
this section if the proposed subdivision:
      1.   Is within an incorporated city or town or consolidated city-county
government and is subject to an adopted growth policy pursuant to MCA title 76,
chapter 1, and adopted zoning regulations pursuant to MCA title 76, chapter 2,
part 3; or
      2.   Is within a county water and/or sewer district created under MCA 7-
13-2203 that provides both water and sewer services or an area outside the
boundaries of an incorporated city, town, county, or consolidated city-county
that is served by city, town, county, or consolidated city-county water and
sewer services and is subject to an adopted growth policy as provided in title
76, chapter 1, and zoning regulations pursuant to MCA title 76, chapter 2, part
2, that, at a minimum, address development intensity through minimum lot sizes
or densities, bulk and dimensional requirements, and use standards;
         a.   Complies with zoning regulations adopted pursuant to MCA 76-2-203
or MCA 76-2-304 and complies with the design standards and other subdivision
regulations adopted pursuant to MCA 76-3-504; and
         b.   Includes in its proposal plans for the onsite development of or
extension to public infrastructure in accordance with adopted ordinances and
regulations. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-7-2: REVIEW PROCESS:
   A.   On submission for expedited review under this section, the subdivision
application must be reviewed for required elements and sufficiency of
information as provided in MCA 76-3- 601(1) through (3) to determine whether
the application complies with zoning regulations adopted pursuant to MCA 76-2-
203 or MCA 76-2-304 and complies with the design standards and other
subdivision regulations adopted pursuant to MCA 76-3-504 MCA and includes in
its proposal plans for the onsite development of or extension to public
infrastructure in accordance with adopted ordinances and regulations. The
application may include a request for variance or deviation from subdivision
regulations adopted pursuant to MCA 76-3-504 and in accordance with the
provisions of MCA 76-3-506.
   B.   The Governing Body Shall:
      1.   Hold a hearing and approve, conditionally approve, or deny the
subdivision application within thirty-five (35) working days of a determination
by the reviewing agent or agency that the application contains required
elements and sufficient information for review as provided in section
11-7-1 -B. If the subdivision application includes a request for variance or
deviation from subdivision regulations adopted pursuant to MCA 76- 3-504, the
time for holding a hearing as required in this subsection
11-7-2 -D must be extended to a total of forty-five (45) working days.
      2.   Provide notice for the hearing required in section
11-7-2 -D-a by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county
not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the hearing;
      3.   Approve the application unless public comment or other information
demonstrates the application does not comply with:
         a.   Adopted zoning regulations, design standards, and other
requirements of subdivision regulations adopted pursuant to MCA 76-3-504,
including any criteria for granting variances or deviations from subdivision
regulations adopted pursuant to MCA 76-3-504; or
         b.   Adopted ordinances or regulations for the onsite development of
or extension to public infrastructure; and
      4.   Provide to the applicant and the public a written statement within
thirty (30) days of the decision to approve or deny a proposed subdivision for
expedited review as allowed in this section that provides:
         a.   The facts and conclusions that the governing body relied on in
making its decision to approve or deny the application; and
         b.   The conditions that apply to the preliminary plat approval that
must be satisfied before the final plat may be approved.
   C.   The Governing Body May:
      1.   With the agreement of the applicant, grant one (1) extension of the
review period allowed in subsection
11-7-2 -D-a not to exceed one hundred eighty (180) calendar days;
      2.   Adopt conditions of approval only to ensure an approved subdivision
application is completed in accordance with the approved application and any
applicable requirements pursuant to MCA title 76, chapter 4; or
      3.   Delegate to its reviewing agent or agency the requirement to hold a
public hearing on the subdivision application as required in this section.
   D.   A local governing body may not adopt zoning regulations pursuant to MCA
76-2-203 or MCA 76-2-304, subdivision regulations pursuant to MCA 76-3-504, or
other ordinances or regulations that restrict the use of the expedited
subdivision review process as provided in this section.
   E.   Except as modified in this section, subdivision applications meeting
the requirements for an expedited review remain subject to the provisions of
MCA 76-3-608(3)(b) through (3)(d) and MCA 76-3-608(6) through (10), MCA 76-3-
610 through MCA 76-3-614, MCA 76-3-621, and MCA 76-3-625.
   F.   The provisions of this section supersede any provision of this chapter
that conflicts with any provision of this section. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
CHAPTER 8
SUBDIVISIONS CREATED BY RENT OR LEASE
SECTION:
11-8-1: General
11-8-2:    Procedure
11-8-3:    Standards For Mobile Home Parks And Recreational Vehicle Camping
Parks
11-8-1: GENERAL:
An area, regardless of its size, that provides for the rent or lease of
multiple spaces for recreational camping vehicles or mobile homes, townhouses
and condominiums are exempt from the survey requirements of these regulations,
but must be submitted for review and be approved by the governing body before
possession of any portion thereof may be conveyed in any manner.
   A.   Condominiums, townhomes, townhouses, or conversions, as those terms are
defined in section 70-23-102, constructed on land subdivided in compliance with
parts 5 and 6 of this chapter or on lots within incorporated cities and towns
are exempt from the provisions of this chapter if:
      1.   The approval of the original subdivision of land expressly
contemplated the construction of the condominiums, townhomes, or townhouses and
any applicable park dedication requirements in section 76-3-621 are complied
with; or
      2.   The condominium, townhome, or townhouse proposal is in conformance
with applicable local zoning regulations pertaining to land use, density, bulk
and dimensional requirements, landscaping, and parking requirements when local
zoning regulations are in effect. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-8-2: PROCEDURE:
Subdivisions created for the rent or lease of multiple spaces for recreational
camping vehicles or mobile homes, Townhouses, and condominiums shall be
reviewed in accordance with the procedures outlined in the major subdivision
section for proposals that include six (6) or more mobile home, townhouses,
condominium, or recreational camping vehicle units; or the minor subdivision
section for proposals that include five (5) or fewer mobile home, townhouses,
condominium, or recreational camping vehicle units.
   A.   Plans And Data. Plans and supplemental information required in these
regulations shall be submitted with the following exemptions and additions.
      1.   Boundary Lines: All plans may show approximate boundary, lot, right-
of-way, or other lines including the plan submitted for final approval.
      2.   Documents And Certificates: Only the following documents and
certificates shall be submitted with or shown on the preliminary plan (draft or
copy) and the plan submitted for final approval (final form and signed).
         a.   Covenants, restrictions, or lease and rental agreements.
         b.   Encroachment permits or a letter indicating intent to issue a
permit where new roads, easements, and other subdivision improvements intersect
or are located within city, county, or state highways or roads.
         c.   Certificates of installation of improvements by engineer.
         d.   Certificate of the town council.
         e.   A letter of approval from the town council where a zoning change
is necessary (with plan for final approval only).
         f.   Certificate of approval by MDEQ (with plan for final approval
only). (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-8-3: STANDARDS FOR MOBILE HOME PARKS AND RECREATIONAL VEHICLE CAMPING PARKS:
   A.   The design and improvement standards of these regulations shall be
compiled with, except where otherwise noted below.
   B.   Density: The density shall not exceed twenty (20) spaces per acre of
gross site area.
   C.   Occupied Area: Mobile home and its attached structures may not occupy
more than one- third (1/3) of the area of its lot. The total area occupied by a
mobile home and its roofed accessory buildings and structures may not exceed
two-thirds (2/3) of the area of a lot.
   D.   Space Layout: Required plans shall include a layout of a typical mobile
home or recreational camping vehicle space showing the location and dimensions
of the space, stand, driveway, and parking spaces in compliance with the
following standards:
 Mobile Home Park Recreational Vehicle Park
                        Mobile Home Park            Recreational Vehicle Park
Minimum Space Area      6,000 sq. ft.               1,500 sq. ft.
Minimum Space Width     60 ft.                      15 ft.
Minimum Stand Size      12 ft. x 50 ft. Single Wide
                       24 ft. x 50 ft. Double Wide
Setback of Stands from:
 
Property Lines          20 ft.                      25ft.
Interior Roads          15 ft.
Public Roads            25 ft.
Distance between Stands
Side to Side            25 ft.
Rear to Rear            15 ft.
Parking Spaces
Each Lot                2
Every four (4) Lots     1
Space Size Requirements 9 ft. x 20 ft.
 
   E.   Road Design: Roads within mobile home or recreational camping vehicle
parks shall be improved in accordance with the Manhattan transportation design
and construction standards. The subdivider shall not be required to reserve
right-of-way more than road width. The roadway width, as measured from improved
edge to improved edge shall be:
 
Road with parking on each side    40 feet
Road with parking on one (1) side 32 feet
Roads with no parking             24 feet
 
As determined by the town's engineer, roads within a mobile home or
recreational camping vehicle park may either be public or private.
   F.   Mail Delivery: If mail delivery will not be to each individual space or
unit, the mobile home or recreational camping vehicle park shall provide an
off-road area for mail delivery within the park in cooperation with the United
States post office.
   G.   Driveway: The driveway shall be located to allow convenient access to
the mobile home. The minimum width shall be sixteen feet (16').
   H.   Primary Access: Mobile home and recreational camping vehicle parks
shall have direct access to a collector or arterial road.
   I.   Stand Access: Minimum access width to each mobile home stand shall be
twelve feet (12').
   J.   Second Access: To facilitate traffic, the provision of emergency
services, and the placement of utility easements, the subdivider may be
required to provide all mobile home or recreational camping vehicle parks with
a second access.
   K.   Skirting: Each mobile home shall be skirted within sixty (60) days
after being moved onto a lot within the mobile home park. The skirting shall be
made of fire-resistant material like the material which the mobile home
exterior is constructed.
   L.   Arrangement: Mobile or manufactured home spaces shall be arranged to
permit the practical placement and removal of mobile homes.
   M.   Detached Structures: No detached structure, such as a storage shed, may
be located within five feet (5') of any mobile home or its attached structures.
   N.   Limits Marked: The limits of each mobile home or recreational camping
vehicle space shall be marked on the ground with a suitable means prior to
submittal of the plan for final approval.
   O.   Stand Base Requirements: Each mobile home stand shall be constructed to
provide adequate support for placement of the mobile home, including a stabile
sub base along with an appropriate base material (gravel, concrete, etc.) and
this base material shall be subject to road department approval.
   P.   Tie-Downs: Mobile home stands shall be equipped with anchors or tie-
downs in conformance with the uniform building code.
   Q.   Landscaping: Landscaping may be required to provide a buffer between
mobile home and recreational camping vehicle parks and adjacent properties.
   R.   Recreation Areas: A common recreational area(s) shall be provided in
the mobile or recreational camping vehicle park for use by all tenants and
their invited guests. These areas shall be located to conveniently serve
residents of the entire development, with a minimum total area of four hundred
(400) square feet of recreational space for each mobile or recreational camping
vehicle space. Common recreation areas may include community recreation
buildings and facilities.
   S.   If a Subdivision provides multiple spaces for mobile homes or
recreational camping vehicles is also a "trailer court", "work camp", "youth
camp", or "campground" as those terms are defined in section MCA 50-52-102, the
town council will not grant final approval of the subdivision until the
subdivider obtains a license for the facility from the Montana department of
public health and human services under MCA title 50, chapter 52. (Ord. 24-007,
12-11-2024)
CHAPTER 9
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENTS
SECTION:
11-9-1: Procedures
11-9-2:    Standards
11-9-3:    Administration And Review Process
11-9-4:    Project Design
11-9-5:    Application Requirements
11-9-6:    Legal Requirements
11-9-7:    Standards Of Development
11-9-8:    Conditional Approval
11-9-9:    Approval
11-9-10: Review Criteria
11-9-11: Responsibility For Impact Mitigation:
11-9-12: Appeal Process
11-9-1: PROCEDURES:
   A.   Subject To Procedures: Planned unit developments are subdivisions and
are subject to the procedures contained in chapter 4 of this title.
   B.   Qualifications Required: To qualify as a PUD, the development plan must
promote the clustering of individual building sites, and do one (1) or more of
the following:
      1.   Preserve to the maximum extent possible, the natural characteristics
of the land including topography, vegetation, streams, and other bodies of
water.
      2.   Provide economies in the provision of roads and other public
improvements.
      3.   Preserve productive agricultural land, open space, or riparian
areas.
      4.   Protect important historic sites or structures or areas of important
wildlife habitat.
      5.   Provide developed facilities for recreational purposes. (Ord. 24-
007, 12-11-2024)
11-9-2: STANDARDS:
   A.   Flexibility: For PUDs, flexibility in certain subdivision standards is
provided allowing creativity in subdivision design using cluster development to
promote economies in providing services while preserving and enhancing open
space and unique natural features.
   B.   Design And Improvement Standards: Planned unit developments shall
comply with the appropriate standards contained in chapter 6 of this title
unless proposing alternatives approved by the town council.
   C.   Modification Of Standards: The design and improvement standards
contained in chapter 6 of this title may be modified by the town upon request
of the subdivider where the plan for a PUD includes provisions for efficient
traffic circulation, adequate light, air, and open space and where these
standards are not practical or reasonable in respect to the overall PUD
subdivision design.
   D.   Streets: The arrangement, type, extent, width, grade, and location of
all streets shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned
streets, to topographical conditions and to public convenience and safety.
   E.   Common Open Space: Each planned unit residential development shall
provide at least eleven percent (11%) of the platted area, exclusive of all
other dedications, for common open space. The open space shall be:
      1.   Held in common ownership by a property owner's association; and/or
      2.   Dedicated to public use, if acceptable to the town.
   F.   Dedication And Cash Donation Requirements: The town may waive
dedication and cash donation requirements when the subdivider agrees to create
a property owner's association for the proposed subdivision and the deed to the
association land to be held in perpetuity for use as parks or playgrounds.
   G.   Required Information: The development shall comply with PUD provisions
in title 10 of this code. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-9-3: ADMINISTRATION AND REVIEW PROCESS:
   A.   A PUD shall not be placed in the central business district nor the
parks and open space district.
   B.   A PUD application shall follow the review process outlined below.
      1.   All applications for a planned unit development shall be filed in
the town office accompanied with the appropriate fee prescribed on the adopted
Town of Manhattan fee schedule.
      2.   The town council shall then cause to be made such investigation of
facts bearing on the application as will provide necessary information to
assure that the action on each such application is consistent with the intent
and purpose of this title.
      3.   The planning board shall, after legal notice of not less than
fifteen (15) days, hold a public hearing to review the application. At the
hearing the planning board shall make a recommendation to the town council and
add any relevant conditions to mitigate impacts to the criteria found in
section 10-10-5.
      4.   The town council shall, after legal notice of not less than fifteen
(15) days, hold a public hearing on the application and take testimony from
interested parties. The town council shall then either approve or deny the
application. If the application is denied, reasons for denial should be given.
(Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-9-4: PROJECT DESIGN:
   A.   The applicant may submit any combination of proposed uses to the town
council for a PUD. The combination of uses and their impacts to adjacent owners
within and adjacent to the subject site shall be a primary review criterion.
This includes uses that are not currently defined in the town code.
   B.   The applicant may propose their own standards regarding the following
items for review by the council, adherence to the design standards of the town
is required unless the applicant can provide sufficient reasoning as to their
proposed modifications:
      1.   Density;
      2.   Lot Size;
      3.   Use;
      4.   Height Restrictions;
      5.   Encroachments;
      6.   Alleys;
      7.   Road design (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024).
11-9-5: APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS:
A planned unit development application shall include a plan of development with
the following information:
   A.   A sketch of the proposed site showing existing physical features, i.e.,
topography, trees, streams, structures, streets, utility lines, etc.;
   B.   General information and plans of utility systems and any design plans
or reports as required to ensure that the proposal complies with town
standards;
   C.   Legal description and plat of proposed site;
   D.   Notation of acreage within the proposed site, numbers of lots, typical
lot size, proposed uses of lots, sites for parks and recreation or other public
and quasi-public uses;
   E.   Existing zoning of the proposed site and surrounding area;
   F.   Names, location, and tentative finished grades of all proposed streets;
   G.   Location and design of all proposed structures (should include
distances from streets and property lines and between structures);
   H.   Location and number of proposed parking spaces;
   I.   Proposed design standards and proposed zoning requirements of the PUD;
   J.   Copies of all covenants and legal instruments pertaining to operation
of the planned unit development;
   K.   Impacts and mitigation strategies to the following items:
      1.   Stormwater drainage;
      2.   Snow storage;
      3.   Traffic impacts;
      4.   Community services to include:
         a.   Water;
         b.   Wastewater;
         c.   Traffic;
         d.   Police;
         e.   Fire;
         f.   Emergency Services;
         g.   Other services as identified by town staff, the planning board,
or town council (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024).
11-9-6: LEGAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   In a planned unit development containing areas or facilities of common
or restricted ownership, the subdivision plat, dedication, covenants, and other
recorded legal agreements shall:
      1.   Legally create automatic membership in a nonprofit property owner's
association or similar instrument;
      2.   Place title to any common property or facility in the property
owner's association;
      3.   Appropriately and permanently limit the uses of common property and
open space;
      4.   Give each lot or unit owner the right to use and enjoyment of any
common property or facility;
      5.   Place responsibility for operation and maintenance of the common
property in the property owner's association;
      6.   Place an association charge on each lot or unit in a manner which
will:
      7.   Ensure sufficient funds for maintenance and operation, such charge
to be a lien on the property,
      8.   Provide adequate safeguards for owners against undesirably high
charges.
   B.   Where any of the above are not applicable or suitable, the applicant
may suggest alternative solutions approved by the town council. (Ord. 24-007,
12-11-2024)
11-9-7: STANDARDS OF DEVELOPMENT:
All planned unit developments shall meet or exceed the following standards of
development:
   A.   Adequate and legal water supply. The planned unit development shall
provide proof that they have adequate and legal water supply for their proposed
development.
   B.   Site. Planned unit development sites shall not be exposed to adverse
elements, i.e., smoke, dust, noise, etc., which might create damage to property
or bring harm to occupants.
   C.   Site Size. Site size for planned unit developments shall be appropriate
to the proposed area and design but shall not be less than two (2) acres.
   D.   Off-Street Parking. Off-street parking shall be provided in convenient
locations and in accordance with title 10 of this title.
   E.   Off-Street Loading. Off-street loading shall be provided in accordance
with title 10 of this title.
   F.   Open Space. Not less than eleven percent (11%) of the planned unit
development site shall be designated and maintained as common open space for
the use of the occupants of the development.
   G.   Utilities. Utilities shall be provided in a manner to meet town
specifications.
   H.   Landscaping. Landscaping may be required to provide a buffer between
proposed uses or between different adjacent district classifications. (Ord. 24-
007, 12-11-2024)
11-9-8: CONDITIONAL APPROVAL:
The town council may make the granting of a planned unit development subject to
reasonable limitations or conditions as it may deem necessary to protect the
public health, safety, and welfare and to reduce any impacts to nearby property
or residences.
11-9-9: APPROVAL:
   A.   When the town council gives approval of a planned unit development,
permits shall be issued only in accordance with the approved plan and
stipulated conditions.
   B.   When the town council approves the planned unit development it shall be
noted on the official town zoning map and any future development shall adhere
to the approved PUD design standards. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-9-10: REVIEW CRITERIA:
All proposed planned unit developments shall be reviewed against the criteria
listed in this chapter. The applicant shall clearly demonstrate how the planned
unit development specifically addresses each applicable criterion. In
evaluating a planned unit development proposal, the planning board and town
council may determine that certain criteria are not applicable to a particular
proposal and therefore do not apply to that proposal, and establish other
reasonable review criteria and design standards, guidelines, and policies for
the purpose of implementing and interpreting the provisions of this chapter.
   A.   Assure Accordance With Town Plans And Policies: The proposed
development must be in accordance with the Manhattan city-county growth policy
and other adopted plans and policies of the town, including the purpose and
application of planned unit developments as set forth in sections
10-10-1  and
10-10-2  of this chapter.
   B.   Mitigate Effects On Site And Surrounding Properties: The proposed
development should include adequate measures to mitigate adverse environmental
effects, including noise and glare, on the site and on surrounding properties.
If the project includes dwelling units or is adjacent to a residential zoning
district, architectural and landscape design features should be incorporated to
mitigate the impacts of conflicting land uses.
   C.   Mitigate Effects On Existing And Anticipated Traffic And Parking: The
proposed development should include adequate measures to integrate the project
into the traffic circulation plan of the town and to mitigate the adverse
effects of generated traffic and parking on surrounding properties. Where
feasible, it should incorporate and support non-automobile transportation
modes, such as pedestrian and bicycle paths.
   D.   Conform To Engineering Standards: The proposed development should
comply with all town engineering standards and specifications, including those
for water supply, sanitary sewers, utilities and streets, and pedestrian and
vehicular ingress and egress, including accessibility for persons with
disabilities.
   E.   Provide Appropriate Landscaping And Open Space: The proposed site
design should preserve agricultural land where possible, and should create
usable open space for recreational, relaxation or other appropriate uses by
residents and employees, and by the public where appropriate. Existing natural
vegetation in unbuilt areas should be preserved or suitably replaced if
disturbed, in harmony with the existing character of the town.
   F.   Preserve Historic Resources: If the site includes any designated or
potentially significant historic buildings, structures, sites, or objects,
measures should be taken to preserve them and incorporate them into the
development, where such measures will not cause undue hardship.
   G.   Respect Historical Identity: The proposed development should be
harmonious with and integrated into the historical identity of the town, as in
building orientation, street and alley grid, sidewalk patterns and other
features of the town's public spaces. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-9-11: RESPONSIBILITY FOR IMPACT MITIGATION:
   A.   Simultaneous Development: When two (2) adjacent parcels are developed
simultaneously, the responsibility for mitigating conflicts is upon the more
intense use.
   B.   First To Develop: When a use is the first to develop on two (2)
adjacent vacant parcels, the first use shall provide the necessary buffer to
any reasonable future use as determined by the town council.
   C.   Existing Development: When a development is proposed adjacent to an
existing developed parcel, the responsibility for mitigating conflicts with and
adverse impacts on the developed parcel is upon the proposed use. (Ord. 24-007,
12-11-2024)
11-9-12: APPEAL PROCESS:
Any person or persons, jointly or severally aggrieved by any decision of the
town council, may present to a court of record a petition, duly verified,
setting forth that such decision is illegal, in whole or in part, specifying
the grounds of the illegality. Such petition shall be presented to the court
within thirty (30) days after the filing of the decision of the office of the
council. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
CHAPTER 10
ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
11-10-1: Schedule Of Fees
11-10-2: Variances
11-10-3: Violations
11-10-4: Penalty For Violations
11-10-5: Appeals
11-10-6: Vacating Recorded Plats
11-10-7: Amendments
11-10-1: SCHEDULE OF FEES:
A schedule of fees, charges, and expenses to be paid by subdividers to defray
the expense of general subdivision review and any inspections necessary for
plan approval at town hall or on the town's website. No action shall be taken
on applications or appeals until all fees have been fully paid. Applications
for subdivision approval shall not be accepted unless accompanied by all
required fees. Review fees are nonrefundable. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-10-2: VARIANCES:
   A.   Power To Grant: Where the town council finds extraordinary hardships or
practical difficulties may result from strict compliance with this title, or
the purpose of this title may be served to a greater extent by an alternative
proposal, it may approve variances from this title so that substantial justice
may be done and the public interest secure; provided, that a variance shall not
have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of this title.
   B.   Criteria: The town council shall not approve variances unless it makes
findings based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case that:
      1.   The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public
health, safety, or general welfare or injurious to other adjoining properties;
      2.   The conditions on which the request for a variance is based are
unique to the property on which the variance is sought and are not applicable
generally to other property;
      3.   Because of the physical surroundings, shape, or topographical
conditions of the specific property involved, a particular hardship to the
owner would result as distinct from an inconvenience, if this title are
strictly enforced;
      4.   The variance will not cause a substantial increase in public costs;
and
      5.   The variances will in no manner place the subdivision in
nonconformance with title 10 of this code or the Manhattan growth policy or
other such long range adopted document.
   C.   Conditions: In approving variances, the town council may require such
conditions as will meet substantially the objectives of the standards of the
regulations.
   D.   Procedures: A petition for any variance shall be submitted in writing
by the subdivider when the sketch plan or preliminary plat is initially
presented to the planning office for review and approval. The petition shall
state the grounds for the requested variance.
   E.   Statement Of Fact: When any such variance is granted, the motion of
approval of the proposed subdivision must contain a statement describing the
variance and the facts and conditions upon the issuance of the variance is
based. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-10-3: VIOLATIONS:
Every final subdivision plat must be filed for record with the Gallatin County
clerk and recorder before title to the subdivided land can be sold or
transferred in any manner. If unlawful transfers are made, the town attorney
shall commence action to enjoin further sales or transfers and compel
compliance with all provisions of the MSPA and this title. The cost of such
action shall be imposed against the party not prevailing. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-
2024)
11-10-4: PENALTY FOR VIOLATIONS:
Any person who violates any provision of the MSPA or this title is guilty of a
municipal infraction and shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as set
forth in section
1-4-2  of this code. Each sale, lease, or transfer, or offer of sale, lease, or
transfer of each separate parcel of land in violation of any provision of the
MSPA or this title shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 24-
007, 12-11-2024)
11-10-5: APPEALS:
Appeals can be made as stated in MCA 76-3-625. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-10-6: VACATING RECORDED PLATS:
Any plat prepared and recorded may be vacated, in whole or in part, as provided
by MCA 7-5- 2501, 7-5-2502, 7-14-2616(1) and (2), 7-14-2617, 7-14-4114(1) and
(2), 7-14-4115, and MCA 76-3-305. Utility easements shall remain intact for
continued operation and maintenance of public utility facilities. (Ord. 24-007,
12-11-2024)
11-10-7: AMENDMENTS:
Before the town amends this title, it shall hold a public hearing and shall
give public notice of its intent to amend this title and of the public hearing
by publishing notice of the time and place of the hearing in a newspaper of
general circulation in Gallatin County not less than fifteen (15) days and not
more than thirty (30) days prior to hearing date. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
CHAPTER 11
APPENDICES
SECTION:
11-11-1: Appendix A, Environmental Assessment And/Or Guidelines To Prepare
Findings Of Fact
11-11-2: Appendix B, Subdivision Improvements Guarantee Procedures
11-11-3: Appendix C, Sample Forms, Notices And Certificates
11-11-4: Appendix D, Fee Schedule
11-11-5: Appendix E, Subdivision Appeal Process
11-11-6: Appendix F, Developing A Major Subdivision
11-11-7: Appendix G, Developing A Minor Subdivision
11-11-8: Appendix H, Preliminary Plat Form, Contents And Supplements
11-11-1: APPENDIX A, ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT AND/OR GUIDELINES TO PREPARE
FINDINGS OF FACT:
General Instructions
Using available information the subdivider shall provide responses to the
following questions and provide materials as required. Sources of information
must be identified for each section of the assessment. Preparation of the
environmental assessment shall adhere to the following outline and shall be
identified with the appropriate section, heading, number and letter. On-site
inspections may be made regarding any question. Falsification or omission of
any part of the questionnaire shall constitute grounds for rejection of the
application for plat approval.
I.   DESCRIPTION OF ENVIRONMENTAL FEATURES
Describe the following environmental features, provide responses to the
following questions and provide reference materials as required.
   A.   Surface Water
      1.   Locate on a plat overlay or sketch map:
         a.   Any ditches and irrigation systems (also indicate the names,
sizes and present uses of each).
         b.   Time when water is present (seasonally or all year).
         c.   Any areas subject to flood hazard, or in delineated 100-year
floodplains.
   B.   Groundwater
      Using available data, provide the following information:
      1.   The minimum depth to water table and identify dates when depths were
determined.
   C.   Topography, Geology and Soils
      1.   Provide a map of the topography of the area to be subdivided and an
evaluation of suitability for the proposed land uses. Address conditions such
as:
         a.   In considering any unusual conditions, specifically address any
problems which may be encountered in excavating for:
            1)   Basements
            2)   Water supply trenches
            3)   Underground electrical and telephone lines
      2.   Locate on an overlay or sketch map:
         a.   Any known hazards affecting the development which could result in
property damage or personal injury due to:
            1)   Seismic activity.
            2)   High water table.
      3.   Describe measures proposed to prevent or reduce these dangers.
      4.   Describe the location and amount of any cut or fill more than three
(3) feet in depth. Indicate these cuts or fills on a plat overlay or sketch
map. Where cuts or fills are necessary, describe plans to prevent erosion and
to promote vegetation such as replacement of topsoil and grading.
   D.   Vegetation
      1.   On a plat overlay or sketch map:
         a.   Indicate the distribution of the major vegetation types, such as
marsh, grassland, shrub, deciduous forest, mixed forest.
         b.   Identify the location of critical plant communities such as:
            1)   Stream bank or shoreline vegetation
            2)   Vegetation on soils highly susceptible to wind or water
erosion
            3)   Type and extent of noxious weeds
      2.   Describe measures to:
         a.   Preserve trees and other natural vegetation (e.g. locating roads
and lot boundaries, planning construction to avoid damaging tree cover).
         b.   Protect critical plant communities (e.g. keeping structural
development away from these areas, setting areas aside for open space).
         c.   Prevent and control grass, brush or forest fires (e.g. green
strips, water supply, access).
         d.   Measures to control noxious weeds.
II.   SUMMARY OF PROBABLE IMPACTS
Provide a summary of the probable impacts of the proposed subdivision on the
following criteria.
   A.   Effects on Agriculture and Agricultural Water User Facilities
      Summarize the effects of the proposed subdivision on agriculture. Provide
responses to the following questions and provide reference materials as
required.
      1.   Would the subdivision remove agricultural land with significant
existing or potential production capacity?
      2.   Would the subdivision remove from production agricultural lands
which are critical to the area's agricultural operation (e.g. removing key
irrigated lands, winter pastures or hay lands which may limit the overall
livestock production)?
      3.   Would the subdivision create a significant conflict with nearby
agricultural operations (e.g. residential development creating problems for
moving livestock, operating farm machinery, maintaining and operating
irrigation systems, controlling weeds or applying pesticides; or would
agricultural operations suffer from vandalism, uncontrolled pets or damaged
fences)?
      4.   Would the subdivision generate nuisance complaints or problems (e.g.
dust, odor or noise from agricultural operations, safety hazards to residents
or water problems from irrigation, straying farm animals, or pesticide
application)?
      5.   How would the subdivision affect the value of nearby agricultural
lands:
         a.   Would the market, mortgage and taxable value of nearby
agricultural land increase?
         b.   Would the increased market value and the conditions in 2, 3, and
4 above encourage further land division or otherwise remove land from
production?
         c.   Would the cost of providing additional educational and other
public facilities result in higher mill levies on agricultural properties?
   B.   Effects on Local Services
      Summarize the effects of the proposed subdivision on local services.
Provide responses to the following questions and provide reference materials as
required.
      1.   Indicate the proposed use and number of lots or spaces in each:
              Residential, single family
              Residential, multiple family
              Types of multiple family structures and number of each (e.g.
duplex, 4-plex)
              Planned unit development (No. of units)
              Condominium (No. of units)
              Mobile Home Park
              Recreational Vehicle Park
              Commercial or Industrial
              Other (Please describe)
      2.   What additional or expanded public services and facilities would be
demanded of the Town of Manhattan to serve the subdivision?
         a.   What additional costs would result for services such as streets,
bridges, law enforcement, parks and recreation, fire protection, water, sewer,
and solid waste systems, or schools (including additional personnel, equipment,
construction, and maintenance costs).
         b.   Who would bear these costs (e.g. all taxpayers within the
jurisdiction, people within special taxing districts, or users of a service)?
         c.   Can the service providers meet the additional costs given legal
or other constraints (e.g. statutory ceilings on mill levies or bonded
indebtedness)?
      3.   What are the present tax revenues received from the unsubdivided
land?
         a.   By Gallatin County $____________________
         b.   By the Town of Manhattan if applicable $____________________
         c.   By the school(s) $____________________
      4.   What would be the approximate revenues received by each above taxing
authority if the lots are reclassified, and when the lots are all improved and
built upon? What other taxes would be paid by the subdivision and into what
funds (e.g. personal property taxes on mobile homes are paid into the County
general fund)?
      5.   Would new taxes generated from the subdivision cover additional
public costs?
      6.   How many special improvement districts would be created which would
obligate the Town of Manhattan fiscally or administratively?
      7.   Are any bonding plans proposed which would affect the Town of
Manhattan's bonded indebtedness?
   C.   Effects on the Natural Environment, Historic Buildings, Features, and
Sites
      Summarize the effects of the proposed subdivision on the natural
environment, historic buildings, features, and sites. Provide responses to the
following questions and provide reference materials as required.
      1.   Describe and locate on a plat overlay or sketch map known or
possible historic, archaeological, paleontological or cultural sites, and
structures or objects which may be affected by the proposed subdivision.
      2.   Describe plans to protect these sites.
      3.   How would the subdivision affect the townscape of Manhattan (e.g.
visual features within the subdivision or on adjacent land)? Describe efforts
to visually blend the proposed development with the existing environment (e.g.
architecture, use of appropriate building materials, colors, street design,
underground utilities and revegetation of earthworks).
   D.   Effects on Wildlife and Wildlife Habitat
      Summarize the effects of the proposed subdivision on wildlife and
wildlife habitat. Provide responses to the following questions and provide
reference materials as required.
      1.   List species of wildlife which use the area affected by the proposed
subdivision. Describe how the subdivision or any access road affect critical
wildlife areas such as migration routes, nesting areas, wetlands or important
habitat for rare or endangered species?
      2.   How would pets or human activity affect wildlife?
   E.   Effects on the Public Health and Safety
      Summarize the effects of the proposed subdivision on public health and
safety. Describe any health or safety hazards on or near the subdivision, such
as: natural hazards, drainage problems, heavy traffic, dilapidated structures,
high pressure gas lines, high voltage power lines or irrigation ditches. These
conditions, proposed or existing, should be accurately described with their
origin and location identified. Provide responses to the following questions
and provide reference materials as required.
      1.   Would the subdivision be subject to hazardous conditions due to
highways, railroads, dilapidated structures, high pressure gas lines,
irrigation ditches, or adjacent industrial uses?
      2.   Describe land uses adjacent to the subdivision, and how the
subdivision will affect the adjacent land uses. What existing uses such as feed
lots, processing plants or industrial firms could be subject to law suits or
complaints from residents of the subdivision?
      3.   What public health or safety hazards, such as dangerous traffic or
fire conditions or contamination of water supplies, would be created by the
subdivision?
   F.   Compliance with survey requirements, local subdivision regulations and
review procedures.
      Summarize compliance with survey requirements, local subdivision
regulations and review procedures. Provide responses to the following questions
and provide reference materials as required.
      1.   Does the subdivision meet the requirements of the Montana
Subdivision and Platting Act, the surveying requirements specified in the
Uniform Standards for Monumentation, and these subdivision regulations? (Note
any requirements the proposed subdivision does not comply with, and note any
variance requested.)
      2.   Has the subdivision review procedure been complied with? (Note any
areas where deviations have occurred from the procedures contained in these
regulations.)
   G.   Provision of easements for the location and installation of any planned
utilities.
      Summarize provision of easements for the location and installation of any
planned utilities. Provide responses to the following questions and provide
reference materials as required.
      1.   Indicate what utilities will be supplied.
      2.   Indicate the utility companies providing electrical power, natural
gas, or telephone service. To what extent will these utilities be placed
underground? What arrangements have been made to secure these utilities?
      3.   Describe proposed street lighting and who will provide it.
      4.   Has the preliminary plat been submitted to affected utilities for
review?
      5.   Estimate the completion date of each utility installation.
      6.   Does the subdivision provide easements for the location and
installation of utilities as specified in these regulations?
      7.   Are all easements, both proposed and existing, clearly noted on the
face of the plat?
III.   COMMUNITY IMPACT REPORT
Provide a community impact report containing a statement of estimated number of
people coming into the area as a result of the subdivision, anticipated needs
of the proposed subdivision for public facilities and services, the increased
capital and operating cost to each affected unit of local government. Provide
responses to the following questions and provide reference materials as
required.
   A.   Education
      1.   Estimate the number of school children that will be added by the
proposed subdivision. Provide a statement from the administrator of the
affected school system indicating whether the increased enrollment can be
accommodated by the present personnel and facilities. If not, estimate the
increased expenditures that would be necessary to do so.
   B.   Streets and Maintenance
      1.   Estimate how much daily traffic the subdivision, when fully
occupied, will generate on existing streets and arterials.
         a.   Describe the capability of existing and proposed streets to
safely accommodate this increased traffic.
         b.   Describe increased maintenance problems and increased cost due to
this increase in volume.
      2.   Describe proposed new public or private access streets including:
         a.   Measures for disposing of storm runoff from streets.
         b.   Type of road surface.
         c.   Facilities for streams or drainage crossing (e.g. culverts,
bridges).
         d.   Seeding of disturbed areas.
      3.   Describe the closing or modification of any existing streets.
      4.   Explain why street access was not provided within the subdivision,
if access to any individual lot is directly from arterial streets or roads.
      5.   Estimate the cost and completion date of the system, and indicate
who will pay the cost of installation, maintenance and snow removal.
   C.   Water, Sewage, and Solid Waste Facilities
      1.   Describe estimated impacts on the existing system, and show evidence
that permission has been granted to hook up to the existing system.
      2.   All water supply and sewage treatment plans and specifications will
be reviewed and approved by the Montana Department of Environmental Quality
(MDEQ) and should be submitted using the appropriate MDEQ subdivision form or
the MDEQ/Local Government Joint Application Form.
      3.   Describe the proposed method of collecting and disposing of solid
waste from the development.
      4.   If use of an existing collection system or disposal facility is
proposed indicate the name and location of the facility.
   D.   Fire and Police Protection
      Can the fire and police protection service needs of the proposed
subdivision be met by present personnel and facilities? If not, what additional
expense would be necessary to make these services adequate, and who would pay
the costs?
   E.   Payment for Extension of Capital Facilities
      Indicate how the subdivider will pay for the cost of extending capital
facilities resulting from expected impacts directly attributable to the
subdivision.
IV.   CONFORMANCE TO MASTER PLAN
   A.   Indicate whether or not the subdivision plat conforms to Manhattan Area
Master Plan.
(1977 Code title 13 app.)
11-11-2: APPENDIX B, SUBDIVISION IMPROVEMENTS GUARANTEE PROCEDURES:
In lieu of the completion of the construction of any public improvements prior
to approval of the final plat, the subdivider shall provide or cause to be
provided a bond or other reasonable security, in an amount and with surety and
conditions satisfactory to the town of Manhattan, providing for and securing
the construction and installation of the improvements, in accordance with the
specifications set out in section
11-4-2-8 of this title. The following procedures and requirements shall apply:
   A.   Improvements; Standards; Time Limits: The town of Manhattan shall
specify the improvements that may be completed after the final plat is
approved. The town of Manhattan shall specify that the improvements must be
constructed to standards included in these regulations and other standards the
town of Manhattan may adopt. Those improvements shall include streets, roads,
bridges, culverts, curbs, gutters, drainage ditches, water systems, sewage
systems, sidewalks, walkways, streetlights, street signs, road right of way
clearings, solid waste facilities, park and recreation facilities, mobile home
pads and other improvements as required by the town of Manhattan. The town of
Manhattan shall specify a deadline for completion of the improvements. All
improvements shall be completed no later than eighteen (18) months from the
date the final plat is filed with the clerk and recorder. The town of Manhattan
may grant one extension of up to one year, unless otherwise agreed to by the
town.
   B.   Projected Costs: The subdivider shall provide three (3) bids for the
cost of installation of the public improvements. The town of Manhattan may
direct the city engineer or designated representatives to review all
improvements, plans and specifications and projected costs of completing the
improvements.
   C.   Improvements Agreement: The subdivider shall enter into an improvements
agreement which shall follow the model subdivision improvements agreement
contained in appendix C, form 5 of this chapter.
   D.   Improvements Guarantee: The subdivider shall provide a guarantee that
the improvements will be completed. The guarantee shall have a value equal to
one hundred fifty percent (150%) of the highest of the three (3) bids provided
by the developer for the projected costs of completing improvements. The
guarantee shall specify procedures for the town of Manhattan to obtain the
funds should the subdivider fail to satisfactorily complete the improvements.
The types of guarantees acceptable to the town of Manhattan are described in
subsection H of this section. The method of guarantee shall be subject to town
of Manhattan approval.
   E.   Inspection And Certification:
      1.   Upon completion of required improvements, the subdivider shall file
with the town of Manhattan a statement certifying that:
         a.   All required improvements are complete.
         b.   These improvements are in compliance with the minimum standards
specified by the town of Manhattan for their construction.
         c.   The subdivider knows of no defects in these improvements.
         d.   These improvements are free and clear of any encumbrance or
liens.
         e.   All applicable fees and surcharges have been paid.
      2.   The subdivider shall also file with the town of Manhattan copies of
final plans, profiles, grades and specifications for improvements.
      3.   The town of Manhattan will provide for inspection of all required
improvements by the city engineer or a designated representative before final
plat approval when installation is a condition of approval or before releasing
the subdivider from the subdivision improvements agreement. Upon completion of
the inspection, the inspecting engineer shall file with the town of Manhattan a
statement either certifying that the improvements have been completed in the
required manner or listing the defects in those improvements. Only after the
inspecting engineer certifies that the improvements are complete and free from
defect, and after receipt of the other statements detailed above, the town of
Manhattan shall completely release the subdivider from the subdivision
improvements agreement.
   F.   Reduction And Release Of Guarantee: The town of Manhattan shall reduce
bond requirements commensurate with the completion of improvements as specified
in the improvements agreement. The proportion of the collateral released may
not exceed the proportion which the improvements completed represent of all
originally required improvements. An inspection of the completed portion will
be required. Upon acceptance of the final portion of improvements, the town of
Manhattan shall authorize the release of the remaining portion of the
improvement guarantee.
Prior to the release of the guarantee, a copy of the plans, stamped by the
project surveyor or engineer in accordance with their licensing provision,
shall be filed in the clerk and recorder's office with reference to the final
subdivision plat.
   G.   Failure To Satisfactorily Complete Improvements: If the town of
Manhattan determines that any improvements are not constructed in compliance
with the agreed specifications, it shall furnish the subdivider with a list of
specific deficiencies and may withhold collateral sufficient to ensure proper
completion. If the town of Manhattan determines that the subdivider will not
construct any or all of the improvements to required specifications, or within
time limits, it may withdraw collateral and use these funds to construct the
improvements to meet specifications. Unused portions of these funds shall be
returned to the subdivider or crediting institution.
   H.   Acceptable Forms Of Improvements Guarantees: The subdivider shall
provide a financial security guarantee from the following listed methods in the
amount of one hundred fifty percent (150%) of the highest bid for the estimated
total cost of installing all required improvements.
      1.   Escrow Account: The subdivider shall deposit cash, or collateral
readily convertible to cash at face value, either with the town of Manhattan or
in escrow with an escrow agency. The use of collateral other than cash, and the
selection of the escrow agency where funds are to be deposited must be approved
by the town of Manhattan. Where an escrow account is to be used, the subdivider
shall give the town of Manhattan his agreement with the escrow agency
guaranteeing the following:
         a.   That the funds in the escrow account are to be held in trust
until released by the town of Manhattan and may not be used or pledged by the
subdivider as security for any other obligation during that period.
         b.   That, should the subdivider fail to complete the required
improvements, the escrow agency shall immediately make the funds in escrow
available to the town of Manhattan for completing these improvements.
      2.   Surety Performance Bond: The subdivider shall provide a surety
performance bond which shall be executed by a surety company authorized to do
business in the state of Montana and acceptable as a surety to the town of
Manhattan and countersigned by a Montana agent. The bond shall be payable to
the town of Manhattan. The bond shall be in a form which can be reduced
incrementally and shall be in effect until the completed improvements are
accepted by the town of Manhattan.
      3.   Sequential Development: In lieu of requiring a bond or other means
of security for the construction or installation of the required public
improvements, the town of Manhattan may approve an incremental payment or
guarantee plan. The improvements in a prior increment must be completed or the
payment or guarantee of payment for the costs of the improvements incurred in a
