11-12-1: ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT AND/OR GUIDELINES TO PREPARE FINDINGS OF
FACT:
General Instructions
Using available information, the subdivider shall provide responses to the
following questions and provide materials as required. Sources of information
must be identified for each section of the assessment. Preparation of the
environmental assessment shall adhere to the following outline and shall be
identified with the appropriate section, heading, number, and letter. On-site
inspections may be made regarding any question. Falsification or omission of
any part of the questionnaire shall constitute grounds for rejection of the
application for plat approval. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-12-1-1: DESCRIPTION OF ENVIRONMENTAL FEATURES:
Describe the following review criteria, provide responses to the following
questions, and provide reference materials as required.
   A.   Agriculture:
      1.   Locate on a map the following:
         a.   Any lands currently or seasonally used for livestock production
that are part of the subdivision or within two thousand six hundred feet
(2,600') of the site.
         b.   Any lands currently used for hay or crops that are part of the
subdivision or within two thousand six hundred feet (2,600') of the site.
         c.   Any information regarding agriculture traffic or access and how
the proposed subdivision may impact this.
         d.   Any soil types designated as prime farmland, prime farmland if
irrigated, farmland of statewide importance, farmland of local importance by
the natural resources conservation service.
   B.   Agricultural Water User Facilities:
      1.   Locate on a map the following:
         a.   Any irrigation ditch, lateral, or any other element of an
agricultural water user facility.
         b.   Provide written agreements from each ditch company's authorized
representative approving the work or methods of impact mitigation from the
development of the subdivision. The subdivider must provide this agreement to
the town and the town must approve the agreement prior to any work being
completed on the site. This includes staging of materials and equipment, and
any dirt work on the site.
   C.   Local Services:
      1.   Provide the following:
         a.   A map showing distance from all proposed lots to the Town of
Manhattan police station, Manhattan rural fire department, and emergency room.
         b.   Calculation of the total miles of roadway to be maintained by the
town if the subdivision is approved.
         c.   Acres of parkland to be included and the expected annual cost of
maintenance.
   D.   Natural Environment:
      1.   Provide the following on a map:
         a.   Existing trees, native vegetation, and topography lines at three-
foot (3') intervals.
         b.   Soils map from the NRCS.
      2.   Provide the following information:
         a.   Mitigation strategies to decrease erosion.
         b.   Mitigation strategies to ensure that the development will not
lead to the spread of noxious weeds.
         c.   The direction and amount of runoff expected during the
construction period.
      3.   On a plat overlay or sketch map:
         a.   Indicate the distribution of the major vegetation types, such as
marsh, grassland, shrub, deciduous forest, mixed forest.
         b.   Identify the location of critical plant communities such as:
            (1)   Stream bank or shoreline vegetation.
            (2)   Vegetation on soils highly susceptible to wind or water
erosion.
            (3)   Type and extent of noxious weeds.
      4.   Describe measures to:
         a.   Preserve trees and other natural vegetation (e.g. locating roads
and lot boundaries, planning construction to avoid damaging tree cover).
         b.   Protect critical plant communities (e.g. keeping structural
development away from these areas, setting areas aside for open space).
         c.   Prevent and control grass, brush, or forest fires (e.g. green
strips, water supply, access).
   E.   Measures To Control Noxious Weeds:
      1.   Approved Weed Plan from the Gallatin County Weed District.
   F.   Groundwater:
      1.   Using available data, provide the following information:
         a.   The average minimum depth to groundwater table and identify dates
when depths were determined.
         b.   Any impacts from the placement of wells or infrastructure for the
project on any groundwater
         c.   The availability of water in a physical and legal capacity to be
used for the development.
         d.   The source of the adequate and legal water supply for the
development if from groundwater.
   G.   Surface Water:
      1.   Locate on a map:
         a.   Any ditches and irrigation systems (also indicate the names,
sizes, and present uses of each).
         b.   Time when water is present (seasonally or all year).
         c.   Any areas subject to flood hazard, or in special flood hazard
area as defined by the federal emergency management agency.
         d.   Any natural waterbody or waterway including but not limited to
creeks, rivers, streams, ponds, lakes, and wetlands.
         e.   The source of the adequate and legal water supply for the
development if from surface water.
   H.   Topography, Geology And Soils:
      1.   Provide a map of the topography of the area to be subdivided and an
evaluation of suitability for the proposed land uses. Address conditions such
as:
         a.   In considering any unusual conditions, specifically address any
problems which may be encountered in excavating for:
            (1)   Basements.
            (2)   Water supply trenches.
            (3)   Underground electrical and telephone lines.
      2.   Locate on an overlay or sketch map:
         a.   Any known hazards affecting the development which could result in
property damage or personal injury due to:
            (1)   Seismic activity.
            (2)   High water table.
         b.   Describe measures proposed to prevent or reduce these dangers.
      3.   Describe the location and amount of any cut or fill more than three
(3) feet in depth. Indicate these cuts or fills on a plat overlay or sketch
map. Where cuts or fills are necessary, describe plans to prevent erosion and
to promote vegetation such as replacement of topsoil and grading.
   I.   Wildlife:
      1.   Provide the following:
         a.   Any observed wildlife on the property.
         b.   Mitigation strategies between existing wildlife and the
developments impact on the wildlife.
   J.   Wildlife Habitat:
      1.   Provide the following:
         a.   Adjacency to any conservation easements.
         b.   Adjacency of the project to any wildlife corridor as defined in
the Gallatin Valley Sensitive Lands Document.
         c.   Pollinator vegetation that are present on the parcel.
   K.   Public Health And Safety:
      1.   Describe potential traffic impacts that may increase conflicts with
other vehicular traffic, pedestrian traffics, and bicycles.
      2.   Potential concerns to public health and safety during the
construction period. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-12-1-2: SUMMARY OF PROBABLE IMPACTS:
Provide a summary of the probable impacts of the proposed subdivision on the
following criteria.
   A.   Effects On Agriculture And Agricultural Water User Facilities:
      1.   Summarize the effects of the proposed subdivision on agriculture.
Provide responses to the following questions and provide reference materials as
required.
         a.   Would the subdivision remove agricultural land with significant
existing or potential production capacity?
         b.   Would the subdivision remove from production agricultural lands
which are critical to the area's agricultural operation (e.g. removing key
irrigated lands, winter pastures or hay lands which may limit the overall
livestock production)?
         c.   Would the subdivision create a significant conflict with nearby
agricultural operations (e.g. residential development creating problems for
moving livestock, operating farm machinery, maintaining and operating
irrigation systems, controlling weeds or applying pesticides; or would
agricultural operations suffer from vandalism, uncontrolled pets, or damaged
fences)?
      2.   Including proof and data showing that there will be minimal to no
impacts to any agricultural water sources.
         d.   Would the subdivision generate nuisance complaints or problems
(e.g. dust, odor or noise from agricultural operations, safety hazards to
residents or water problems from irrigation, straying farm animals, or
pesticide application)?
         e.   How would the subdivision affect the value of nearby agricultural
lands:
            (1)   Would the market, mortgage, and taxable value of nearby
agricultural land increase?
            (2)   Would the increased market value and the conditions in 2, 3,
and 4 above encourage further land division or otherwise remove land from
production?
            (3)   Would the cost of providing additional educational and other
public facilities result in higher mill levies on agricultural properties?
   B.   Effects On Local Services:
      1.   Summarize the effects of the proposed subdivision on local services.
Provide responses to the following questions and provide reference materials as
required:
         a.   Indicate the proposed use and number of lots or spaces in each.
         b.   Residential, single family.
         c.   Residential, multiple family.
         d.   Types of multiple family structures and number of each (e.g.
duplex, 4-plex).
         e.   Planned unit development (No. of units).
         f.   Condominium (No. of units).
         g.   Mobile home park.
         h.   Recreational vehicle park.
         i.   Commercial or industrial.
         j.   Other (Please describe).
      2.   What additional or expanded public services and facilities would be
demanded of the town to serve the subdivision?
      3.   What additional costs would result for services such as streets,
bridges, law enforcement, parks and recreation, fire protection, water, sewer,
and solid waste systems, or schools (including additional personnel, equipment,
construction, and maintenance costs).
      4.   Who would bear these costs (e.g. all taxpayers within the
jurisdiction, people within special taxing districts, or users of a service)?
      5.   Can the service providers meet the additional costs given legal or
other constraints (e.g. statutory ceilings on mill levies or bonded
indebtedness)?
      6.   What are the present tax revenues received from the unsubdivided
land?
         a.   By the county.
         b.   By the town if applicable.
         c.   By the school(s).
      7.   What would be the approximate revenues received by each above taxing
authority if the lots are reclassified, and when the lots are all improved and
built upon? What other taxes would be paid by the subdivision and into what
funds (e.g. personal property taxes on mobile homes are paid into the county
general fund)?
      8.   Would new taxes generated from the subdivision cover additional
public costs?
      9.   How many special improvement districts would be created which would
obligate the town fiscally or administratively?
      10.   Are any bonding plans proposed which would affect the town's bonded
indebtedness?
   C.   Effects On The Natural Environment, Historic Buildings, Features, And
Sites:
      1.   Summarize the effects of the proposed subdivision on the natural
environment, historic buildings, features, and sites. Provide responses to the
following questions and provide reference materials as required.
         a.   Describe and locate on a plat overlay or sketch map known or
possible historic, archaeological, paleontological, or cultural sites, and
structures or objects which may be affected by the proposed subdivision.
         b.   Describe plans to protect these sites.
         c.   How would the subdivision affect the Townscape of Manhattan (e.g.
visual features within the subdivision or on adjacent land)? Describe efforts
to visually blend the proposed development with the existing environment (e.g.
architecture, use of appropriate building materials, colors, street design,
underground utilities, and revegetation of earthworks).
   D.   Effects On Wildlife And Wildlife Habitat:
      1.   Summarize the effects of the proposed subdivision on wildlife and
wildlife habitat. Provide responses to the following questions and provide
reference materials as required.
         a.   List species of wildlife which use the area affected by the
proposed subdivision. Describe how the subdivision or any access road affect
critical wildlife areas such as migration routes, nesting areas, wetlands, or
important habitat for rare or endangered species?
         b.   How would pets or human activity affect wildlife?
   E.   Effects On The Public Health And Safety:
      1.   Summarize the effects of the proposed subdivision on public health
and safety. Describe any health or safety hazards on or near the subdivision,
such as: natural hazards, drainage problems, heavy traffic, dilapidated
structures, high pressure gas lines, high voltage power lines or irrigation
ditches. These conditions, proposed or existing, should be accurately described
with their origin and location identified. Provide responses to the following
questions and provide reference materials as required.
         a.   Would the subdivision be subject to hazardous conditions due to
highways, railroads, dilapidated structures, high pressure gas lines,
irrigation ditches, or adjacent industrial uses?
         b.   Describe land uses adjacent to the subdivision, and how the
subdivision will affect the adjacent land uses. What existing uses such as feed
lots, processing plants or industrial firms could be subject to law suits or
complaints from residents of the subdivision?
         c.   What public health or safety hazards, such as dangerous traffic
or fire conditions or contamination of water supplies, would be created by the
subdivision?
   F.   Compliance with survey requirements, local subdivision regulations and
review procedures.
   G.   Provision of easements for the location and installation of any planned
utilities.
      1.   Summarize provision of easements for the location and installation
of any planned utilities. Provide responses to the following questions and
provide reference materials as required.
      2.   Indicate what utilities will be supplied.
      3.   Indicate the utility companies providing electrical power, natural
gas, or telephone service. To what extent will these utilities be placed
underground? What arrangements have been made to secure these utilities?
      4.   Describe proposed street lighting and who will provide it.
      5.   Has the preliminary plat been submitted to affected utilities for
review?
      6.   Does the subdivision provide easements for the location and
installation of utilities as specified in these regulations?
      7.   Are all easements, both proposed and existing, clearly noted on the
face of the plat? (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-12-1-3: COMMUNITY IMPACT REPORT:
Provide a community impact report containing a statement of estimated number of
people coming into the area because of the subdivision, anticipated needs of
the proposed subdivision for public facilities and services, the increased
capital and operating cost to each affected unit of local government. Provide
responses to the following questions and provide reference materials as
required.
   A.   Education:
      1.   Estimate the number of school children that will be added by the
proposed subdivision. Provide a statement from the administrator of the
affected school system indicating whether the increased enrollment can be
accommodated by the present personnel and facilities. If not, estimate the
increased expenditures that would be necessary to do so.
   B.   Streets And Maintenance:
      1.   Estimate how much daily traffic the subdivision, when fully
occupied, will generate on existing streets and arterials.
         a.   Describe the capability of existing and proposed streets to
safely accommodate this increased traffic.
         b.   Describe increased maintenance problems and increased cost due to
this increase in volume.
      2.   Describe proposed new public or private access streets including:
         a.   Measures for disposing of storm runoff from streets.
         b.   Type of road surface.
         c.   Facilities for streams or drainage crossing (e.g. culverts,
bridges).
         d.   Seeding of disturbed areas.
      3.   Describe the closing or modification of any existing streets.
      4.   Explain why street access was not provided within the subdivision,
if access to any individual lot is directly from arterial streets or roads.
      5.   Estimate the cost and completion date of the system, and indicate
who will pay the cost of installation, maintenance, and snow removal.
   C.   Water, Sewage, And Solid Waste Facilities:
      1.   Describe estimated impacts on the existing system, and show evidence
that permission has been granted to hook up to the existing system.
      2.   All water supply and sewage treatment plans and specifications will
be reviewed and approved by the Montana department of environmental quality
(MDEQ) and should be submitted using the appropriate MDEQ subdivision form or
the MDEQ/local government joint application form.
      3.   Describe the proposed method of collecting and disposing of solid
waste from the development.
      4.   If use of an existing collection system or disposal facility is
proposed indicate the name and location of the facility.
   D.   Fire And Police Protection:
      1.   Can present personnel and facilities meet the fire and police
protection service needs of the proposed subdivision? If not, what additional
expense would be necessary to make these services adequate, and who would pay
the costs?
   E.   Payment For Extension Of Capital Facilities:
      1.   Indicate how the subdivider will pay for the cost of extending
capital facilities resulting from expected impacts directly attributable to the
subdivision. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-12-2: SUBDIVISION IMPROVEMENTS GUARANTEE PROCEDURES:
In lieu of the completion of the construction of any public improvements prior
to approval of the final plat, the subdivider shall provide or cause to be
provided a bond or other reasonable security, in an amount and with surety and
conditions satisfactory to the town council, providing for and securing the
construction and installation of the improvements, in accordance with the
specifications set out in section 11-4-2-8 of this title. The following
procedures and requirements shall apply:
   A.   Improvements; Standards; Time Limits: The town council shall specify
the improvements that may be completed after the final plat is approved. The
town council shall specify that the improvements must be constructed to
standards included in these regulations and other standards the town council
may adopt. Those improvements shall include streets, roads, bridges, culverts,
curbs, gutters, drainage ditches, water systems, sewage systems, sidewalks,
walkways, streetlights, street signs, road right of way clearings, solid waste
facilities, park and recreation facilities, mobile home pads and other
improvements as required by the town council. The town council shall specify a
deadline for completion of the improvements. All improvements shall be
completed no later than eighteen (18) months from the date the final plat is
filed with the clerk and recorder. The town council may grant one extension of
up to one year, unless otherwise agreed to by the town.
   B.   Projected Costs: The subdivider shall provide three (3) bids for the
cost of installation of the public improvements. The town council may direct
the city engineer or designated representatives to review all improvements,
plans and specifications and projected costs of completing the improvements.
   C.   Improvements Agreement: The subdivider shall enter into an improvements
agreement which shall follow the model subdivision improvements agreement found
at the Manhattan town hall or the official Manhattan website.
   D.   Improvements Guarantee: The subdivider shall provide a guarantee that
the improvements will be completed. The guarantee shall have a value equal to
one hundred fifty percent (150%) of the highest of the three (3) bids provided
by the developer for the projected costs of completing improvements. The
guarantee shall specify procedures for the town to obtain the funds should the
subdivider fail to satisfactorily complete the improvements. The types of
guarantees acceptable to the town are described in subsection
11-12-2 -H of this section. The method of guarantee shall be subject to town
approval.
   E.   Inspection And Certification:
      1.   Upon completion of required improvements, the subdivider shall file
with the town a statement certifying that:
         a.   All required improvements are complete.
         b.   These improvements comply with the minimum standards specified by
the town council for their construction.
         c.   The subdivider knows of no defects in these improvements.
         d.   These improvements are free and clear of any encumbrance or
liens.
         e.   All applicable fees and surcharges have been paid.
      2.   The subdivider shall also file with the town copies of final plans,
profiles, grades, and specifications for improvements.
      3.   The town will provide for inspection of all required improvements by
the city engineer or a designated representative before final plat approval
when installation is a condition of approval or before releasing the subdivider
from the subdivision improvements agreement. The subdivider shall bore the
entirety of the cost for the town's inspection of all required improvements.
Upon completion of the inspection, the inspecting engineer shall file with the
town a statement either certifying that the improvements have been completed in
the required manner or listing the defects in those improvements. Only after
the inspecting engineer certifies that the improvements are complete and free
from defect, and after receipt of the other statements detailed above, the town
shall completely release the subdivider from the subdivision improvements
agreement.
   F.   Reduction And Release of Guarantee: The town council shall reduce bond
requirements commensurate with the completion of improvements as specified in
the improvements agreement. The proportion of the collateral released may not
exceed the proportion which the improvements completed represent of all
originally required improvements. An inspection of the completed portion will
be required. Upon acceptance of the final portion of improvements, the town
council shall authorize the release of the remaining portion of the improvement
guarantee. Prior to the release of the guarantee, a copy of the plans, stamped
by the project surveyor or engineer in accordance with their licensing
provision, shall be filed in the clerk and recorder's office with reference to
the final subdivision plat.
   G.   Failure To Satisfactorily Complete Improvements: If the town council
determines that any improvements are not constructed in compliance with the
agreed specifications, it shall furnish the subdivider with a list of specific
deficiencies and may withhold collateral sufficient to ensure proper
completion. If the town council determines that the subdivider will not
construct any or all the improvements to required specifications, or within
time limits, it may withdraw collateral and use these funds to construct the
improvements to meet specifications. Unused portions of these funds shall be
returned to the subdivider or crediting institution.
   H.   Acceptable Forms Of Improvements Guarantees: The subdivider shall
provide a financial security guarantee from the following listed methods in the
amount of one hundred fifty percent (150%) of the highest bid for the estimated
total cost of installing all required improvements.
      1.   Escrow Account: The subdivider shall deposit cash, or collateral
readily convertible to cash at face value, either with the town or in escrow
with an escrow agency. The use of collateral other than cash, and the selection
of the escrow agency where funds are to be deposited must be approved by the
town council. Where an escrow account is to be used, the subdivider shall give
the town his agreement with the escrow agency guaranteeing the following:
         a.   That the funds in the escrow account are to be held in trust
until released by the town council and may not be used or pledged by the
subdivider as security for any other obligation during that period.
         b.   That, should the subdivider fail to complete the required
improvements, the escrow agency shall immediately make the funds in escrow
available to the town for completing these improvements.
      2.   Surety Performance Bond: The subdivider shall provide a surety
performance bond which shall be executed by a surety company authorized to do
business in the state of Montana and acceptable as a surety to the town and
countersigned by a Montana agent. The bond shall be payable to the town. The
bond shall be in a form which can be reduced incrementally and shall be in
effect until the completed improvements are accepted by the town council.
      3.   Sequential Development: In lieu of requiring a bond or other means
of security for the construction or installation of the required public
improvements, the town council may approve an incremental payment or guarantee
plan. The improvements in a prior increment must be completed or the payment or
guarantee of payment for the costs of the improvements incurred in a prior
increment must be satisfied before development of future increments. The town
council may grant final plat approval to only one increment at a time. The plat
approval for each succeeding increment will be contingent on completion of all
improvements in each preceding increment. Improvements in each increment of the
subdivision must be completed or guaranteed using one of the other methods
detailed in this section before final plat approval will be granted.
      4.   Special Improvement District: The town may enter into an agreement
with the subdivider, and the owners of the property proposed for subdivision if
other than the subdivider, that the installation of required improvements will
be financed through a special improvement district created pursuant to MCA
title 7, Chapter 12. This agreement must provide that no lots within the
subdivision will be sold, rented, or leased, and no contract for the sale of
lots executed, before the improvement district has been created. Subdivision
improvements must be completed or guaranteed before final plat approval will be
granted. An agreement to finance improvements through creating a special
improvement district constitutes a waiver by the subdivider, or the other
owners of the property, of the right to protest, or petition against, the
creation of the district under either MCA 7-12-2109 or 7-12-4110, Montana Code
Annotated. This waiver must be filed with the Gallatin County clerk and
recorder and will be deemed to run with the land.
      5.   Letter Of Credit: Subject to town council approval, the subdivider
shall provide the town a letter of credit from a bank or other reputable
financial institution certifying the following:
         a.   That the creditor guarantees funds in an amount equal to the
cost, as approved by the town council, of completing all required improvements.
         b.   That if the subdivider fails to complete the specified
improvements within the required period, the creditor will immediately pay to
the town upon presentation of sight draft without further action, an amount of
cash necessary to finance the completion of those improvements, up to the limit
of credit stated in the letter.
   c.   That this letter of credit may not be withdrawn until released by the
town council. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-12-3: REQUIRED COVENANTS:
The following covenants are required for all subdivisions in Manhattan and the
urban growth area:
   A.   Conditions And Covenants Related To Water Conveyance Facilities:
      1.   Conditions Related To Water Conveyance Facilities:
         a.   Water conveyance facilities and the required water conveyance
facility non-interference setback shall be shown on the final plat and clearly
labeled. Plats shall depict irrigation ditches, canals, or pipelines by their
centerline.
         b.   The following note shall appear on the final Subdivision plat:
"Any water conveyance facility non-interference setback or easement shown on
the subdivision plat does not eliminate any secondary easement described by
section 70-17-112, MCA."
         c.   Unless there is written consent from the appropriate water users
and/or water conveyance facility's authorized representatives, stormwater,
snowmelt runoff, water from dewatering practices, or other water originating
from within the boundaries of the subdivision shall not discharge into or
otherwise be directed into any irrigation ditch, canal, pipeline, or other
water conveyance facility.
         d.   The subdivider shall not undertake any activity that would result
in the interference or obstruction in the transmission of water in any water
conveyance facility. Before any maintenance, improvements, or modifications are
performed on any water conveyance facility, written permission must be obtained
from the water users and/or water conveyance facility's authorized
representatives. Upon completion of maintenance, improvements, or modifications
to any water conveyance facility, the subdivider shall provide written notice
to the water users and/or water cnveyance facility's authorized representatives
and allow them an opportunity to inspect such work.
   B.   Covenants Related To Water Conveyance Facilities:
      1.   No water may be removed from any irrigation ditch, canal, or other
water conveyance facility without a water right, permit, or written water lease
agreement with the appropriate water users and/or water conveyance facility's
authorized representatives.
      2.   Unless there is written consent from the appropriate water users
and/or water conveyance facility's authorized representatives, stormwater,
snowmelt runoff, water from dewatering practices, or other water originating
from within the boundaries of the subdivision shall not discharge into or
otherwise be directed into any irrigation ditch, canal, pipeline, or other
water conveyance facility.
      3.   The owners' association shall remove any trash or debris that
originated from within the subdivision and has accumulated in the water
conveyance facilities passing through their subdivision by no later than May
1st of each year. If the owners' association fails to remove the trash or
debris as described above, the water users and/or water conveyance facility's
authorized representatives may cause the trash or debris to be removed and bill
the owners' association for such efforts.
      4.   Until such time that the owners' association assumes responsibility
for the requirements described herein, such requirements shall be the
responsibility of the developer.
      5.   Lot owners are hereby notified of the water users, water conveyance
facility's authorized representatives, and/or their designee's right to access
the property to maintain and repair the water conveyance facility (this
includes, but is not limited to, placement of excavated material, removal of
vegetation and debris along the water conveyance facility); to install, repair,
and or adjust headgates and other diversion structures; and to carry out other
normal means of repair and maintenance related to the ditch/canal.
      6.   To assure non-interference with water conveyance facilities, no
livestock grazing shall take place, nor shall any new structures (other than
structures for the maintenance and operation of the water conveyance facility),
fences, landscaping (other than grass), or roads, may be installed or erected
within the water conveyance facility non-interference setback, except where
agreed to in writing by the water users and/or water conveyance facilities
authorized representatives. (NOTE: Where the water users and/or water
conveyance facility's authorized representatives agree to something else as
part of the subdivision review process, this covenant would need to be amended
to reflect those changes.)
      7.   Neither the owners' association nor any lot owners shall undertake
any activity that would result in the interference or obstruction in the
transmission of water in the water conveyance facility. Before any maintenance,
improvements, or modifications are performed on any water conveyance facility,
written permission must be obtained from the water users and/or water
conveyance facility's authorized representatives prior to commencing such work.
Upon completion of maintenance, improvements, or modifications to any water
conveyance facility, the person responsible for such work shall provide written
notice to the water users and/or water conveyance facility's authorized
representatives and allow them an opportunity to inspect such work.
      8.   Lot purchasers are hereby notified that Montana law provides
specific protections in regards to liability and nuisance claims for
agricultural operations and irrigators. Those specific protections include, but
are not limited to MCA 85-7-2211, 85-7- 2212; 27-30-101. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-
2024)
11-12-4: FEE SCHEDULE: SUBDIVISION REVIEW FEES:
The purpose of these fees is to cover the costs of processing applications and
reviewing plats, plat supplements, advertising, holding public hearings, and
other expenses related to the subdivision review process. The subdivider shall
pay a nonrefundable review fee at the time of application prior to final
approval. All fees as determined from time to time by resolution of the town
council shall be payable to the own. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-12-5: SUBDIVISION APPEAL PROCESS:
11-12-5-1: APPEALS OF ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS:
Any person or persons, jointly or severally aggrieved by any decision of the
subdivision administrator, may present to the board of adjustments a petition,
duly verified, setting forth that such decision is unfounded, in whole or in
part, specifying the grounds of the complaint. Such petition shall be presented
to the board of adjustments within thirty (30) days after the filing of the
decision of the subdivision administrator. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-12-5-2: APPEALS OF TOWN COUNCIL DECISIONS:
Any person or persons, jointly or severally aggrieved by any decision of the
town council, may present to a court of record a petition, duly verified,
setting forth that such decision is illegal, in whole or in part, specifying
the grounds of the illegality. Such petition shall be presented to the court
within thirty (30) days after the filing of the decision of the office of the
council.
For the purposes of this section, "aggrieved" means a person who can
demonstrate a specific personal and legal interest, as distinguished from a
general interest, who has been or is likely to be specially and injuriously
affected by the decision. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
CHAPTER 13
DEVELOPMENT FEES
SECTION:
11-13-1: Definitions
11-13-2: Calculation Of Impact Fees; Documentation Required; Ordinance Or
Resolution; Requirements For Impact Fees
11-13-3: Collection And Expenditure Of Impact Fees; Refunds Or Credits;
Mechanism For Appeal Required; Cause Of Action
11-13-4: Impact Fee Advisory Committee
11-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this part, the following definitions apply:
CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS Improvements, land, and equipment with a useful life of
ten (10) years or more that increase or improve the service capacity of a
public facility. The term does not include consumable supplies.
CONNECTION CHARGE The actual cost of connecting a property to a public utility
system and is limited to the labor, materials, and overhead involved in making
connections and installing meters.
DEVELOPMENT: Construction, renovation, or installation of a building or
structure, a change in use of a building or structure, or a change in the use
of land when the construction, installation, or other action creates additional
demand for public facilities.
IMPACT FEE: Any charge imposed upon development by the town council as part of
the development approval process to fund the additional service capacity
required by the development from which it is collected. An impact fee may
include a fee for the administration of the impact fee not to exceed five
percent (5%) of the total impact fee collected. The term does not include:
   A.   A charge or fee to pay for administration, plan review, or inspection
costs associated with a permit required for development;
   B.   A connection charge;
   C.   Any other fee authorized by law, including but not limited to user
fees, special improvement district assessments, fees authorized under title 7
for county, municipal, and consolidated government sewer and water districts
and systems, and costs of ongoing maintenance; or
   D.   Onsite or offsite improvements necessary for new development to meet
the safety, level of service, and other minimum development standards that have
been adopted by the town council.
PROPORTIONATE SHARE: That portion of the cost of capital system improvements
that reasonably relates to the service demands and needs of the project. A
proportionate share must consider the limitations provided in MCA 7-6-1602.
PUBLIC FACILITIES:
   A.   A water supply production, treatment, storage, or distribution
facility;
   B.   A wastewater collection, treatment, or disposal facility;
   C.   A transportation facility, including roads, streets, bridges, rights-
of-way, traffic signals, and landscaping;
   D.   A storm water collection, retention, detention, treatment, or disposal
facility or a flood control facility;
   E.   Police, emergency medical rescue, or fire protection facility; and
   F.   Other facilities for which documentation is prepared as provided in
section 7-6-1602 that have been approved as part of an impact fee ordinance or
resolution by:
      1.   A two-thirds (2/3) majority of the governing body of an incorporated
city, town, or consolidated local government; or
      2.   A unanimous vote of the board of county commissioners of a county
government. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-13-2: CALCULATION OF IMPACT FEES; DOCUMENTATION REQUIRED; ORDINANCE OR
RESOLUTION; REQUIREMENTS FOR IMPACT FEES:
For each public facility for which an impact fee is imposed, the town council
shall prepare and approve a service area report.
   A.   The service area report is a written analysis that must:
      1.   Describe existing conditions of the facility;
      2.   Establish level-of-service standards;
      3.   Forecast future additional needs for service for a defined period;
      4.   Identify capital improvements necessary to meet future needs for
service;
      5.   Identify those capital improvements needed for continued operation
and maintenance of the facility;
      6.   Determine as to whether one service area or more than one (1)
service area is necessary to establish a correlation between impact fees and
benefits;
      7.   Determine as to whether one service area or more than one service
area for transportation facilities is needed to establish a correlation between
impact fees and benefits;
      8.   Establish the methodology and period over which the town council
will assign the proportionate share of capital costs for expansion of the
facility to provide service to new development within each service area;
      9.   Establish the methodology that the town council will use to exclude
operations and maintenance costs and correction of existing deficiencies from
the impact fee;
      10.   Establish the amount of the impact fee that will be imposed for
each unit of increased service demand; and
      11.   Have a component of the budget of the town council that:
         a.   Schedules construction of public facility capital improvements to
serve projected growth;
         b.   Projects costs of the capital improvements;
         c.   Allocates collected impact fees for construction of the capital
improvements; and
         d.   Covers at least a five (5) year period and is reviewed and
updated at least every five (5) years.
   B.   The service area report is a written analysis that must contain
documentation of sources and methodology used for purposes of section
11-13-2 -A and must document how each impact fee meets the requirements of
section
11-13-2 -F.
   C.   The service area report that supports adoption and calculation of an
impact fee must be available to the public upon request.
   D.   The amount of each impact fee imposed must be based upon the actual
cost of public facility expansion or improvements or reasonable estimates of
the cost to be incurred by the town council because of new development. The
calculation of each impact fee must be in accordance with generally accepted
accounting principles.
   E.   The ordinance or resolution adopting the impact fee must include a time
schedule for periodically updating the documentation required under section
11-13-2 -A.
   F.   An impact fee must meet the following requirements:
      1.   The amount of the impact fee must be reasonably related to and
reasonably attributable to the development's share of the cost of
infrastructure improvements made necessary by the new development.
      2.   The impact fees imposed may not exceed a proportionate share of the
costs incurred or to be incurred by the town council in accommodating the
development. The following factors must be considered in determining a
proportionate share of public facilities capital improvements costs:
         a.   The need for public facilities capital improvements required to
serve new development; and
         b.   Consideration of payments for system improvements reasonably
anticipated to be made by or because of the development in the form of user
fees, debt service payments, taxes, and other available sources of funding the
system improvements.
      3.   Costs for correction of existing deficiencies in a public facility
may not be included in the impact fee.
      4.   New development may not be held to a higher level of service than
existing users unless there is a mechanism in place for the existing users to
make improvements to the existing system to match the higher level of service.
      5.   Impact fees may not include expenses for operations and maintenance
of the facility. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-13-3: COLLECTION AND EXPENDITURE OF IMPACT FEES; REFUNDS OR CREDITS;
MECHANISM FOR APPEAL REQUIRED; CAUSE OF ACTION:
   A.   The collection and expenditure of impact fees must comply with this
part. The collection and expenditure of impact fees must be reasonably related
to the benefits accruing to the development paying the impact fees. The
ordinance or resolution adopted by the town vouncil must include the following
requirements:
      1.   Impact fees collected for a public facility must be deposited in a
special proprietary fund created specifically for each public facility as
identified in the service area report. Funds must be invested with all interest
accruing to the fund. Impact fees collected for a specific public facility may
not be transferred to a different fund and must be spent and accounted for
solely for the public facility as identified in the service area report.
      2.   The town council may impose impact fees on behalf of local
districts.
      3.   If the impact fees are not collected or spent in accordance with the
impact fee ordinance or resolution or in accordance with MCA 7-6-1602, any
impact fees that were collected must be refunded to the person who owned the
property at the time the impact fee in question was paid.
         a.   If a written request is submitted as provided for in subsection
11-13-3 -I, the town council shall refund any impact fee due under this section
within ninety (90) days.
         b.   The town council may not impose conditions when issuing a refund
pursuant to this part.
      4.   Impact fees may only be used to acquire, construct, or improve the
specific public facility project for which they were collected and may only be
expended in compliance with the service area report.
   B.   All impact fees imposed pursuant to the authority granted in this part
must be paid no earlier than the date of issuance of a building permit if a
building permit is required for the development or no earlier than the time of
wastewater or water service connection or well or septic permitting.
   C.   The town council may recoup costs of excess capacity in existing
capital facilities, when the excess capacity has been provided in anticipation
of the needs of new development, by requiring impact fees for that portion of
the facilities constructed for future users. The need to recoup costs for
excess capacity must have been documented pursuant to MCA 7-6-1602 in a manner
that demonstrates the need for the excess capacity. This part does not prevent
the town council from continuing to assess an impact fee that recoups costs for
excess capacity in an existing facility. The impact fees imposed to recoup the
costs to provide the excess capacity must be based on the town council's actual
cost of acquiring, constructing, or upgrading the facility and must be no more
than a proportionate share of the costs to provide the excess capacity.
   D.   The town council may accept the dedication of land or the construction
of public facilities in lieu of payment of impact fees if:
      1.   The need for the dedication or construction is clearly documented
pursuant to MCA 7- 6-1602;
      2.   The land proposed for dedication for the public facilities to be
constructed is determined to be appropriate for the proposed use by the town
council;
      3.   Formulas or procedures for determining the worth of proposed
dedications or constructions are established as part of the impact fee
ordinance or resolution; and
      4.   A means to establish credits against future impact fee revenue has
been created as part of the adopting ordinance or resolution if the dedication
of land or construction of public facilities is of worth more than the impact
fee due from an individual development.
   E.   Impact fees may not be imposed for remodeling, rehabilitation, or other
improvements to an existing structure or for rebuilding a damaged structure
unless there is an increase in units that increase service demand as described
in MCA 7-6-1602(2)(j). If impact fees are imposed for remodeling,
rehabilitation, or other improvements to an existing structure or use, only the
net increase between the old and new demand may be imposed.
   F.   This part does not prevent the town council from granting refunds or
credits:
      1.   That it considers appropriate and that are consistent with the
provisions of MCA 7-6- 1602 and this chapter; or
      2.   In accordance with a voluntary agreement, consistent with the
provisions of MCA 7-6- 1602 and this chapter, between the town council and the
individual or entity being assessed the impact fees.
   G.   An impact fee represents a fee for service payable by all users
creating additional demand on the facility.
   H.   An impact fee ordinance or resolution must include a mechanism whereby
a person charged an impact fee may appeal the charge if the person believes an
error has been made.
   I.   Any person or entity who is owed refunded impact fees as provided in
this part may request in writing from the town council that prompt payment be
concluded. A person or entity who submitted a written request pursuant to this
subsection may bring a cause of action against the town council in a court of
competent jurisdiction for failure to comply with this part. If a claimant
prevails in an action brought against the town council pursuant to this
subsection, the court shall award the claimant payment of all amounts due,
court costs, expert witness fees, and attorney fees incurred by the claimant.
If the claimant is unsuccessful, the court shall award the town council court
costs, expert witness fees, and attorney fees. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-13-4: IMPACT FEE ADVISORY COMMITTEE:
When the town council intends to propose an impact fee ordinance or resolution
shall establish an impact fee advisory committee.
An impact fee advisory committee must include at least one representative of
the development community. The committee shall review and monitor the process
of calculating, assessing, and spending impact fees.
The impact fee advisory committee shall serve in an advisory capacity to the
town council. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
CHAPTER 14
DIVISIONS OF LAND EXEMPT FROM SUBDIVISION REVIEW
SECTION:
11-14-1: Purpose; Review Required
11-14-2: Exemption For Airport Land And State-Owned Lands; Exception
11-14-3: Exemption For Conveyances Executed Prior To July 1, 1974
11-14-4: Divisions Or Aggregations Of Land Exempted From Review But Subject To
Survey Requirements And Zoning Regulations; Exceptions; Fees For Examination Of
Division
11-14-5: Exemption From Surveying And Platting Requirements For Lands Acquired
For State Highways
11-14-6: Agricultural Covenant; Change In Use
11-14-7: Standards For Condominiums
11-14-8: Standards For Townhouses
11-14-9: Procedures And Review Of Subdivision Exemptions
11-14-9-1: Submittal
11-14-9-2: Review
11-14-9-3: Appeals
11-14-1:   PURPOSE; REVIEW REQUIRED:
The MSPA provides that certain divisions of land, which would otherwise
constitute subdivisions, are exempt from local subdivision review and approval,
unless the use of the exemption is an attempt to evade the MSPA.
   A.   Unless the method of disposition is adopted for the purpose of evading
this chapter, the requirements of this chapter may not apply to any division of
land that:
      1.   Is created by order of any court of record in this state or by
operation of law or that, in the absence of agreement between the parties to
the sale, could be created by an order of any court in this state pursuant to
the law of eminent domain, MCA title 70, chapter 30;
      2.   Subject to this section, is created to provide security for
mortgages, liens, or trust indentures for the purpose of construction,
improvements to the land being divided, or refinancing purposes;
      3.   Creates an interest in oil, gas, minerals, or water that is severed
from the surface ownership of real property;
      4.   Creates cemetery lots;
      5.   Is created by the reservation of a life estate;
      6.   Is created by lease or rental for farming and agricultural purposes;
      7.   Is in a location over which the state does not have jurisdiction; or
      8.   Is created for rights-of-way or utility sites. A subsequent change
in the use of the land to a residential, commercial, or industrial use is
subject to the requirements of this chapter.
   B.   An exempt division of land as provided in subsection
11-14-1 -A-1 is not considered a subdivision under this chapter if not more
than four new lots or parcels are created from the original lot or parcel.
   C.   Before a court of record orders, a division of land, the court shall
notify the town council of the pending division and allow the town council to
present written comment on the division.
   D.   An exemption under subsection
11-14-1 -A-2 applies:
      1.   To a division of land of any size;
      2.   If the land that is divided is not conveyed to any entity other than
the financial or lending institution to which the mortgage, lien, or trust
indenture was given or to a purchaser upon foreclosure of the mortgage, lien,
or trust indenture. Except as provided in subsection
11-14-1 -E, a transfer of the divided land, by the owner of the property at the
time that the land was divided, to any party other than those identified in
this subsection subjects the division of land to the requirements of this
chapter.
      3.   To a parcel that is created to provide security as provided in
subsection
11-14-1 -A. The remainder of the tract of land is subject to the provisions of
this chapter, if applicable.
   E.   If a parcel of land was divided pursuant to subsection
11-14-1 -A-2 and one of the parcels created by the division was conveyed by the
landowner to another party without foreclosure before October 1, 2003, the
conveyance of the remaining parcel is not subject to the requirements of this
chapter.
   F.   The Town Council:
      1.   May examine a division of land to determine whether the requirements
of this chapter apply to the division;
      2.   Shall complete the examination and approve or deny the application
for a division of land under this section within twenty (20) working days of
the receipt of an application containing all materials and information required
by the town council to complete the examination under regulations adopted
pursuant to MCA 76-3-504(1)(p); and
      3.   May not impose conditions on the approval of a division of land
under this section except for conditions necessary to ensure compliance with
the survey requirements of MCA title 76, chapter 3, part 4. (Ord. 24-007, 12-
11-2024)
11-14-2:   EXEMPTION FOR AIRPORT LAND AND STATE-OWNED LANDS; EXCEPTION:
   A.   A division of land created by lease or rental of contiguous airport-
related land owned by a city, a county, the state, or a municipal or regional
airport authority is not subject to the requirements of this chapter if the
lease or rental is for onsite weather or air navigation facilities, the
manufacture, maintenance, and storage of aircraft, or air carrier-related
activities.
   B.   A division of state-owned land is not subject to the requirements of
this chapter unless the division creates a second or subsequent parcel from a
single tract for sale, rent, or lease for residential purposes after July 1,
1974. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-14-3:   EXEMPTION FOR CONVEYANCES EXECUTED PRIOR TO JULY 1, 1974:
This chapter shall not be applicable to deeds, contracts, leases, or other
conveyances executed prior to July 1, 1974. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-14-4:   DIVISIONS OR AGGREGATIONS OF LAND EXEMPTED FROM REVIEW BUT SUBJECT
TO SURVEY REQUIREMENTS AND ZONING REGULATIONS; EXCEPTIONS; FEES FOR EXAMINATION
OF DIVISION:
   A.   Except as provided in subsection
11-14-4 -B, unless the method of disposition is adopted for the purpose of
evading this chapter, the following divisions or aggregations of tracts of
record of any size, regardless of the resulting size of any lot created by the
division or aggregation, are not subdivisions under this chapter but are
subject to the surveying requirements of MCA 76-3-401 for divisions or
aggregations of land other than subdivisions and are subject to applicable
zoning regulations adopted under MCA title 76, chapter 2:
      1.   Divisions made outside of platted subdivisions for the purpose of
relocating common boundary lines between adjoining properties;
      2.   Divisions made outside of platted subdivisions for the purpose of a
single gift or sale in each county to each member of the landowner's immediate
family;
      3.   Divisions made outside of platted subdivisions by gift, sale, or
agreement to buy and sell in which the landowner enters a covenant for the
purposes of this chapter with the governing body that runs with the land and
provides that the divided land will be used exclusively for agricultural
purposes, subject to the provisions of MCA 76-3-211;
      4.   For five (5) or fewer lots within a platted subdivision, the
relocation of common boundaries;
      5.   Divisions made for the purpose of relocating a common boundary line
between a single lot within a platted subdivision and adjoining land outside a
platted subdivision. A restriction or requirement on the original platted lot
or original unplatted parcel continues to apply to those areas.
      6.   Aggregation of parcels or lots when a certificate of survey or
subdivision plat shows that the boundaries of the original parcels have been
eliminated and the boundaries of a larger aggregate parcel are established. A
restriction or requirement on the original platted lot or original unplatted
parcel continues to apply to those areas.
   B.   Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection
11-14-4 -A:
      1.   Within a platted subdivision filed with the county clerk and
recorder, a division, redesign, or rearrangement of lots that results in an
increase in the number of lots or that redesigns or rearranges six (6) or more
lots must be reviewed and approved by the governing body before an amended plat
may be filed with the county clerk and recorder;
      2.   A division within a platted subdivision is exempt from additional
subdivision reviews and is subject to applicable zoning regulations adopted
under title 76, chapter 2, unless the method of disposition is adopted for the
purpose of evading this chapter, if the division:
         a.   Is within a subdivision that has been approved by a local
governing body;
         b.   Creates parcels of a size allowed within the subdivision; and
         c.   Is gifted or sold to a member of the landowner's immediate
family;
      3.   An amended plat must be filed with the county clerk and recorder
after a division provided in subsection
11-14-4 -B-2 occurs; and
      4.   Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, a restriction or
requirement on the platted subdivision continues to apply to a subdivision;
      5.   A division of land exempted under subsection
11-14-4 -A-2 that is also located in a zoning district is allowed if each
family transfer parcel created by the division is at least five (5) acres,
unless the zoning district allows for smaller lot sizes; and
      6.   A division of land transferred to an immediate family member
pursuant to subsection
11-14-4 -A-2 may be transferred regardless of age and may be owned jointly with
that immediate family member's spouse.
   C.   A division of land may not be made under this section unless the county
treasurer has certified that all real property taxes and special assessments
assessed and levied on the land to be divided have been paid.
      1.   If a division of land includes centrally assessed property and the
property taxes applicable to the division of land are not specifically
identified in the tax assessment, the department of revenue shall prorate the
taxes applicable to the land being divided on a reasonable basis. The owner of
the centrally assessed property shall ensure that the prorated real property
taxes and special assessments are paid on the land being sold before the
division of land is made.
      2.   The county treasurer may accept the amount of the tax prorated
pursuant to this section as a partial payment of the total tax that is due.
   D.   The Governing Body:
      1.   May examine a division or aggregation of land to determine whether
the requirements of this chapter apply to the division or aggregation;
      2.   May establish reasonable fees, not to exceed four hundred dollar
($400), for the examination;
      3.   Shall complete the examination and approve or deny the application
for a division or aggregation of land under this section within twenty (20)
working days of the receipt of an application containing all materials and
information required by the governing body to conduct its review under
regulations adopted pursuant to MCA 76-3-504(1)(p); and
      4.   May not impose conditions on the approval of a division or
aggregation of land under this section except for conditions necessary to
ensure compliance with the survey requirements of MCA title 76, chapter 3, part
4.
   E.   An immediate family member or the spouse of an immediate family member
who receives a division of land pursuant to subsection may not transfer or
otherwise convey the division of land for a period of up to two (2) years after
the date of the division unless the governing body sets a period of less than
two (2) years. A governing body may authorize variances from these requirements
to address hardship situations.
   F.   If a governing body can prove by documented evidence in a court of
competent jurisdiction that a person has knowingly evaded subdivision
regulations using a division of land under this section, that person is subject
to a civil penalty of five thousand dollars ($5,000) for each division of land,
payable to the governing body. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-14-5:   EXEMPTION FROM SURVEYING AND PLATTING REQUIREMENTS FOR LANDS
ACQUIRED FOR STATE HIGHWAYS:
Instruments of transfer of land which is acquired for state highways may refer
by parcel and project number to state highway plans which have been recorded in
compliance with MCA 60-2-209 and are exempted from the surveying and platting
requirements of this chapter. If such parcels are not shown on highway plans of
record, instruments of transfer of such parcels shall be accompanied by and
refer to appropriate certificates of survey and plats when presented for
recording. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-14-6:   AGRICULTURAL COVENANT; CHANGE IN USE:
   A.   A change in use for anything other than agricultural purposes subjects
a division of land that received an exemption under MCA 76-3-207(1)(c) to
subdivision review under parts chapter 4 and chapter 5 of this title. However,
the governing body, in its discretion, may revoke the covenant provided for in
MCA 76-3-207(1)(c) for the purposes of this chapter and the division may
proceed without subdivision review if:
      1.   The original lot lines are restored through aggregation of the
covenanted land prior to or in conjunction with the revoking of the covenant;
or
      2.   A government or public entity seeks to use the land for public
purposes as defined in the governing body's review criteria pursuant to MCA 76-
3-504(1)(p).
   B.   If a governing body proposes to revoke a covenant, the governing body
shall hold a public hearing. Within fifteen (15) days of the hearing, the
governing body shall issue written findings of fact and a decision based on the
record. If the governing body approves the revoking of the covenant, the
approval must be recorded with the clerk and recorder.
   C.   The revocation of a covenant pursuant to this section does not affect
sanitary restrictions imposed under MCA title 76, chapter 4. (Ord. 24-007, 12-
11-2024)
11-14-7:   STANDARDS FOR CONDOMINIUMS:
   A.   A determination whether the condominium, or conversion proposal is
exempt from the provisions of this chapter must be made by the governing body
or the agent or agency designated by the governing body within twenty (20)
working days of the receipt of an application containing all materials and
information required by the governing body to complete the determination.
   B.   Condominium developments shall meet the minimum standards of the MDEQ,
adopted pursuant to sections MCA 76-4-101 through 76-4-128.
   C.   The design and improvement standards of these regulations shall be
complied with, except where noted below.
   D.   Unit Ownership Act: Condominium development shall comply with all
provisions of the unit ownership act, MCA 70-23-102 through 70-23-703, and all
regulations adopted pursuant thereto.
   E.   Other Requirements: The subdivider shall comply with all other
standards and requirements of these regulations, the Manhattan transportation
design and construction standards, and other local and state regulations.
Condominium applications shall show the proposed location of buildings, snow
storage, parking, and internal access.
   F.   If it is determined that the project is exempt from the provisions of
this title the application shall be reviewed administratively by the
subdivision administrator or their designee. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-14-8:   STANDARDS FOR TOWNHOUSES:
   A.   A determination whether the townhouses, or conversion proposal is
exempt from the provisions of this chapter must be made by the governing body
or the agent or agency designated by the governing body within twenty (20)
working days of the receipt of an application containing all materials and
information required by the governing body to complete the determination.
   B.   Townhouses shall conform to the standards found within title 10 of the
municipal code of Manhattan.
If it is determined that the project is exempt from the provisions of this
title the application shall be reviewed administratively by the subdivision
administrator or their designee. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-14-9: PROCEDURES AND REVIEW OF SUBDIVISION EXEMPTIONS:
11-14-9-1:   SUBMITTAL:
Any person seeking exemption from the requirements of the MSPA shall submit to
the subdivision administrator:
   A.   A subdivision exemption application
   B.   Appropriate fee as shown on the official fee schedule
   C.   A certificate of survey or, if a survey is not required, an instrument
of conveyance, and
   D.   Evidence of, and an affidavit affirming, entitlement to the claimed
exemption. For purposes of MCA 76-3-207, when a parcel of land for which an
exemption from subdivision review is claimed is being conveyed under a contract
for deed, the terms "property owner", "landowner", and "owner" mean the seller
of the parcel under the contract for deed. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-14-9-2:   REVIEW:
When a division of land for which an exemption is claimed is submitted to the
subdivision administrator, the subdivision administrator shall cause the
documents to be reviewed by the designated agents of the governing body (e.g.,
town attorney, engineer, treasurer, and clerk and recorder). The subdivision
administrator and governing body agents shall review the claimed exemption to
verify that it is the proper use of the claimed exemption and complies with the
requirements set forth in the MSPA, the Montana sanitation in subdivisions act,
and these regulations.
   A.   Landowners or their agents are encouraged to meet with the subdivision
administrator to discuss whether a proposed land division or use of an
exemption complies with the criteria.
   B.   The subdivision administrator shall make a written determination of
whether the use of the exemption is intended to evade the purposes of the MSPA,
explaining the reasons for the determination.
   C.   If the subdivision administrator finds that the proposed use of the
exemption complies with the statutes and the criteria set forth in this
section, the subdivision administrator shall notify the governing body and
advise the clerk and recorder to file the certificate of survey or record the
instrument of conveyance and accompanying documents.
   D.   If the subdivision administrator finds that the proposed use of the
exemption does not comply with the statutes and the criteria in this section,
the subdivision administrator shall advise the clerk and recorder not to file
or record the documents, and the materials will be returned to the landowner.
   E.   The subdivision administrator shall consider all the surrounding
circumstances when determining whether an exemption is claimed for the purpose
of evading the MSPA. These circumstances may include, but are not limited to,
the nature of the claimant's business, the prior history of the tract in
question, the proposed configuration of the tracts if the proposed exempt
transaction is completed, and any pattern of exempt transactions that will
result in the equivalent of a subdivision without local government review.
(Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
11-14-9-3:   APPEALS:
Any person or persons, jointly or severally aggrieved by any decision of the
subdivision administrator, may present to the board of adjustments a petition,
duly verified, setting forth that such decision is unfounded, in whole or in
part, specifying the grounds of the complaint. Such petition shall be presented
to the board of adjustments within thirty (30) days after the filing of the
decision of the subdivision administrator.
Any person or persons, jointly or severally aggrieved by any decision of the
town council, may present to a court of record a petition, duly verified,
setting forth that such decision is illegal, in whole or in part, specifying
the grounds of the illegality. Such petition shall be presented to the court
within thirty (30) days after the filing of the decision of the office of the
council.
For the purposes of this section, "aggrieved" means a person who can
demonstrate a specific personal and legal interest, as distinguished from a
general interest, who has been or is likely to be specially and injuriously
affected by the decision. (Ord. 24-007, 12-11-2024)
TITLE 12
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODES
SECTION:
12-1-1: Adoption Of The Model Technical Codes And Administrative Rules
12-1-2: Building Permit Required
12-1-3: Appeals Board
12-1-1: ADOPTION OF THE MODEL TECHNICAL CODES AND ADMINISTRATIVE RULES:
   A.   The current editions of the model uniform technical codes, to include,
but not be limited to, building, plumbing, electrical and mechanical, and all
accompanying appendices, amendments and modifications adopted or required to be
adopted by the building codes bureau, Montana department of labor and industry
(or its successor) as set out in the administrative rules of Montana, as
amended from time to time by the building codes bureau, are adopted by
reference and incorporated in this title as if set forth in full, except for
any exception noted in this chapter or any regulations not applicable to local
government jurisdictions. From the date this ordinance is effective, all
buildings and enclosed structures to be constructed within the town limits of
the town of Manhattan shall be constructed in accordance with the applicable
provisions of these codes.
   B.   One copy of each code shall be kept on file in the office of the town
clerk/treasurer of the town of Manhattan.
   C.   Any amendment adopted or requested by the department of labor and
industry, building codes bureau, which applies to local government
jurisdictions including the adoption of the latest editions of the model
technical codes to include, but not be limited to, building, plumbing,
electrical and mechanical codes, or any applicable administrative rules (ARM)
modifying the aforementioned building codes, may be adopted by administrative
order, signed by the mayor and shall become effective sixty (60) days after the
order is signed.
   D.   A copy of the amendment notification will be kept in the office of the
town clerk/treasurer.
   E.   The model technical codes and administrative rules of Montana as
adopted above, and the amendments thereto, are applicable within the town of
Manhattan.
(Ord. 287, 2-10-2004; amd. Ord. 299, 11-9-2004; Ord. 06-007, 6-13-2006; Ord.
24-005, 5-9-2024)
12-1-2: BUILDING PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   For the construction of any building or enclosed structure greater than
two hundred square feet (200), the owner of such building project must apply to
the town for a building permit, which shall include a plumbing permit,
electrical permit, and zoning permit. Application shall be made at the town
office on a form provided by the town for such purposes. Application must be
made before the start of construction and construction may not start until such
time as the plans have been approved by the building inspector and zoning
administrator.
   B.   The applicant shall pay to the town an administrative fee for
processing the application and shall further pay for the cost of the plan
review and building inspection as set out in a schedule provided by the
building code inspector which will be available at the town office.
   C.   Plans shall be reviewed and inspections made in accordance with the
rules and procedures of the Bozeman city building code enforcement division.
(Ord. 297, 8-9-2004; amd. Ord. 24-005, 5-9-2024)
12-1-3: APPEALS BOARD:
   If after a decision is rendered by the building inspector or zoning
administrator regarding any aspect of the review or permitting process, which
the applicant disputes, the applicant may file an appeal with the Board of
Adjustment.
   A.   After the applicant files an appeal with the appeal board, the board
shall set a hearing on the appeal within thirty (30) days of the filing of the
appeal. Further, the board shall render its decision on the appeal no later
than five (5) days after the hearing.
   B.   The Board of Adjustment shall follow the process outlined in
Title 10 Chapter 3 of the Manhattan Town Code.
   C.   After the applicant files an appeal with the appeal board, the board
shall set a hearing on the appeal within fifteen (15) days of the filing of the
appeal. Further, the board shall render its decision on the appeal no later
than five (5) days after the hearing.
   D.   If the applicant is dissatisfied with the decision of the Board of
Appeals, appeal may be made in the manner described in
10-3-4-7.
(Ord. 297, 8-9-2004; amd. Ord. 24-005, 5-9-2024)
CHAPTER 2
BUILDING INSPECTOR
SECTION:
12-2-1: Building Code Inspection And Enforcement Officer
12-2-2: Duties
12-2-3: Inspections
12-2-4: Right Of Entry
12-2-5: Enforcement
12-2-6: Authority
12-2-7: Effective Date
12-2-1: BUILDING CODE INSPECTION AND ENFORCEMENT OFFICER:
The town council shall appoint a building inspector who shall administer and
enforce the provisions of this title. (Ord. 288, 2-10-2004)
12-2-2: DUTIES:
It is the intent of this chapter that the building inspector shall inspect all
building construction of enclosed structures greater than one hundred twenty
(120) square feet for commercial buildings and two hundred (200) square feet
for residential buildings within the jurisdiction of the town of Manhattan, and
in accordance with the provisions of this code relating to buildings and to
inspect all buildings or structures being constructed, wrecked or altered, as
frequently as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the ordinances of the
town. (Ord. 288, 2-10-2004)
12-2-3: INSPECTIONS:
The building inspector shall be ex officio electrical inspector and ex officio
plumbing inspector, and shall perform the duties of those offices until such
time as a separate electrical inspector and plumbing inspector are provided for
and appointed. (Ord. 288, 2-10-2004)
12-2-4: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The building inspector shall have the power to make or cause to be made an
entry into any building or premises, where the work of altering, repairing or
constructing any building or structure is going on, for the purpose of making
inspections at any reasonable hour. (Ord. 288, 2-10-2004)
12-2-5: ENFORCEMENT:
The building inspector shall have the power to order all work stopped on the
construction, alteration or repair of buildings in the town when such work is
being done in violation of any provision or of any ordinance relating thereto.
Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such an order except on the
written permission of the building inspector provided that if a stop order is
an oral one, it shall be followed by a written stop order within one hour.
Any person who shall continue work in violation of a stop order of the building
inspector shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as set forth in section
1-4-2 of this code. (Ord. 07-002, 2-13-2007)
   A.   If possible, the building inspector will notify a project owner or an
agent thereof, of any violation of this chapter, or of any applicable building
code by verbal or written notice. If the builder or owner is not on the site,
the building inspector shall post such notice at the job site in a conspicuous
manner. If the violation is not corrected within forty eight (48) hours of
receiving notice, the building inspector shall have the power to order all work
on the project stopped as set out in this section.
   B.   If the builder or owner continues to work on the project in violation
of the stop work order, the town may pursue legal remedies as set forth in
section 50-60-109, Montana Code Annotated.
   C.   Any person served with an order to stop work, who fails to comply with
the order not later than thirty (30) days after service or within the time
fixed by the building inspector is guilty of a misdemeanor as set forth in
section 50-60-110, Montana Code Annotated.
   D.   Any construction started without first obtaining the necessary permits
as set forth in section
12-1-2 of this title shall be immediately stopped and no work may continue
until such time as the plans have been approved and the necessary permits
issued. (Ord. 297, 8-9-2004)
12-2-6: AUTHORITY:
Sections 7-1-4123, 7-1-4124, and 7-5-4202, Montana Code Annotated. (Ord. 288,
2-10-2004)
12-2-7: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This chapter does not affect the rights and duties that matured, penalties that
were incurred or proceedings that were begun before the effective date hereof.
(Ord. 288, 2-10-2004)
